0, 2014
												Since there's no chance in hell anyone's going to see this review, I guess there's no point in me telling you that this is objectively one of the greatest roleplaying experiences in video games ever. There is also no point in me telling you that white wolf unarguably makes the greatest vampires and one of the darkest atmospheres in any kind of game, just as there is no point in telling you that this is the kind of game that has to be experienced because we will probably never get another game like this again. And since nobody can see this, there's definitely no chance anyone will ever know that I personally recommend pirating this 100% so you don't accidentally fund a terrible publisher that ruined an amazing development team. But since this is just a review, you can make your own decisions.

content:
er 24, 2013
												The looks of this game are somewhat dated, but some ardent fans have made a texture-and-bugfix pack that alleviates this a little. Game is surprisingly good at conveying the V:tM atmosphere of the better pen & paper sessions I've had (the worse ones got bogged down in dice rolling -- for a system called "story teller", the mechanics can be annoyingly gamist). Lets you play as any of the classic clans and either sex (but looks are determined by the combination of those two factors and can't be customized further, except with clothes). I thoroughly enjoyed this game, was sad when it was over, and wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone liking the pen & paper V:tM (or even just the Kindred: the Embraced show), and anyone enjoying a decent blend of fight/RP/drama elements, as long as you can get over the yesteryear graphics.If this is your kinda thing, wait till it drops to 9.99. If you're not sure, wait till it drops below 5 again. Then go for it. You'll thank me later.And then you'll be sorry because there is no multi-player, nor a steam workshop for additional campaign, so that all good things must come to an end.

content:
r 19, 2015
												This is it. The quintessential vampire game. There are many reviews that highlight its pros and cons, so I will just say this: it's very good; play it. Be aware, however, that installing the unofficial patch isn't just recommended, but necessary, since the game is very buggy (which is by no means the developer's fault, but rather the publisher's). So check out the community hub for guides on how and where to get patches and various mods. First timers should also be careful in choosing the clan for their inaugural playthrough. For instance, Malkavian are a... peculiar breed, and some of the dialogue may be a bit confusing; you might also hear voices and talk to objects. Nosferatu, on the other hand, have an altered physical appearance (more "monstruous"), so moving around and interacting with various NPCs can be a challenge; thankfully you can use sewers, and an innate cloaking ability. Even Ventrue can be difficult, because they are selective with their food; so you won't be able to feed off rats or homeless people. But all in all, the clans are pretty balanced, so it's down to personal preference29th Oct edit: It seems Paradox bought White Wolf, which means chances for a sequel have just gone up. By a lot. Rejoice!

number of helpful: 438 of 448 people (98%) found this review helpful19 people found this review funny
content:
9, 2015
												Vampire: The Masquerade-Bloodlines is an immensely intriguing vampire-role playing game by Troika Games, and an exellent example of a "flawed masterpiece" and had a lot of things going for it.For starters, you are thrown into the game with the option of choosing between 7 different clans (vampire bloodlines) that each play a good bit differently. There's the Brujah: fast hard hitting rebels, the Gangrel: animalistic loners, the Malkavians: bat-**** crazy psychopaths, the Nosferatu: sneaky grotesque monsters, the Tremere: a vampire sect of blood mages, the Toreador: artsy fast vampires that are closer to humanity, and Ventrue: the most power hungry members of vampire society. Every single one of these classes feels distinct, as every clan has advantages and disadvantages. For example, the nosferatu get more blood from feeding on rats than the other Kindred (Vampire: The Masquerade's term for vampire), but cannot seduce anyone because of their monstrous appearence. The Ventrue are the only kindred that can use dominate (basically mind control) in dialogue, but they cannot feed on animals and may vomit when feeding on "lowlife" like street bums.Now, the gameplay is extremely engaging. Combat is fast, fun, and allows you several options. Every kindred clan has their own disciplines, or vampiric abilities, that allow you to choose your own approach to conflict. Do you use obfuscate to invisibly sneak past the goons? Or do you use "fortitude" to soak up their bullets and "animalism" to summon spectral wolves to tear them apart. It's your choice. Of course there are the standard ways of fighting: guns, unarmed, and melee weapons. There are a good variety of each weapon types (except unarmed) with upgraded weapons available to you along the way. Another potential tool for combat is feeding. As you need blood to maintain your sanity and use your disciplines, you will need to drink blood. You can drink blood from any humanoid you choose, hostile or not, but it can be more difficult to drink blood from hostiles. This is tempered by the fact that you have to stop yourself from completely draining innocent humans, but don't think twice about draining a thug. There is one problem with feeding, but I'll cover that later.I need to mention the dialogue too, as it's absolutely awesome. The facial expressions on the characters in this game are better than some of the facial expressions I see in the games coming out today, and the dialogue choices are absolutely brilliant. The Malkavians and Nosferatu get hilarious dialogue options, including an infamous one where a malkavian player character can actually get into an argument with a stop sign. A stop sign! And if I remember correctly, there's a conversation with a TV as well.The quest system is absolutely one of the best parts about this game. The side quests range from defeating demons to hunting down serial killers to fighting of zombies in a graveyard. You'll always have some sort of want to complete them because completing quests gives you experience, not killing enemies. I think this is an exellent system because this keeps you from being penalized for using stealth and guile over brute strength and bloodshed. There are quite a few missions where things turn out better in the end if you choose a stealthier, more thoughtful approach instead of going full Rambo. The main quest is no slouch either, with multiple engaging quests.I enjoy the game's atmosphere quite a bit. The endless night conveys a mysterious feeling (to be fair, it's not like you're character can feel the sun anymore) and the music lends itself to this. While sometimes the music can feel a little repetitive (combat music is determined by area, so if you get into lots of fights in one area, you're gonna hear that music a lot) I never found myself annoyed by it because it was good. There are lots of songs from real bands, such as Lacuna Coil and Tiamat.Now, time for the "flawed" part of "flawed masterpiece". The game was rushed out on the same day as Half-Life 2 because the idiocy of the game's publisher, Activition. As a result, the game has several glitches by default, so don't even think about playing the game without an unofficial patch of some sort. The late game feels less fun because it's all combat, and becomes quite tedious because before, combat was more spaced out. I don't mind mandatory combat sections, but the last portion of the game gets excessive with these. Because of the mandatory combat and power of late game weapons, if you don't have your gun skill fairly high by the end, you're screwed. Melee skills only work well when you're not being shot at by 10 enemies, and that's a rarity near the end. Also, the series of levels, the Nosferatu warrens/sewers can be very boring, unintuitive, and downright frustrating at times, as there are few sources of blood, annoying enemies, it's long as hell, and mandatory. Lastly, there is the problem with feeding. When used against normal human enemies, I don't mind it. But when it's used against a human boss, it's pretty overpowered. There is no way for an enemy to escape from your grasp besides you getting hit, so if you get your teeth on a boss while they're alone, they're done. But all in all, these things don't break the game by any means, but they should be mentioned.One last thing that makes the game great, and it should be no surprise what this is: mods. There are two mods particularly, Vampire: The Masquerade: The Final Nights, And Bloodlines Antitribu (although this one is somewhat buggy at the moment). Both (and other mods I'm forgetting ATM) add in cut content, new character models, brand new content and quests, and even new systems like the companion mods and blood loss that take the games immersion to new heights.If you had your interest piqued by this review, you should definitely pick up the game. Even now, more than a decade after the games release, I still give this game a playthrough every now and then, because it's just that good.

content:
22, 2014
												This is not Twilight. This is not Dracula. This is not Anne Rice. This is not Buffy. This is World of Darkness... and a masterpiece.Vampire: TMB's world is mysterious and complex, rich with lore from White Wolf Publishing's WoD tabletop games. The quests are memorable, characters desperate, locations varied, and character customization extensive. It is easily one of the best written RPGs ever published, right up there with the Fallout series.I would blindly recommend this to anyone remotely into verbose games. NPCs have very unique insights into the world they live in, and constantly share their philosophies with the player (the voice acting is excellent). Naturally, anyone who finds themselves bored after a few paragraphs of hearing NPCs talk should skip this game.Edit:I should have probably also mentioned that although VTMB's writing is stellar, there is also quite a bit of combat. The game strikes a nice balance between letting you feel like a ridiculously overpowered rampaging creature of the night, and a mere shadow of other, elder vampires: some fights will be hilariously easy (especially against human foes), others will be tremendously difficult (high-level supernatural enemies, yikes!). Character creation and levelling up is very comprehensive, and should be a joy for anyone who likes putting thought into how they will play the game.Please note that the game was extremely buggy when released, and is moderately difficult to run on modern PCs. See here for post-installation instructions: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035Shoutout to modder Wesp5 for keeping this game playable even 10 years after its original release!

content:
r 19, 2014
												This is by far one of my favorite games. I seriously play it at least once every year or so. VTMB is not your basic Vampire RPG. The game allows you to switch between first and third person, features both melee and ranged combat, and allows you mutliple paths to any of your goals. This is set in White Wolf's World of Darkness universe. If you are familiar with table-top RPGs and the World of Darkness, good, if not that is okay (I was not).The World of Darkness is your basic modern urban fantasy universe. You the player take the part of a newly created vampire thrust into a world of intrigue and darkness where ancient vampires pull the strings of humanity and each other in ever-shifting alliances and plans. The game allows you a high degree of customization, when creating your character you can choose from one of 6 clans, which feature different superpowers that your character can build as you level. There are no classes, you build your stats how you want them. Your quests almost all feature multiple paths to completion. Need to kill a vampire hunter? Well you can talk your way into her place of work (if you got the speech skills), sneak around the pack and pick some locked doors (if you have the stealth and lockpicking skills), maybe hack some computers to put the place into lockdown and get civilians to leave the area (if you have the hacking skills), or maybe you just want to kick in the front door and go to work with your katana/shotgun/teeth&claws. In this game there are mutilple paths to your goal. A few different endings (choose one of the factions or yourself), and enless playthrough ability. Visit the community forums for this game and download the fanmade patches, they will give you extra quests, clans and plug some bugs.Seriously. I can't reccomend this game highly enough.

content:
er 16, 2015
												Firstly, you will need the unofficial patch to play this (so here it is: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647.) The original devs were pushed to release this early by activision, thus it was very buggy. BUT that said, this is easily one of the best RPGs ever concieved. (Also ignore the low play time, for some reason when I installed the patch on my last system the patch only worked if I launched it off of steam, my play time probably numbers in the hundreds of hours.)So, Pros-The Role Playing aspect of this game is very deep, I haven't played a game in a long time that rivals it. You can play as one of 7 vampire 'clans' (which are basically sub species of a sort.) Each clan has it's own unique skill sets, meaning each clan have strengths and weaknesses. Whether it's the toreador with their seductive ability to manipulate practically anyone, the nosferatu, who can stealth their way into just about anywhere, or the brujah who are your more naturally brawling vampire type. Each of the seven clans has distinct strengths and distinct weaknesses. -Skill specialisation means that you can't be a jack of all trades, if you commit to being a silver tongued devil that talks their way into and out of everything, then you won't be as good at fighting. The opposite is also true, and considering that being good at persuasion/seduction doesn't result in bloodshed this means your vampire will naturally be able to accomplish things that a violent vampire would not, again the opposite is true.-Because of this, the game has vast replayability, as even a slightly different playstyle results in quite a different story. -Speaking of replayability, Malkavians are amazing, but they are insane, I would not recommend playing them on your first playthrough. Nosferatu can also be really fun, but are hard to play because you cannot be seen by mortals.-Leads me on to another important point. The Maquerade itself. The Masquerade is a conspiracy of vampire culture that maintains the illusion to mortals that they don't exist. Meaning that you can't behave in a supernatural way in certain areas, lest you violate the masquerade and incur the discipline of vampire culture. Certain abilities can still be used, depending on whether they are discreet or not, this is another layer of depth to the roleplaying system, as some vampire clans are naturally more capable in masquerade areas. For me personally, I am an avid player of the Toreador (It appeals to the part of me that adore the Anne Rice books.) This clan plays exceptionally well in masquerade areas because they are the most 'human' of all the vampire types, whereas the Nosferatu for example cannot be seen in these areas due to their appearance.-The Characters in this are not necessarily believable (some are very convincing, some are less so,) but either way the characters are... well... characters... You will love them, and you will love them a lot, the voice acting is amazing, and so is the facial animation, (which is ridiculously expressive, notice I say expressive, not necessarily realistic.) Dialogue options are also insanely awesome in a bethesda before bethesda kind of way. Cons-Combat (it pains me to mention it, but I have to.) The combat in this game doesn't bother me, but it can be a bit twitchy. Don't worry, we're not talking morrowind levels of twitchy, but it's a little twitchy nonetheless. But it's very easy to overlook because everything else in this game is so on point. -I should probably mention this as a con, but I just see it as an inevitable mechanic: There are points in the game where you simply cannot avoid intense combat. This can really annihilate a social vampire, so it's good to invest the odd point into ranged weapons once every now and then (because ranged weapons are generally the best thing to deal with the late game combat.) This seems to put some people off the game but it really doesn't bother me that much, and again i'm willing to overlook it because everything else in the game is done so damn well.In summary this game is one of the gems of the rpg genre, and you can't call yourself a fan of roleplaying games if you haven't checked this out. it is THE example of a flawed masterpiece; something which had so much ambition and very nearly lived up to it all but fell just a little short. But in spite of this the game is still way above average, and very close to perfection. And it represents something that more games developers should aspire to, because this game went for the moon, and damn nearly got there. Games aren't this ambitious anymore, they don't try to be this unusual any more, and if something did in this generation of gaming, it would truly be a masterpiece.

												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is a RPG about vampires, their clans and that vampires don't show their true identity to humans for fear of being eradicated. First, vampires have a bad stand with gamers. They all remember how being a vampire sucked in Elder Scroll's Oblivion or how girls made them watch those stupid twilight movies. We have all been there, mate! ++ Jeanette and Therese.+ Good atmosphere+ Believable characters+ Picking a clan over another one matters.+ Big skill tree+ Good facial animations that hold up even today.+ Good first half of the game.+ Funny dialogue-- Major technical issues. Don't try out this game in an unpatched state. This game was an unoptimized and buggy mess when it was released and only the patches fixed it.- Combat could be better- Second half isn't as good nor fun as the first.- Some animations are awful- The endings felt a bit rushed. Some choices during the game should have mattered more.- Some maps or rooms needed more details or objects.The Masquerade is built on an early source engine version and was an unoptimized and buggy mess when it was rushly released. Note that installing either the official or the unofficial patch is essential. Additional links Unofficial Patch: http://www.moddb.com/mods/vtmb-unofficial-patchPerformance issues can be solved by vampyri_lestat's guide: https://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/914819-vampire-the-masquerade-bloodlines/faqs/43148Replay value: Potentially high (with different endings, clans, skills and some choices during the game)Rating: 8.5/10Recommendation: Yes

content:
28, 2014
												Bought this game while on sale thinking it was gonna be pretty so-so. I'd heard things about Vampire: The Masquerade before, but never actually tried it. Boy am I glad I did. This game is like a hidden gem. The graphics are outdated, but what else can you expect from a game that's over 10 years old? If you enjoyed being able to make your own story in Dragon Age or Mass Effect, you may enjoy Vampire: The Masquerade, as it allows you to choose conversation options and shape your character's path. Although you can't customise the appearance of your character (other than clothing), you can choose between 7 different races of vampires of each gender, each with different abilities. Other clothing options can later be bought from the different locations throughout the game, each giving more armour and a different look from the last.The story begins with your character and the opposite gender version of your character's race getting 'friendly', and your character will be Embraced (turned). Unfortunately, your sire has commited a violation of the Masquerade by Embracing someone without permission, and is executed for their crimes. Left sireless, after an intervention by the vampire Nines you are allowed a chance to live, but you must 'serve' LaCroix, the prince. During the story, you'll learn what Sabbat, Camarilla, Kuel'jin and many other things are. But I won't spoil the story for you, go play it yourself.The downside of this game is that, in order to play it, you must do a few things. There are a few bugs that will not allow the game to play on Steam. To combat this, you must run Steam in administrator mode and change the compatibility properties of Vampire: The Masquerade. I changed the properties to run the program in compatibility mode for Windows XP (Service Pack 3), and disabled visual themes and desktop compositions. Doing these steps should allow you to run the game. But that's not all. Even though this game is old, there are still unofficial patches being made for it. I recommend installing Wesp's unofficial patch 8.9 at least, as this will fix the resolution error with the game and make the interface clear instead of blurry. Each patch contains everything from the patches before, so you can install the latest one without missing anything. The patches fix a lot of bugs and add things to the game. However, with each patch you must make it a fresh install, delete everything from the patches before (this includes your save files) and replace them with the new patch. The game may crash if you do not do this. You should replace the folder named Vampire inside your Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines folder with the patch folder, which will also be named Vampire. You must also disable the auto updates for the game in the Steam properties, or it may install the old official patch over your unofficial one.Overall, I really enjoyed this game. Some of the boss fights were quite challenging, there is a lot of side quests and missions to keep you occupied, and you can choose your character's destiny in the world of darkness. You can choose to be a saucy seductress, a badmouthed badass, anything really. And if you choose a Malkavian, you'll have different conversation options than the other races, as Malkavian's have a sort of split personality and insanity. I wish there was a sequel or something. Sucks that the World of Darkness MMO based on this universe was recently cancelled as I was looking forward to it, but what can you do.~ 9/10 ~

er 26, 2013
												It has everything a good RPG needs: A deep class system, interesting story, fun dialogue, frantic first- and third-person combat, set in an atmospheric world inhabited by humans and vampires alike. You play as a vampire and whilst having access to a vast and diverse array of powers (depending on your chosen class), you will also have to disguise yourself so as not to be discovered by humans and thus breaking the "Masquerade". Along with the main quests, the world is filled with many fun side missions, both of which are told through rich and interesting dialogues delivered by some great voice acting.Overall a great and unique game set in an atmospheric world; especially a must have due to its refreshing and unused setting.

number of helpful: 121 of 131 people (92%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
er 31, 2014
												Many moons ago a developer named Troika Games released Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines yet through its lifetime it has managed to linger behind the curtain despite the generally unrivalled quality it bears. I wish to open the curtain and propose you to join me in this ‘sombre dance’. To start off you get to choose between 7 quite varied classes, called clans. Want to play as a Nosferatu and deal massive damage but have the sewers as your main travel path, or would you rather be of the noble kind, a master of eloquence and persuasion but lack physical prowess? Or maybe you fancy the clinically insane that suffers from schizophrenia? I chose the clinically insane because... well as if you wouldn't...and it turned out I chose well because the Malkavian is indubitably one of the most creative character you can play in video games.From the start, you'll notice major technical issues and design decisions that indicate the game was released on its last legs. Their dream nearly did indeed turn to dust as the company went bust soon after its release. In spite of this, the team managed to make a game that unfortunately today is a merely an ash, but a game that still to this day goes against the grain. Eventually an (unofficial) patch was released that made the game much more playable. It takes a very conventional approach to customization. On offense you can choose to specialise in guns, unarmed, melee and powers known as disciplines. The defensive counterparts also exist. Each clan has its own set of disciplines that you can specialise in. In addition you can level up skills including hacking, lock picking, intimidation, seduction, research etc and some of these skills add extra dialogue options which can lead to otherwise unavailable rewards. Loot isn’t as abundant as in Bethesda games for example but it exists in moderate amounts. The game features your standard health bar and a blood bar for good measure. You fuel your blood bar by using civilians as sustenance. The refuel rate varies on the civilian type and caution is required since if you get caught you lose masquerade points and once that reaches zero you lose the game for reasons you can find out for yourself. Additionally killing civilians (for example) will lower your humanity and once that reaches a certain point your character does bad things. The graphics are dated but definitely passable.These aforementioned issues, these run of the mill customization options are ultimately trivial because the game manages to supersede its faults completely as it ironically isn't devoid of spirit and soul. The game induces perturbation, states of uneasiness, disorientation and even sheer unadulterated terror in both expected and unexpected locations that’ll make you just wish you could give it a maniacal final vale and go make a sandwich while playing Skyrim or something. It isn't all doom and gloom though. This atmosphere, this ‘sombre dance’ can quickly shift to an upbeat vampiric club rave (literally). Of course this tonal shift is entirely at your digression but it's this type of juxtaposition that makes the sinister and foreboding moments all the more significant. The game has quite a few unique takes on conventional missions and a cast of absolutely impeccable characters. These characters can be usually manipulated depending on the clan you choose. For example If you choose the insane schizophrenic, you can use mind control on people to make weird gigglies and other disturbing lines come out their facehole which consequently will make gigglies come out of your facehole. To please the masses there’s also tons of philosophical yet hilarious one liners too.As an encore the game washes you with its masterful soundtrack. It’s an eclectic bunch of tunes that amplify the various moods you’ll feel in the game. Whether it’s ominous or calm, frantic or upbeat it does its job. At times there’s an absence of music where ambience is created by the sound of the world around you which in my mind is a soundtrack in itself. This natural ambience can be felt in many places but for the majority of people it will be most memorable in the Ocean House Hotel, considered by those who’ve experienced it as one of the most frightening areas in video games, alongside Shalebridge Cradle from Thief Deadly Shadows. No other game has matched the level of trepidation I felt in The Ocean House Hotel.Upon release, a significant portion of those who played it hated it because it was marred by its technical issues of which it became infamous for but the biggest cause of its demise was its release alongside Half Life 2. Luckily the game is still on sale today so bless your blood vessels by biting into this magical game like the pale lotus eater that you know you are because once you are done, you'll realise that this product, in this large market where the generic usually flourish most, is an ensemble of special silence and Troika's genuine, bittersweet farewell kiss.Mod Recommendations: Unofficial patch: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647

content:
er 23, 2013
												Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a RPG from publisher Activision and developed by Troika Games. For years I'd been hearing from various people about  how great this title is and now that I've played it I must totally agree. Roleplaying games are my bread and butter so this title definitely delivers with its core RPG elements. You create your character and as you progress through the game you acquire experience points which you can then distribute to many different skills and abilities thus allowing you to customize your vampire to your liking and particular style of play be that close or long ranged combat or stealth. The game is action oriented and played in either a first or third person perspective similiar to say Fallout 3 or New Vegas. Graphically the game is dated especially compared to many of the titles from recent years but with the addition of the unofficial patches by Wesp5 and various others you can update the title with high resolution textures and an abundance of bug fixes and enhancements that make it look fairly great for a game that was released so long ago. I myself am a fan of games with retro and outdated graphics and this title just has a nice style to it that fits the dark and forboding theme perfectly. Even better, the dialogue that I've been having throughout the game is one of my favorite aspects of the title as the voice acting is top notch and done so very well. Released in 2004 this game also seems to have been doing things slightly ahead of its time...things that we take for granted as they are very common place in the games of today. Pound for poind I'm loving this title and plan to spend many hours playing it so it is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!! P.S.-Thanks to Section Nine http://steamcommunity.com/id/Section9/ for providing the links to the patches for the game.

content:
er 10, 2014
												Vampire; the Masquerade - BloodlinesBefore purchasing please note you will need to download an Unofficial Patch to fully get the game to work.Storyline, lore and depth is heavy in this game. When you first lay eyes on it, it might be an eye sore, but trust me. Start to sink your fangs into the first few victims and get lost into the twisted personal horror game that lets you cling to your humanity while witnessing unGodly, unspeakable things... or let loose and become the monster you always wanted to be all the while walking the thin red line of not breaking too many Kindred laws.The RPG element comes from the table top version of the game, point in intel, point in strength, point in charisma or melee, the concept is easy to use for beginners and easy to follow if you hover your mouse over any stat. It will tell you exactly what other stats benifit from your choices. Lacking in Hacking? Lacking in lock picking? (Dues Ex - like skills) Just add points to whatever helps you make you better at what you like doing.Game play: When you start you pick a clan, each clan has their own strengths, their own weaknesses. Adding to the replay value of the game. Brawl your way, punk your enemies into submission, lie or whisper sweet nothings into the humans' ears to manipulate them into giving you what you want. Stealth your way through the city via sewers and back alleys, stick to the shadows - or walk among the humans and other vampires as their superior. It's all up to you.Lots of side quests and though the world is not too vast (hence the game was made in 2004) you will have plenty to do with the portions of the city you have access to. Some you will need to gain specific skills, others you will get to as the game progresses.The music is awesome. 90's and early 2000's gothic/rock, dark metal music. Will be looking for the OST of this game.Voice acting, Jeanette! And many others. Even a popular actor from the TV show Futurama voice acted in this. Jeanette's voice actress did a role for Harley Quinn as well. Love her work! One of the strongest parts of this game is conversing with the NPCs. Some are funny, others will make you annoyeed, but none will be boring. Certain powers and certain social skills will effect how NPCs interact and react to you. Some you will need to threaten, if your threat is high enough, some you will have to persuade, others you have to flirt with, and some (if you pick clan Malkavian) you can just talk crazy talk with them. All adding to the depth of each NPC and some making you wish you could talk with them all night long.The game is a Horror game, and some jump scares, but the feeling I get from playing the game... CREEP FEST. The atmosphere of the game when you get into a haunted house, or exploring a mad house, or going into a den of those trying to hurry the end of the world... and the sewers! It will make you think twice about opening a manhole, in real life and in game.Over all this game is a CULT CLASSIC. If anything, get it and play it so when you nerd it out with your friends online or in person, you can give them lots of bloody tales of your own experiances in Vampire - Bloodlines.9.5 / 10 Play it! Worth every penny at full price and at 75% off. No reason not to on a big sale!

content:
9, 2015
My Review on VTMBTl:dr Awesome game with (in my eyes) no downside, high replayability, nice characters and a dark story/atmosphere. If you are not sure if you want it, wait for a sale. If you have no problem with older games in your library and love RPG’s, get it instantly and stop reading.Now to the main part of the Review....So I was thinking that I need a new RPG to play. It should have a nice story, good gameplay and some open choices for the player. After a long time searching I found Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines. I waited for a long time, before grabbing it on sale and what can I say....I love it.First things first as you may read in other reviews, this game has many bugs. Luckily there is a nice Community that fixes them and brings patches for the game. Before you play it make sure you download the latest patch found here: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647. Now let’s start with The Review itself, why do I love this game so much? First, it is inspired by the Vampire: The Masquerade Pen and Paper, and the universe of it, a universe that is deep and complex, and instantly took a place in my heart, where Vampires live along mortal people with rules they have to keep, called the Masquerade. In that world, there are 7 playable and some more (Npc only) Clans that all play in a different way and even have a small impact on your story. The Clans are called: Brujah, Gangrel, Malkavian, Nosferatu, Toreador, Tremere and Ventrue. At the beginning you pick 1 of these, decide if you are female or male (sadly no more customization) and then you allocate your "standard skill points" in your character sheet, whilst every clan has his own abilities and different bonuses on some of the attributes.Then the Story starts. After a pretty, long but well-made intro sequence you can control your character. The controls feel a bit strange at first and you may have to enable mouse look in the options to get a free camera, everything else should feel similar to rpg players/source users.The graphic is also well designed and fits the dark theme of this game perfectly well, as does the synchronization. What I liked was the fighting style. You have different melee and ranged weapons that reach from a Tire Iron and a magnum to a katana and a flamethrower. While you fight in 3rd person with your melee weapons, you switch to 1st person while using your ranged firearms. Also nice : most of your attributes increase more than 1 ability, example: 1 point of dexterity will get you +1 lockpicking and +1 sneaking skill, strength will get you +1 unarmed and +1 melee and so on, so there are many different ways to design and actually play your character, which leads to the next point. The Story has to my knowledge 5 endings, that trigger with your final choice and your positioning to the factions (called sects), which are the Camarilla (the "standard" vampire community) the Anarchs (fighters against the Camarilla) and the Kuei-Jin (eastern vampires that are slightly different). And while you don't actively decide your standing, your actions that you make in the story "speak" for you.And finally The Difficulty...... I love it. The Disciplines between the clans are well balanced and with the right combination of Disciplines and weapons, even the hardest bosses turn to ash in seconds (recommandation: Flamethrower)So what can I say.... I guess the fact I recommended the game and my playtime + this review are showing it is worth playing, but again get the unofficial patch and if you are unsure get it on sale. Now excuse me while I enjoy my 2nd playthrough.

content:
r 23, 2014
												This game is a cult classic.  You should be warned that this game is broken and will not function on most modern machines.  There is an Unofficial Patch made by Wesp5 that fixes nearly all issues with the game and also adds new content. Based on the board game, and sequel to Redemption, you play as a fledgling Vampire in California.  The story starts as you create your character.  Here you choose your background, bloodline, and gender.  Backgrounds change your stats slightly and your powers as a vampire will differ depending on your bloodline.  Some bloodlines have some side effects, however.  The best examples are Malkavians and Nosferatu.  Malkavians are insane and schizophrenic.  You'll talk like a crazy person, hear voices in your head and see things other people don't see.  Nosferatu are cursed in a different way as they can't be seen by humans without violating the masquerade.  This does not make it impossible to beat the game as a Nosferatu, because the main quest NPC's will still be approachable.The masquerade is a system in the game where if you get 5 bad marks it's game over and you'll be executed by your peers.  You earn bad marks by displaying certain powers in public or are seen feeding.  You can redeem yourself if you have bad marks by protecting the masquerade.  This usually involves killing someone who is speaking  too much or who isn't playing it safe like all other good little vampires should.  Graphics are decent and passable.  The game is an older game, so don't expect mind blowing visuals.  City hubs are fairly small but there's a lot to find if you set your mind to it.  There are some nice facial animations that you won't even see in games nowadays which adds to the immersion.  There's also several mods for the game to add atmosphere and even more depth to the classes.  Gameplay is basic.  You shoot things, you smash things.  You talk to people, you kill people.  There are extra dialog options if you level your seduction, intimidation, or persuassion skills.  These skills can be vital to completing some quests perfectly.  You can also recieve bonuses from certain NPC's for having them at the required level at certain points in conversation.  You gain experience from doing quests and you level up to gain strength, wisdom, guile, skill, and become more attractive.  If you're sexy enough you get free hookers! Just like IRL! =P  The beginning of the game will mostly be fetch quests, with a few baddies to either slaughter or let live.  It's a game where you can put the fate of nearly everyone around you in your hands.  Being good is rewarded with extra perks like your very own slave ghoul girl, or an extra item/money/experience.  There's also a decent but easy stealth system that's based on how many points you have in stealth.  If you max out stealth, are in the shadows and crouch you're pretty much invisible.  There are also assassinations you can do with each weapon while stealthed and behind your victim.  My favorite is the baseball bat.  :)Audio is very good as well.  Just make sure you turn Environmental Effects off or there will be a constant echo.  Voice actors are all top notch and AAA grade ones that you'll know if you've heard them before.There are some very good mods for this game available as well.  My favorite being the original Unofficial Patch Plus, but there are other that increase the difficulty of the game and add new quests and bloodlines to choose from.  When installing these big mods you need to remember that they aren't compatible with eachother.  E.G. Final Nights mod will not work with Camarilla Edition nor with either work with the Unofficial Patch.  Both mods have an Older version of the Unofficial patch that come with it, which still fixes a lot of bugs.  There's also several mods  that are still being produced constantly by fans.  Every now and then you should check up and see what new mods are out to keep you coming back for more. All in all, if you are in need of a good RPG that's open world with a lot of freedom and are tired of Fallout 3/NV, Skyrim, etc.  Then you should definately check this game out.  Especially if it's on sale.  Well worth every penny spent.

er 23, 2016
												Oh, Bloodlines. The epitome of "cult classic". This game is the most unpolished gem I've ever seem in my gaming life. It was difficult to overlook it's many bugs, and in it's time, this game suffered from incredibly poor losses (also because of a bad business launch date). However, as the time passed and the modding community adressed most of it's glaring problems, this game finally blossomed into an experiece worth of the pantheon of the best RPGs ever made.Because make no mistake: underneath that filthy layer of bugs and it's shortcomings of production/lack of content, lies one of the best RPGs ever made. Seriously. I wholeheartedly recommend you to buy it, whatever the price tag is, with a simple caveat: use the mods that fix it otherwise your experience will be undeniably disapointing.The way the IP behind this game is treated (Vampire: The Masquerade, one of the best storyteller RPGs ever) is incredible, it will plunge you down to the World of Darkness and hook you up with an engrossing mature story with all the right touches of horror and sensualization we all love about vampires. Never before or since playing a vampire character would be so cool.The mechanics are not the high point but enough to be called "good". The engine is the same as Half-Life 2, and it aged pretty well. The voice acting is ♥♥♥♥ing AMAZING. The story as multiple endings and the choices you make matter (to some degree), making for an incredible narrative. The Vampire Storyteller progression system is here, with slight tweaks, and it's awesome.You basically play as one of the classic Camarilla clans. I won't say much more, because the word of advice here is THIS GAME IS WORTH IT< VERY MUCH WORTH IT, JUST USE THE MODS TO FIX IT.

er 29, 2016
												One of the best video games of all time and one of my eternal favorites.The world, story and atmosphere are unparalelled.In contrast to other known Vampire fictions, this one happens in modern day Los Angeles where by luck (bad or good) a steamy night of wild debauchery drains all of your bodily fluids and thrusts you into the world of the undead.Even though the stiffs are divided between faux-regality and anarchists, they all follow rules of the Masquerade - as a bearded man once said "Sheep need not know that the wolf is here". And by all of them i mean those who are not hairy beasts or necromantic golems of stolen flesh. But that's another story.A choice of 7 clans offers gameplay more diverse than any class choice in any other game ever could.You're not just picking your skills and appearance here. You're picking your unlife.For instance, as a diabolic Tremere you will often find yourself using the blood magic exclusive to your clan to explode your enemies from inside out.As a deformed Nosferatu, your non-human appearance will force you to live and travel through the sewers, as any human who sees you will surely get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ heart attack triggering 6 GTA Police stars.Meanwhile as my favorite - an insane Malkavian, you will be a spoiler spewing machine who encounters events exclusive to those not of sound mind and all of your dialogue choices will represent your twisted psyche - in a hilarious way.The game is packed with varied weapons if you think that a revolver would be a nice bonus to the vampiric powers, a lot of side-quests if you're thirsty for these, and a cast of characters that you will not forget. Like a vampire ♥♥♥♥ who sure likes to party, half of the time.Just be warned, use Wesp's Unofficial Patch. Devs meant well but they were cut short, thankfully community has carried on their legacy.The game is a must play.

content:

												 As a rule, when a game is so poorly made that it almost doesn't work without a fan patching it, I normally consider it a failure. When the last half of a game is just a maze with enemies that you kill while feeling lost and confused and the combat system is pretty sub-par, I consider it a waste of money... ... But the first half of this game is So Bloody Good! It has story! It has characters! It has non-violent solutions if you're a social character! It has sneaking solutions if you're a stealth character! It has hacking and knowledge solutions if you're an intelligent character! Remember how everyone praised Deus Ex for having all these things? Multiple solutions to problems that allow your character to focus on things other than shooting and stabbing? This was like that, only you drink blood! Then there's the last half of the game... You can almost feel the moment that the money runs out and Activison come knocking at the door, demanding the alpha build be put in stores tomorrow. There's a perceptible shift from multiple solutions, story focus and character driven conversations into: "Go to this place and kill everyone. Enter this 5 x 5 room. You see 3 orcs, roll to hit the nearest one!" This game was almost something very beautiful but, like a relationship with a shallow woman, it just needed more money thrown at it! Like heating a microwave dinner, it really needs more time than they gave it. Buy it on the cheap, patch the game, play the first half... If you reach the part where you have to start just running around and killing enemies constantly and you're invested, see it out, otherwise maybe use a cheat or something and just skip the boring, endless corridors of mooks.

number of helpful: 41 of 48 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
y 29
												I doubt I'll see anything else like this for as long as I live. That's the true tragedy of V:TMB. As the years pass, and the game industry grows increasingly stagnant and problematic, only the biggest most profitable game franchises can survive. This means that year after year we'll keep seeing the Elder Scrolls, the Call of Dutys, the newest Mario spin, and whatever else; probably Final Fantasy 55 at this point. Point is, a game like this wouldn't even come close to piercing the surface of mainstream interest, let alone acclaim. So, firstly, enjoyment in this game hinges entirely on how much you like vampires. This game takes after the actual role playing lore and books very closely. That means a lot of weird terminology, specifics, and politicking. Unfortunately, this is where V:TMB runs into problems. Limitations, namely. I can see the vision the creators had, and their dedication to the niddy gritty is appreciated, but the game is held back by itself in a lot of cases. This is a clunker of a game, and I don't think anyone would be able to defend that. Everything feels so... Crude. It just doesn't hold a candle to games that had their engine in better order. Even contemporary or earlier games could handle some of these problems. Inventory management is a chore. Flipping through separate pages for items is a pain. What's worse is the combat, which won't get any mercy from me. It's pretty bad. And not bad in the charming way. Just bad. Things rapidly go downhill after your first fight. Hits lack impact, and the thrill of sending enemies spinning with a three hit combo wears off fast when every enemy in the game does that. Ranged combat fares the same. None of the guns feel especially satisfying to use; aside from maybe the sniper rifle, but that's just from the sheer power of it.But let's talk about something immediate. This game won't run without a patch. It simply can't understand recent hardware enough to run without a patch. The thing is, this game hasn't been updated at all. The original creators left this game in a state, like a poor abandoned puppy. So, downloading a patch will be your first order of business if you buy this game. Which, I don't know why you would, considering its current year, but whatever.What about the rest of the game? The characters in general are very convincing for their roles. I wanted to talk to them as much as I could. Customization for the player character isn't what I'd consider modern, but it is very interesting. How you want to play will likely rest on your choice of lineage, or vampire clan. Sidequests on the whole are rewarding. The plot itself is interesting, sure, but falls short on some points. It feels like you get some real choices here. Not only with what kind of ending you want, but also how you want to play, or role play, I should say. I have yet to see another video game that legitimately lets you play an insane person; an insane person that speaks in gibberish riddles no less. Now, whether that's a result of my patch or the base game, I'm not sure, but its impressive nonetheless. This game makes big strides for player freedom, but has limits of its own to worry about. It feels like you're put on story rails, and after a while of playing the main storyline, I'll admit, it got a bit exhausting. It seems like everywhere I turned in this game, it was lacking that extra bit of grandeur it desperately needed. It's a shame.It's dated. It hasn't aged well. It tries, sure. It chugs along as well as it can. But what goes through my mind when I play this game isn't "wow what a blast from the past," its more like "what would this game look like if it was made today with twice the budget?" This is a true role playing game. There's rolling dice for damage. There's leveling up your stat points, and spending blood points to use any one of your hereditary vampire powers. This is serious nerdery at work here, and I love it, because no other games but the most fringe nerd experiments would embark on this complete transition. Its exceptionally admirable. But apparently it wasn't made to be. Instead we get rpgs that streamline and dumb down formulas. We get games that are rpgs in name only, We get games that fail to bring anything interesting to the table at all.What I'm saying is, this game is a miracle. For every stilted exchange, there is a cool little sidequest. For every half finished stealth section, there is a piece of interesting lore shown to you. Whatever immovable objects that had to align to make this game possible, I'm thankful for them. It might not be the best or most entertaining game, but damned if its not a piece of gaming history. Unlike Fallout, its unlikely that this franchise will ever see the light of day. But for a quaint little vampire game, that's not too bad.

content:
er 19, 2014
												The stronger points of the game are that it has a fantastically dark atmosphere, believable and often intense characters (something which alot of games lack), and a solid storyline that does the game justice. Also, you choose at the beginning which bloodline (faction) you are part of, which will directly affect your relationships with the characters in-game, offering variation and replayablility, if you don't mind already knowing the storyline the second time through. Finally, the level design is very well done, giving varied and interesting locations that will keep your interest, no rampant cookie-cutter design here.On the down side, it is a dated game, having been released in 2004, so you will probably only get the most out of it if you don't mind the avatars looking a bit blocky compared to what you might be used to. I'm sure it was 'fairly' close to cutting edge graphics in 2004, but if you can look past it, the game will suck you in and you won't notice.It was mentioned that the game doesn't feel finished by one reviewer, and while I disagree, I can see why that might come up. The game is completely set at night, so far as I can remember, so you won't get the bustling city feel that daytime would bring, and also it doesn't have a huge amount of side quests that seem to pack into games these days (to cover up lack of original content), but there is plenty to keep you occupied.. you won't get bored.Also, apparently the game was quite buggy at release. I'd used the official patch when I played it, and didn't come across any problems. I certainly didn't come close to checking on forums, as one or two others had, but everyone plays a game differently, and it's becoming standard practice to check forums rather than think a problem through, or work around it. Regardless, apparently the unofficial patch made by fans is the best, from what I gather.Overall I greatly enjoyed the game and thought it to be underrated, definately a pleasant surprise. At no point did I get bored, even though there are many areas, nor did I question whether I'd see it through to the end, unlike quite a few games which get churned out. The storyline was interesting, and I found myself carefully watching the behaviour of all the characters, not quite sure who to trust, as it should be in a vampire underworld. The hotel level was especially spooky, I might add ;) good job on that. I only wish that there was a sequel.

If you try it, I would highly recommend getting hold of the community patch - which fixes 95% of what was wrong with the game at launch. Please, developers - give us more games like this. ber 14, 2016
												I've just completed my first playthrough, and all I can say is consider me a parrot. Anything positive or negative you see in someone else's review is no doubt something I will also be saying.In short:-It has its share of flaws, primarily in the combat - but it doesn't matter. There's nothing else like it, especially in todays market. I found the combat a bit clumsy but enjoyable, and only the occasional bugs made me swear in anger. I got this bug a few times where I couldn't change weapons or couldn't change my view from third to first person. It got annoying, but reloading usually fixed it.-Class variety is excellent. (I've watched other people let's play classes besides the one I chose, and the actual storylines and character to character interactions vary drastically with some classes; The gameplay experience will also be very unique with some character types.)-Multiple outcomes for missions/multiple ways to approach missions (think Deus Ex but a bit dialed back in some cases) plus multiple endings.-Great story, great characters, great voice acting.-------------------------------If you do want to get this game, make sure to download and install the Unofficial Patch. It's a simple google search and drag and drop install, and it fixes many issues with the game and even adds missing quest lines and balances combat for the better. There is no reason not to experience this title. I waited many years, always thinking to myself it would be too dated, too cheesy, not worth it, etc. I was wrong. From start to finish, you will be under this games spell - like a devilishly handsome vampire seducing you with his cold stare. Embrace the night, uphold the masquerade, and as many others have said before me - do not open it.

er 4, 2016
Product received for free
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is the best half game ever. I love this game, everyone should. It reminds me a lot of Deus Ex and if given more development and money this could have been even better. It pains me when I see all the wasted potential of this hidden gem.The writing is top notch, the stat system is robust and the choice of clans is a really great addition with some clans in particular pretty much changing the entire gameplay. The combat takes a lot of getting used to and that is not an understatement but it's fine enough considering this is an RPG and not a standard action game. The graphics are really good for the time considering the engine it is using the feel of the game is not like anything else you'll see. For those of you unaware, this takes place in a modern Los Angeles setting with hidden clan of vampires. It's like Angel but with nosferatu.However all that comes with a problem. The development is incredibly depressing to read about and I'll save you the details of what game came out the same day, but the point is this is clearly unfinished. The longer the you play the game the less freedom you get until finally you end the game with one of the most disappointing final missions I've played. It really is a shame since I do love this game so much.You need to play this if you love WRPGs. In fact many people consider it one of their favourites let alone favourite games of all time and I can understand why for the most part but it just slips out of that for me due to its diminishing quality over the game. This game still has fan patches being made constantly and for your sake get it immediately. Bloodlines might not be perfect but it'll be hard to find a game as rewarding, fun and memorable as this. Rest in peace Troika, you will be missed.

content:
ry 1
												This game is like wine; the more it ages, the better it's getting.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines truly is a unique hidden gem among games that for some reason never loses its charm no matter how much you play it. It doesn't strike me as surprising to see that even to this day that there is an active community still creating patches, mods, and content despite its release in 2004. With that being said, the replay-value is tremendous and upholds alot of unique writing mixed with extensive vocabulary and a passion for extravagant settings, atmosphere and level-design. Admittedly, considering that this game has been overseen by many, there still is no game that comes even remotely close to what this game is offering you despite how much it has aged over a decade. Now, it would be unfair if I wouldn't mention its disastrous state when being released with its horrendous bugs and glitches that more likely scared people off from buying it, however, I could talk about how the developers struggled creating this game based on the Source-Engine when the engine itself still was being developed. Also this game is extremely unpolished, unfinished and it doesn't take a genius to see where exactly they struggled developing the game when in its initial state is almost unplayable without the patches, that gladfully fixed and added alot of content throughout the game. But I'd like to keep that aside for now, since there's more to this game than meets the eye.You're starting off as a fellow kindred - a newborn vampire so to speak, and suddenly your fate will be met with a hidden vampire society called "Camarilla", that have a strict code of conduct they must obey in order to survive and uphold the masquerade that serves as a protection from humanity finding out about the existence of vampires within their society. As soon as you leave the meeting, you are on your own without anyone to rely on or trust, except a vampire called "Jack" that simply teaches you the basics of your new life as a kindred. Now, if that alone isn't less of any help, you will be put out there all alone by yourself and any wrong move disturbing the masquerade such as violently exhibiting agressive behaviour may even lead to your immediate execution - of course, after breaking the masquerade a several times understandably. Anyhow, you are pretty much relying on yourself without any explanations as to why you became a creature of darkness, but these answers you will have to deliever yourself, which makes this game so unique in the first place. There absolutely is no hand holding you, telling you to go there and do this - no annoying quests that play out the same repetitive cycle that is: gathering, combat, exploration and boring dialogue. Every quest in this game is incredibly unique and well-thought giving you alot of choices how to respond and thus change the outcome. Oh, have I also mentioned the dialgoue choices? There's plenty. And I mean plenty to choose from. From seducing to intimidating that perfectly well suits all your roleplay needs at once. This is all about you being you.I could also talk about the graphics and performance of this game, you know, the technical side of things! But there really isn't much to see here except outdated graphics and a stable framerate. Make no mistake, this game still has some pretty aspects when it comes to graphics but overall it's a fairly ugly game, but that shouldn't keep you from playing it as when it comes to characters you have facial expressions you've never seen before except in Half-Life 2 and some other exceptional games, even to this very day many games lack fluid animations and facial expressions - and VTMB gives you exactly what the games nowadays are missing, not only technically. Anyway, you are more likely to ignore the ugly graphics once you indulge into this masterpiece and I can assure you that it will be that way.The soundtrack you may ask? Well, generally the soundtrack is pretty much mediocre or at least decent to a certain scale. Many of the voice clips are re-cycled especially when it comes to fighting, but that only goes for cops or generic enemies you will have to deal with from the beginning. The voice acting in this game really is good! I mean it's nothing groundbreaking but all of the voice actors or at least partially some are known roles in games that come out these days, or memoreable games that people adore. So in that aspect I can only say that I enjoyed the soundtrack as well as the voice acting.The storyline of this game is very well-written and that goes for side-quests as well. Never have I felt so indulged and motivated to look around and eventually come across a random character that may fill me in a quest that has a particular humour, charme and dialogue that's going to keep you busy for a decent amount of time. So, all I can really say without spoiling is that this game and all quests in it are memoreable all the way from the beginning to the ending. Although the game slighty gets weaker when it comes to the storyline near the ending of the game I must say.Now that I covered pretty much every topic I wanted to talk about, with all of that being said, this game is a must and you shouldn't miss out on playing it. It may be old and look crappy but don't judge this book by its cover, not this one. Don't ask yourself once, or twice, but play it immediately when you have the chance to. But please download the latest unofficial patch so that this experience is worthwhile and won't get interrupted by hasty bugs and annoying glitches.

number of helpful: 158 of 263 people (60%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
y 2, 2016
												There's only one reason to give this game a poor review:IT DOES NOT WORK WITHOUT ONE OF THE UNOFFICIAL PATCHES YOU WILL HAVE TO DOWNLOAD AND INSTALL.Now, this isn't a great hindrance, as you can find the guides to help you right here on Steam.  There are even guides that will aid you in getting the graphic-enhancing mods to work that come with one of the patches (I chose Wesp's Unoffical Patch since it seemed to contain more goodies).Yeah, yeah, I know the game's developer's are out of business.  I know it 'only takes five minutes to install the patch'.  Doesn't really matter.Someone is asking people to fork over $20 for a decade-old game (as of the time of this writing, you can get it for $5 though!), and someone is getting that money.  That 'someone' could at least update it with a patch of their own that is included in the purchase.  Whoever is getting paid for this game is relying on the cult status this game has achieved to put money in their pockets and giving their fans the middle finger as they do it.Which is a shame because, what I've played so far, it's a great game.  Not top-notch, but pretty good for its niche.Graphics:  They're a decade old and even with enhancements, it shows its age.  Animations are kind of stiff and clunky, and everything is sort of reminiscent of the way the original Blood Rayne looked.Voice-Acting:  Some of it is Grade A, some of it is Grade F.  Pretty hit or miss, as usual with most games, your protagonist stays silent.  Nothing wowing here, except for how terrible some of it is.Gameplay:  Pretty basic.  Forces you into third-person view whenever you do melee fights, which I find irritating.  I'd like it a lot more if I didn't have to see my own character's awkward flailing strikes.  There are some nice elements, such as your ability to be a silver-tongued rascal, or computer-hacking nerd, or lockpicking sneak really coming into play.  I also like how faithful they are to the source material, with Nosferatu having to stay hidden from humans, the rivalry war between Sabbat and Camarilla, etc.Story:  It's nothing to sneeze at, but it's not quite as great as some people claim.  Your dialogue choices are often clunky and ridiculous, but the whole thing weaves together fairly well.TL;DR:  Get it while it's on sale.  KNOW YOU WILL HAVE TO MANUALLY PATCH IT TO GET IT TO WORK.  DO NOT IGNORE ALL THE REVIEWS TELLING YOU THIS, THINKING IT WILL WORK ON YOUR RIG.If whoever is making money off of selling this game would patch it themselves, I would give it a positive recommendation.

ry 7
												Probably one of the finest RPG's out there. The characters are not only memorable, but just damn well done. I cannot remember any NPC's in Fallout 4. I played this game a year or two back, and vividly remember every chilling moment. The storyline is beyond excellent, with the pacing of the original Deus Ex. You have plots within conspiracies within plots. Bonus points for having each 'sub-race' of vampires having different experiences. (The insane one is especially fun. Same with the sewer noseferatu types.)Truly no other game out there does Vampires as well as this one. You really feel like you are just a person in this beautiful dark world....that being said... the UI takes more than a little getting used too. Also some areas are downright brutal for certain builds.This game and the original Deus Ex hold a special place in my heart......and I played them both for the first time within the last five years. That should say something. An ageless classic.

number of helpful: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 20, 2016
												A deep RPG whose strengths are able to overcome its various flaws.You start by picking one of seven vampire clans, which have their own advantages and disadvantages, slightly different starting stat upgrade choices, and 3 different special powers (some of which are unique to certain clans, others can be found among multiple clans).  Dialogue choices and NPC dialogue can change depending upon the clan you choose.  Especially interesting is the freakish looking Nosferatu clan who are suppose to stay in the shadows.  If you choose them, some NPCS will refuse to speak to you and may even freak out if you attempt to, others will comment on how hideous looking you are.  There're even unique events that happen if you choose the Nosferatu.  Sorry old woman working at the diner...As a vampire living in a normal society, you have to keep your existence hidden.  If you start sucking blood out on the main streets or use certain special powers, people will notice and you'll get 'masquerade' violations.  As you start getting more and more, vampire hunters will randomly show up to kill you.  If you get too many violations, you'll be executed by the vampire clans.  You earn experience by completing quests and use that experience to choose how to upgrade your character.  You can choose to spread experience around or focus in certain areas.  How you build your character will change how you'll be able to complete quests.  You can choose to focus on social skills, which will make it easier to talk, seduce, or intimidate your way into certain areas.  You could focus on stealth, lockpicking, and hacking to make your way around.  Or you could just beat the crap out of everyone in your way.The dialogue choices in the game are deep, and there're plenty of interesting & likeable characters throughout the game who will react to you based on how you talk to them.  If you insult some enough, they won't bother talking to you anymore or give you their sidequests.  The game also has several different endings, some of which will only be available if you've stayed friendly with certain major characters.The game has four major areas you can travel between and freely explore or ignore.  The game finds a sweet point on area size.  Areas are large enough that there're plenty of unique places that you'll want to explore.  However, areas are never so large that you feel like it'll take forever to find/complete all the quests and they can all be completely traversed within a minute or two.On the downside, the game has several bugs even with the "Unofficial Patch" installed.  I didn't run into anything game breaking, but there was a time or two where I had to change up my choices so the game wouldn't get stuck.  Stealth isn't the game's strongsuit.  Sometimes enemies won't notice you even if you're right in front of them.  Sometimes if they see you or hear you, they'll get stuck in search mode and just stand staring at a spot you need to walk through to get by.  Sometimes you can get them out of being stuck, other times you can't.  For the most part, combat is alright, but don't expect to be blown away.I went into the game worried that it might be overhyped and not that good.  Was very pleasantly surprised by how much I ended up enjoying it.  If you like deep RPGs, you'll like this game.

content:
22, 2016
												Nominated this game for "Test of Time" award! Do you want to know what is the greatest hidden gem that was harshly buried due to its rushed release, lack of sales, and bugs in the history of gaming? Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is it. I had this game standing alone in the backlog two years ago. I kept having strange sudden urges saying I need to play this game over and over again. I decided why the heck not. The game kept crashing and crashing. I found out it required community patches. Already had 300 of them... Wow, the community must be sooo dedicated. I wonder why? Hmm... Now it finally ran smooth at the start. Boom, my life changed when I put my foot in the city of Santa Monica and met a memorable character named Smiling Jack. The atmosphere and the characters in the game were something I have never seen or experienced before in any games that blown me away. They were soooo freaking immersing that kept me hooked playing this game nonstop for two weeks. The story became remarkably darker, mind blowing, and emotional all at the same time. It was sooo well written and properly executed that I couldn't believe how good the whole thing is. The characters. The atmosphere and places to explore. The gameplay and RPG elements chosen for this game. The plot. EVERYTHING. So good. I do not want to spoil ANYTHING because you need to play this first.The experience inspired me to complete few playthroughs with different clan and mods. The community and cult following are so dedicated that it's amazing. This game is a textbook example of a cult classic. Excellent cult classic. I am proud to claim this game as my third favorite game of all time. 9.7 out of 10

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Reading through the negative reviews here, most of them have the same complaint: they can’t get the game running. It’s true the game won’t run on a modern OS without the unofficial patch, which is shameful on Activision’s part, especially since the creator of the patch offered it to them for free.But despite the annoyance of getting the game running, it has a 94% approval rating here on Steam. Indeed it seems nearly everyone that actually managed to play the game liked it. That speak volumes of the game.Apart from getting the game running is it flawless? Not entirely, the gameplay leaves a lot to be desired. While the combat isn’t quite as clunky as the first Deus Ex, enemies with fully automatic weapons will kill you in about two seconds, though these enemies mostly appear towards the end of the game and thankfully stealth is preposterously easy.So why play this game? Simple: Atmosphere and Characters. This game has such wonderful way of making you feel like a creature of the night. The graphics are obviously dated, but there are nice touches such as animated facial expressions. The original soundtrack is great. The licensed music ranges from pretty good to really awful.What really keeps me coming back to this game is the characters. Though most of them are clinically dead they are more alive the character in any other game I’ve played. The dialogue is brilliantly written and voice acted. It’s just a delight to talk to people in this game. The Vampire Politics at the heart of the game are also really fascinating and how you treat the different factions affects which endings are available to you.Despite the problems with getting it running and the rather poor gameplay this is a must play if you like good writing in games. If, however, you only care about gameplay this game is not for you.

												This game has got a lot of flaws, but I forgive almost every single one of them because I am so enamored with its world, and its writing. Seriously, it takes a lot to get me to give a ♥♥♥♥ about ♥♥♥♥ing Vampires. Set in the World of Darkness RPG universe, this game had writing and design that was just too ambitious. The developers clearly had a magnificent vision for this game -- a game where the experience is vastly different depending on which clan you picked. A game where playing it through once only shows you a fraction of what it has to offer. A world filled with choices, and so, so many ways to solve your problems. If this game had been allowed to finish, it could have been right up there alongside revered greats such as Deus Ex and Planescape: Torment. Unfortunately, its flaws, and the fact that the game is literally not finished, rob it of such a reward. It's almost tragic, really.If you're gonna buy this game, be prepared to do some homework just to get the damn thing to run. The unofficial patch is basically mandatory. But this game is well worth the effort. If you're a fan of dynamic RPGs with loads of replay value, give this a shot. I put off trying it out for a long time and honestly wish I had played it sooner.

												I love this game. Absolutely adore this game. For an older game released in the early 2000's, I expected less. I expected something easy and fun and fluffy. Instead I found myself so enthralled by the story and the plot and the style that I replayed the game over and over again going through as much as I possibly could and making as many changes as I could just so the game would not end. This is a fantastic vampire game. We need more games like this nowadays. It reminded me of the style of American McGee's Alice and reminded me of the world of Rice's vampires, such as Lestat and Louis. It took me a little bit to figure out how to run the old game on a newer computer, but I will never, ever regret making this purchase and I envy all who have yet to discover its brilliance, because I just want to go through and re-descover everything all over again. The graphics were good for the time, a little shaky now, but it hardly takes away from gameplay. I fell in love with so many characters I was ashamed with myself. 10/10 all the way.

												One of my all time favourite RPGs. As apposed to most role–playing games, Bloodlines offers a more diverse approach to the platform, creating near unique scenarios for each different Clan, outfitted with bespoke abilities and skills. One of the more enjoyable qualities of Bloodlines is that – and unlike most other games of the same genre – content transcends the battle front, development and progression is key to successs. Having said that, combat is equally as awesome as storyline content, and one of the funnest aspect of the game for me so far has been trying out different Clans, and seeing how they work differently with dialogue and the eventual endgame, there's to say it's a very redoable game as long as you broaden your horizons for each new character and select a different Clan for your playthrough.100% recommendable for RPG fans.
