content:
26, 2016
												Okay, so I started playing this game about two years ago and only made it to the second location because the game is buggy as Hell and wasn't loading something that was an intergral part of one of my missions (so, I quit instead of starting over).I recently replayed the game, all the way through, this time, and let me tell you: this game is fantastic. I's an old game, sure, but it definitely holds up well. And in some ways, is vastly superior to some modern games. The graphics are a bit dated, but not horribly so. Again, I've played some modern games with worse. Voice acting is top-notch. The story and lore that surrounds the game is amazing and deep. You could spend hours just talking to NPCs because the lore is that involved and you may want to absorb it all. I hesitate to say characters are believable (I'm looking at you, Knox), but they're charming. Some are likeable, whereas others are easy to hate. Either way, they're all written well for the world they are in and really help to develop it. I found the Anarchs to be a much more relatable, realistic group than some of the others. That said, the members of the Anarchs are my favorite chraracters, so I could be biased. Combat (especially melee) can be a bit clunky, but not impossible to handle. And, due to the various clans, it makes it very easy to find a playstyle that works best with what you like. This game transitions from a stealth/puzzle game, to a 3rd person hack and slash, to a 1st person shooter seamlessly, and allows the player to change up their playstyle on the fly.  Each clan has a very unique, rich story that surrounds them, which makes it fun to play multiple times in order to get a feel for all seven of them.Some the levels are unsettling, or downright scary to go through. They're very atmospheric, with great audio and visuals. I would be lying if I said that there weren't some missions where I had to take my headphones off, or had to play during daylight hours while other people were around. There's one in particular where you don't even face any enemies, but the hair on the back of my neck still stands up every time I go through it. My one main complaint is that VTMB is a game that hinges on the fact that your character might be a sexual creature, making it possible to sort of romance some of the characters. However, there is only one male NPC throughout the game who can be 'romanced', yet several females. I get that at the time, game companies thought  that female gamers were a rarety, so I don't really fault it too much.

content:
5, 2014
												Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is a simply sublime title by Troika. It was the third and final title they ever made before kicking the bucket.You play as a newly formed vampire in a "World of Darkness". You choose between several clans, from the rebellious Brujah to the insane Malkavians. Each clan has their own stat differences and NPCs react to you very differently. Especially if the player plays as a Nosferatu, you are treated like a hideous monster and cannot stay around human NPCs without them running away from you. The gameplay is solid and acts as both a first person shooter and a hack and slash.Most notable is the atmosphere of VtmB. It features very well made map design that is riddled with side quests in it's city hubs. Believe me when I say this game takes a while to complete, and is very rewarding once you do it. It is also replayable due to how much of the game changes depending on what clan you play as.It runs on a beta version of the Source engine. The version it runs on is actually more primitive than Half Life 2. As a result the game is fairly buggy due to it's rushed development. However like all of Troika's games there is a large fan community that has released an unofficial patch that fixes most of the issues.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2015
												In a way this game (when you manage to run it with the unofficial patch) reminds me about Bathesda's Elder Scrolls series. It has small, more compact world because of the source engine I presume, but lots of content. I am mentioning Elder Scrolls for the solo purpose of saying that just like TES, VTM:B must be loved with all its flaws, bugs, errors and imperfections.I honestly believe that Troika Games just had horrible luck as if universe screwed them up while they were creating the game.Starting with engine itself, Troika used an unfinished Source Engine and had to work with it, adding their own code. Troika worked on the same engine that Half-Life 2 were even before the engine was shown publicly. In fact they had an agreement that they can't sell the game before the Half-Life 2 release.After the engine came Activision. Even though Troika employers kept on working overtime on the game, Activision still rushed the release and cut off sponsorship of the game. So in the end we got ourselves a rushed, unpolished product that in fact was fixed and updated by fans for more than 11 years now.And you might think thats it? Troika Games sold too little copies of the game to keep up afloat and ended up being closed. How did that happen if the game is so good as I keep on saying?Bad luck.Release date of the game is November 2004. What else happened in 2004 prior the November?Unreal Tournament 2004, Far Cry, Sacred, Painkiller, Hitman: Contracts, Manhunt, Thief: Deadly Shadows,  Doom 3, Silent Hill 4: The Room, Sims 2, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War, Star Wars: Battlefront, Myst IV: Revelation, Rome: Total War and many other awesome games. Year 2004 was an amazing year in the industry.And you may think that with all that competition on the market VTM:B were safe since they released in November, while other games were earlier? Well, still bad luck Troika Games.What happened in November in the PC game industry? (I am not mentioning games such as MGS3 and other console games since I am talking about PC)CS:Source, Half Life 2, NFS: Underground 2, World Of Warcraft, Prince Of Persia: Warrior Within and so on. With all respect to Troika Games, they had no chance of wining a competition.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is probably one of my favorite games of all time. With all it's imperfections and glitches it delivers an amazing lore, story, humor and experience. Gameplay itself (fighting) is done horribly and sloppy though so don't expect to be blown away with it, dialoges is what makes it so special. Depending on the vampire clan you chose it can take you 3 or more walkthroughs to experience all the game aspects such as different approaches (stealth, fighting with magic or brute force, persuation/intimidation/seduction) and even a special, Malkavian clan walkthorugh. You see, Malkavians are insane vampires. And by insane I mean totally sick. When you play as a Malkavian character literally every dialogue line for you is changed in a mad/insane way. In fact you can have a dialog with a news reporter on your TV if you are playing as a Malkavian.All and all, when playing this game keep in mind that it was released in 2004 and it has lots of flaws that modern games don't, but thats simply because people are always becoming better at what they do and creating videogames is not an exception.

content:
y 12
												I have waited a decade and change to play this game. I still have an ancient Bradygames walkthrough guide along with written notes in it to deal with each clan character. But in the end, perhaps it was a blessing in disguise to wait this long, where I can now play the game with all the bugs fixed. Due to that, I can say, without a doubt, that Bloodlines is one of the most underrated, underappreciated RPGs you have never heard of.Your beginning is straightforward enough. In Los Angeles, you are changed into a vampire against your will, which ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the local vampiric powers-that-be enough to kill them outright. You, on the other hand, are spared with the understanding that you will contribute to Kindred (as these vampires call themselves) society or else. From there, it becomes a tangled web of politics, competing agendas and choices that are eventually going to ♥♥♥♥ SOMEBODY off enough to take a shot at you.Prior to this intro, you get to create your character from scratch with the aid of a simplified but true-to-the-source White Wolf character sheet. Picking one of seven clans will likely have the biggest effect on your gameplay, as each has their own unique strengths and weaknesses. After that, though, anything goes. Just be careful to note violate the Masquerade (an honor system where you do nothing too stupid too often to tip off the mortal herd that vampires are real) and you can be whatever kind of character you want: brawler, socialite, hacker, thief, assassin, gunfighter. Just always account for the fact that sooner or later, you're going to have to fight and you'll find unique playthroughs each time you pick a different clan.One other important note: getting the latest fan-made patch for this game (9.7 at the time of this writing) is an absolute MUST or you're going to have the dubious joys of running into all those bugs the original game came with. But with that accomplished, have fun!

Yet I find myself playing it again every year trying to capture the essence of what i felt the first time playing it. The games atmosphere and setting is deeply immersive, and the voiceacting is fantastic. The NPCs are fleshed out, which makes the gameworld come alive in a way that no other RPG has managed after it in my opinion.I can't recommend this game enough, dispite the games age, it still will give you an RPG experience that you will not find anywhere else.P.S: Play it with the newest fanpatch for the most optimal experience.

content:
10, 2016
												Hands down, the best game I've ever played. It's dark and gritty without taking itself too seriously, filled with atmopshere and world-detail without playing like a fantasy encyclopedia. and you can roll around town dressed up as a pimp or a stripper. What more could you want from a game?The best testimony of how fantastic this game is is undoubtedly the fans; Even though this game came out in 2004, there are still unofficial patches being developed and released as you read this. Never has a game been more loved, cherished, or enriched by its community. We're just lucky to be able to play it now, when all the bugs have been fixed by dedicated fans, compared to its initial release.The game play is fairly simple and easy to access, though the variety of levels mean it never gets dull. You can shoot, tear, or bite your way through your enemies, and look like something straight out of a bondage fever dream/nightmare whilst doing it. The plot is genuinely gripping, with twists and turns I never saw coming, and the ending? The ending is just... f*** me. Well played, Bloodlines. Well played.Storyline? Basically, you wake up a fledgling after a passionate night with your fanged lover, only to end up becoming a glorified slave of a grumpy french nobleman with a Napoleon complex and a damn nice suit. Be his ♥♥♥♥♥ for what feels like eternity. Blow ♥♥♥♥ up. The ranges of choices you're given are actually pretty impressive, and DO make a difference, unlike some franchises I can think of (*cough*Mass Effect*cough). Be sassy. Be crazy. Be sexy as hell. It's one of those games where you can truly be whoever you want. Aside from appropriately dressed. No mod will ever give you that.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
12
												Bloodlines is a great rpg, it has a very awkward tutorial that does a poor job of introducing the game to you and it can be quite a turn off for newcomers but the tutorial does not represent the game well at all. Once you are left to explore the first area of the game after the tutorial you start to see the strengths of the game and you start to understand why this game has such a cult following. It has an interesting story and world, interesting lore and interesting characters with also very surprisingly great voice acting. I absolutely loved exploring the open world hub areas without the burden of objective markers, soaking in the world and atmosphere from just talking to npcs and discovering side missions which by the way are very well done and tell great stories on their own and end up being very memorable. The ideologies of the different vampire factions I found very intriguing in particular. The main missions offer up nice variety with the visuals and locations you are visiting and you can tell the developers tried to make an effort to make each mission feel different from each other so the game doesn’t get repetitive. However you can tell the developers ran out of either time or money because the level design in the later stages become really generic and repetitive especially compared to the early missions like the amazing ocean house hotel. The rpg mechanics are implemented to the game very well, I appreciated the amount of options in the character creation and the leveling up system. I really liked the morality system with the humanity and being faithful to the masquerade, it’s well integrated with the main and side missions in particular. I appreciated all the different ways you can tackle an objective even though I always ended up just going in guns blazing. Speaking of the combat I enjoyed it overall I don’t think it’s horrible like some people claim, it does it’s job perfectly fine in my opinion and it can be pretty fun at times. The end game can be very brutal if you haven’t leveled up your character in a few certain ways which does restrict the freedom you have with your character. I recommend installing the fan made unofficial patch of the game because without it it’s almost unplayable with all the bugs, crashes and lack of high resolution options.8/10 (Great)

content:
ry 28, 2016
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is considered one of the classic PC RPGs. I've seen nothing but positive things about it, but to be honest, the cover art and the concept kind of warded me off of it. After all, vampires suck now. Now, after 30 hours and having beaten the game, I can safely say it's one of the best games I've ever played.It has a unique atmosphere, gothic without feeling forced, gritty and stylish. It takes what the modern take on the modern vampire is and makes it well... good. Great. Apparently, this is the norm for VTM (which I haven't played at Tabletop before). I would say its the best depiction of a modern vampire out there. It's not all rosy, of course. This game doesn't pull any punches if you're not being careful and keeping aware. I couldn't even get the game to run on Steam. However, VTM-B has a very active, very devoted fanbase that creates custom content and mods so I was able to get a 'true to game' patch that simply made the game run in no time at all. I only beat the game a few hours ago, but I am already thinking of second play throughs, with new mods and new choices. This game gives the player a ton of opportunities to alter the story, too. I felt like, at most every juncture, that my decisions mattered. That I wasn't just plodding through the developer's story but that I was writing a story of my own.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines manages to hold together a beautifully crafted environment, with some satisfying combat and evocative NPC interaction and story telling. It borders on perfection and a standard that other RPGs should be held to. Pros:+Amazing Atmosphere+Cool and gothic without feeling forced+Likeable/multidimensional NPCs+Lots of choices and approaches to both build and story progression+Satisfying, high-impact combat (at least in melee)+Active fanbase producing extra content+Very addictive once things get goingCons:-The first half hour or so of the game are slow and fail to grab attention-The unmodded/unpatched game was not playable for me (but this is not such a big issue)-Character building and numbers can be unintuitiveOverall, I would say it's completely worth the purchase, even at non-sale price.

content:
2, 2016
Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines is an action role-playing game, developed by Troika Games and released in 2004. Overshadowed by other landmark releases such as Half-Life 2 and crippled by a rushed development, this criminally underrated Source game is a faithful interpretation of the popular table top classic and an enjoyable - albeit pulpy - romp through the World of Darkness.Presented in both third- and first-person perspective, the gothic reimagining of Los Angeles features a tumultuous social and political landscape between the various factions of vampires vying for control. You assume the role of the unnamed protagonist thrown into this violent underbelly and join the clan of your choice before being literally let loose in to the new (and often strange) world. But what happens next is up to you.The game world is the centrepiece of Bloodlines as it constantly invites the player to really explore the depths of what it has to offer. With the incredible variety of methods and playstyles available within this sandbox-like environment, replay value is immense, as is the sheer enjoyment of exploration. There are plenty of unique abilities to use (and abuse) on the unsuspecting citizen, ranging from the seductive bloodsucking of the Toreador to the animalistic brute strength of the Nosferatu or Gangrels. Each clan has its own particular style and the variety of outfits available to the player reflects this. Despite associating yourself with a particular clan at the beginning of the game, there isn’t content that is locked off to the player due to the constant political in-fighting of the Camarilla that forms the basis of the game’s narrative. Revealing your presence to the human population results in Masquerade point deductions, which can result in failing the game entirely and your activities depend on keeping up this secrecy. Outside of that however, your journey actively encourages as much havoc as possible and those interested in the supernatural will not be disappointed.Pros Great depth to RPG elements and remains true to pen-and-paper origins.  Fascinating and diverse list of characters, backed up by fantastic voice acting. Plenty of gameplay freedom and emphasis on player choice. A tonne of interesting missions and side quests, if a bit repetitive.   Excellent atmosphere, with equally remarkable writing and dialogue options throughout. Phenomenal restoration effort (and ongoing support) by the community. Cons Technical issues abound. Requires a fan-made patch to properly play and actually finish. Frequently poor visuals; a mixed bag generally.   Though varied, combat tends to be clunky and dissatisfying at times. Stealth A.I. is poor. Some abilities/attributes are useless or progressively made redundant. Final Thoughts: Technical issues aside, VtMB is the vampire-themed game that you've been dying to play. A great example of the capabilities of the Source engine in it's prime, embrace this flawed gem with lowered expectations or during a sale and prepare for a bloody good time.Rating: 6.5/10

												This game is amazing. It's just so rich - all of the characters and places are incredibly detailed, memorable, and unique. It's also got this filthy, depraved, gritty atmosphere that's always there, even when you're in a fancy hotel or something. Another awesome thing about this game is how many options it gives you, and how what you say and do actually matters. The npcs really recognize the things that you say to them, your clan, your gender, your attitude, etc. For example, if you're playing as a narcisstic, smooth-talking Toreador and you get into a conversation with a vanity-hating Nosferatu, don't expect the conversation to go easily - they'll probably talk about their desire to burn your pretty little face in acid. To boot, the facial expressions and voice acting is amazing, and probably the best I've ever seen in a game.This game is, however, quite glitchy due to its troubled release. For that reason, the unofficial patch is a necessity. Seriously, don't even start playing the game until you've got it installed.All in all, though, this is definitely one of my favorite games of all time. If you're thinking about getting it, do it. You won't regret it!

content:
er 24, 2016
												*** Senneca's nomination: "Test Of Time Award" 2016 ***I first played this game in 2004, at a friend's house, and I still enjoy it just as much today.It is easily one of the greatest RPGs of the era, arguably one of the best of all time. I honestly don't think a better vampire themed game has ever been made. However, all that being said, it is not a perfect geme. There are plenty of bugs to contend with, the combat system was bad, even when the game was new, and the graphics definitley show the game's age. Despite the shortcomings, it's well worth the $19.99 Steam is currently charging for it.The game is set in (what was then) contemporary LA. You'll find yourself unwittingly thrust into the vampire subculture that exists "hiding in plain sight" among the mortal world. Like the human world, vampire society consits of various factions with their own ideas and values, governed by a set of mutually agreed upon rules. You'll need to learn these rules, and how these factions relate to each other quickly if you want to survive.The setting, and the characters are one of the strengths of the game. Learning to be a vampire, how to feed without being seen, and use your new powers feels natural. Your abilities, and even the dialogue options available to you, will be determined by which clan you choose to be "embraced into". Each clan has various strengths and weaknesses, and tend to be aligned with (but not limited to) certain political factions. There are tons of memorable characters you'll meet along the way, and the multiple diologue options, character customization, and high quality voice acting both ensure you'll be back for multiple playthroughs.The gameplay is standard for the RPG genre, with the inevitable bugs that come with them (especially older titles like this game). There are various semi-open world parts of LA that you will be able to explore as you progress through the game. The combat is one of the glaring weaknesses of the game, and the system takes getting used to. Still, you'll eventually figure out the system, and the AI, and as your character gets stronger, you can invest skill points into your chosen combat style (firearms, melee, etc.) to become more effective.All in all this game is a must play for any fan of RPG games, or the vampire genre. I have hundreds of hours sunk into it over the past decade (most of them on my pre-Steam CD copy), and I'm sure you'll get a fair amout out of it too. The only sad part is that we never got a sequel to this amazing game!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2014
												A third-person action/RPG that is true to the old whitewolf roleplay system. Pros:- The game is true to the old pen and paper whitewolf system, you'll feel like you're really playing Vampire: The Masquerade- Fun character generation with all the classic vampire clans complete with most of the old powers- Immersive environments that make you feel like you're really in a vampire run city- Intrigue and political tactics true to the setting complete with clan biases and alliances- Interesting items and weapons that seem appropriate for the setting- Different playstyles depending heavily on clan and powers- Interesting quests that add a lot of color to the world- A real feeling of power at higher level, but also danger as the game never becomes easyCons:- Buggy, lots of crashes and locks can make things annoying at times- Lots of prep work needed to get the game running, you usually have to use one of the fan-created patches to get this to work on steam- Some knowledge needed, building a character poorly can make the game very hard to progress inOverall:  This game is a great experience, even with the work needed to get it running (which is usually an instant fail for me), I have to recommend this game.  It's worth the investment to be able to immerse yourself in a game and a world that pays so much respect to the original Whitewolf source material.  And even if you've never played Vampire before, you can enjoy it for the interesting story and unique world.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
r 23, 2014
												Use the unofficial patch or this game will be too broken to even touch.Now:Probably the best overall writing ever seen in a video game. Deus Ex, Thief, Morrowind, System Shock and Pathologic were all excellent in their own respects --- but this game beats them all in terms of consistency and believability. Characters actually have personality, conversations actually flow, and every single NPC that can be interacted with has a ton of depth and maybe even a few ulterior motives. This game is easily tied with Deus Ex as the closest we've ever gotten to Warren Spector's "one city block" vision. It simply has to be experienced to be believed.Unfortunately, the game is even more broken than Deus Ex. While Deus Ex was marred by half-baked and unsatisfying systems that would make for a terrible games on their own, this game is marred by a ton of systems that are either there for no reason whatsoever or just outright don't work. The Seduction skill makes Deus Ex's Swimming look useful, and there is absolutely no reason to use firearms at any point in the game. Not even the tutorial for firearms requires that you use them --- they are that useless. For the first two areas, the game is a brilliant collage of choices and possibilities, surpassing even, yes, Deus Ex, but that vision becomes more and more distant as the game goes on, to the point where the latter half of the game is a concoction of horribly rushed and bland dungeon crawls and some of the worst boss fights even seen in games and the final area is almost entirely devoid of any complex architecture, sidequests or secrets. The story comes to a similarly rushed, mean-spirited and silly conclusion. If there was ever a game that deserved this kind of fate, this one wasn't it.Overall, this game is Deus Ex taken to the extreme in every aspect --- while the world of Deus Ex occasionally felt real and personal, Bloodlines' world bursts at the seems with life, and for a precious moment, one could be forgiven for seeing the World of Darkness as truly alive and endless. While Deus Ex was somewhat weak in its mechanics and failed to retain its momentum into the latter stages of the game, Bloodlines barely functions at all beyond its first few stages and completely falls apart in the latter half. This game is utterly brilliant for its first half, but the second half will make any player mourn for what it could have been. Considering the fact that Troika closed its doors after Bloodlines' release and nobody has so much as attempted something approaching the first half of the game ever since, it's unlikely that we'll see a happy ending for this kind of game, so we have no choice but to enjoy this precious specimen.

content:
5, 2016
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is an underrated gem and probably the best vampire game ever made. If you're a fan of deep RPG's and have never played this game you're missing out. The world, the unforgettable characters and the incredible in-depth lore taken from the original tabletop game is amazing and deserves to be praised.Although the game looks dated from a graphical standpoint and it's far from bug free, thanks to the fan created Unofficial Patch the game is playable on most modern systems, fixes most of the instability issues and quest bugs and even restores some lost and/or unfinished content. The combat is still clunky though and the stealth AI remains poor but this is luckily easy overshadowed by the fantastic story and atmosphere in this game.Apart from that, the well written dialogue, the great voice acting, the stylish music, the variety in quests that you can undertake and the complete freedom to approach each situation in a number of different ways all make this game standout to this day. You are free to explore and there are countless side quests to stumble upon, each with their own unique story, there is certainly no copy and paste content here.Technical issues aside this is still one hell of a game. If you haven't already, pick this game up and give it a try, it deserves to be played.

2, 2015
												First things first.  To deal with the game's issue with not being able to load properly, disable Steam updates and load the latest non-official patch.  After that, you're golden.  As far as good RPGs are concerned, I find myself returning to this game a lot.  I don't think I've ever had an RPG draw me into its world and characters as much as this one has, and the more I play it, the more I enjoy it.  It has its rough edges, mostly moments where combat is inevitable and odds feel stacked a bit unfairly against you.  Still, I love the ever living heck out of the interactions you have with characters, the dialogue, and the choices you can make thoughout the game.  Don't like the cop stopping you?  Mind control him, persuade him, seduce him.  There are plenty of choices and it's beautiful.  The game plays just long enough not to overstay its welcome.  Take the plunge and enter the World of Darkness.

y 1, 2014
												There is a reason this game still comes in on my Top 10 Favorite Games. At time of writing I have logged over 60 hours into this game. I love the setting, the gameplay, and the experiance that it presents to you.        The creatures and clans remain faithful to their source material which makes for a great mix of horror and RPG. Some of the creepier places really get under your skin. When this game came out, it had top of the line graphics, but has aged a bit. That doesn’t distract from the incredible art direction and level design.         With each clan bringing a unique playstyle, and 5 endings, this game has a lot of replayability. I especially enjoyed the madness inducing Malkavians. The game will often give you a goal and have several ways to accomplishing it. 10 years after the fact, I still love and play this game. Make sure you get the unofficial patch though. It fixes a lot of bugs and adds a lot of extra content (mainly stuff the designers hadn’t finished yet).Overall, if your looking for a great game with horror/RPG elements, give this game a try. It will suck you into its world!Highly Recommended5/5

content:
y 6, 2016
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, is Role Playing game released in 2004. You can play in both First or Third-person Mode, as one of several vampire clans each with their own abilities and gameplay style: Playing as Nosferatu, are especially challenging. You start the game as a fledgling vampire who has to find your way through the streets of Los Angeles. Along the way you learn about the Various Vampire clans, as well as investigate a recently discovered relic that is supposed to bring an end to all vampires. The story takes you through Santa Monica, Downtown Los Angeles, Hollywood, Chinatown, as well as the Underground. I don't want to go into the story to much, due to spoilers, but I will say the game has varying levels of difficult depending on what clan you choose to play as. You have the ability to create ghouls, which are humans who are fed Vampire blood, giving them powers, and binding the ghoul to you. I personally like the voice acting in this game and found some of the characters to be memorable such as; Jeanette. Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is a fun RPG, worth your time if you are into Occult-themed games.

content:
er 6, 2015
												What to say about this game, man. First don't let the 1.1 hours mislead you, I've put around ten hours so far into this game. The Unofficial patch functions outside of steam so the counters not gonna work. I reccomend the patch by the way it has a list of improvements that make the game more enjoyable.The Pro's:-Lore. There's a lot of it and it is fairly easy to understand most of it.-Graphics. Top notch for it's time, early 2000's, it has aged pretty well to my eyes.-Audio/Voice Acting. The background music is pretty atmospheric and in tense situtions got my heart quickening a bit. The VO is well acted and cast, Each important and even supporting characters feel very distinct.-Gameplay. It's an rpg so you'll have to manage stats and what not but I found keeping track of your "Humanity" interesting as well as "The Masquerade". Falling to zero in either of those is game over. Also don't die, that's a game over too...-You Are a Vampire Baby! Bloody act like it!!!!!The Cons:-Some small bugs are still present even with the patch but that's to be expected. Nothing is perfect.-Character creation is really limited. You have about a dozen sub species of vampire to choose from but you CAN'T go in and edit facial appearances or anything. Options are limited to race, gender, backstory and predetermined body build. Each has it's own strengths and weakness. My character is a Brujah, strong willed idealist types but low self control when "The Thirst" rears its ugly head. (I use The phrase "The Thirst" because the Blade movies had the better term.)-Quest details often give you very little clues as to where to find goals. You'll end up wandering about before figuring out that you need to be in a area that hasn't been unlocked to you yet.-Managing your skills seems a bit daunting at the very begining but it gets smoother as you go on.-Quick travel between areas but not to specific locations i.e. clubs, motels and such. So be prepared to walk, a lot...This game is savage (in a good way) and is well worth playing atleast twice I feel. I give it 9 out of 10 bites to the neck. Would bite again and again. Hehehe the Thirst always wins...

content:
5, 2014
												This is a no-brainer purchase/must-play for anyone who is familiar with White Wolf's World of Darkness franchise, anyone who has played the first of the legacy Vampire the Masquerade games, anyone who plays LARP or tabletop versions of VtM, or really anyone who is even vaguely interested in an introduction to the rich lore offered by an immersive and addictive tabletop game series. Unlike with Vampire the Masquerade: Redemption, where you are forced to play out the storyline set before you from the perspective of a "true" Brujah, this game gives you the choice of what clan you are to be embraced under, and it gives you a taste of the what the game world is really about, allowing your choices to affect the events that play out around you. Ofcourse, there are still linear aspects of the game, and a few glitches here and there, but thankfully there is an entire decade of reliable user-made updates that improve upon those, along with increases in graphics and presentation. All around, this is an excellent game that I would recommend to so many of my friends that are interested in dark fantasy role playing games.

Let us get into this,What I liked?-Very stat heavy which makes for some interesting skillchecks-Multiple ways to create a character-Multiple ways to complete a mission-Brilliant Dialogue(If you want movie type of dialogue this is the game if you want book type of dialogue look for Planetscape : Torment)-Voice acting is spot on, probably one of the best voice acting ever recorded in an rpg.-Combat abilities are just marvelous-Clan specific abilities give your character a different feel.-Lots of Side Missions-Interesting story component-Multiple Endings-Mixture of Minor and Major Decisions to be made(Not all rpgs should be based on making decisions of finding a cure for cancer or ending world hunger)What I didn't like?-BUGS. With the amount of bugs that this game has, you would think it was made by an obsidian programmer working through a hangover. The amount of bugs in this game are probably being cast for ANTZ 2(3?). When I think about the bugs i run away in peril because I think they are all over me. (They are amazing patches to fix this though)-The last quarter of the game was more copy paste than that friend of yours that leaves assignments till sunday. Seriously troika fix your ♥♥♥♥.Other than that it is probably my most favorite game out there. I would go ahead and give it what it is due. VTMB with patches and everything is a complete 9.7/10. I absolutely wasted and had so much fun in this game. I would recommend it for anyone that wants to have fun. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 7
												i played this game before it was on steam. beat it once and did several playthroughs that i didnt finish. (or did i ?)so nevermind my 5.3 hours on record.this rpg is very similiar to the deus ex games. a lot of your time will be spend in open "hub"? areas where there is a lot to explore and find.a lot of places you didnt expect to be there and some disturbing secrets.combat wise you can shoot, sneak, bash and use bloodmagic and the like. all is mostly stat based.there are no levels in the game you just get exp that you can spend on anything you like whenever you like. (except for some clan exclusive abilities)this game is highly NONlinear. there are not only multiple endings but branching storylines and various ways to complete a quest.want to talk your way through the entire game? well you can. but make sure your vampire clan isnt nosferatu or you will be so hideously deformed that most people will run away from you and call the cops. sometimes you might convince someone you had a horrible accident but you should really stick to the shadows and mostly the sewers where you feed on rats.want to be part of the insane malkavian clan so you cant speak one coherent sentence and creep everybody out and convince human beings that they are in fact turtles? you can too but prepare for things to unfold very differently. or do you want to be part of the snobbish ruler clan where the lower classes will treat you with disdain or a pretty boy (or gal) who charmes and seduces his way through the game (to the disdain of certain nosferatus).you can choose to hack computers and talk and find clues to complete quest. or bully, brawl and shoot your way through the questlines. you can be compassionate, insane or cruel all these things shape the story you will experience. not only can you decide the way you approach the game mechanically but you also have a say in how the story unfolds. for better or worse.there is a lot of atmosphere and humour to the game so there are definitely light hearted moments. but for the most part its all about lowlife, decadence, depravity, perversion and supernatural and sometimes even lovecraftian horror.bloodlines is using the source engine (the half life 2 one). im not sure but i think it came out before half life 2 and it certainly shows. but the facial animations in the dialouge are on point. ranging from bored teenage store clerk, doped up pawn shop owner or insane cultist. oh and the mutliple choice dialogue is decently expansive. with great writing.troika went broke while completing the game so it was released in a very buggy state. nonetheless this game was (and still is) considered by many rpg fans as one of the best. i concur. if you like deus ex or just rpgs in general you will find a lot to like. its quite unique and unmatched in many ways. certainly the best vampire game on the market.even 13 years (wow really? time flies!) after release the community is still active in modding and patching the game. you should definitely (yes there is no argument to be had) get the latest unofficial community patch by wesp (i think) from patchesscrolls. the last one is from a few days ago. shows you the dedication of certain fans. a lot of bugfixes and an optional plus patch that restores content cut from the game due to development limitations and such.the voice acting ranges from superp and excellent to "sufficient". but the enviromental sounds are quite fitting and the soundtrack gives you a great neonoir (thats a thing right?) feeling.theres a lot more to mention and im sure other steam reviews will help you out or some big game reviewers go into more detail. all in all its a fantastic game and there is no reason not to try it.(btw if you live in germany dont be put off by the "low violence" disclaimer)this "low violence" version used to be sold as the german uncut version in stores and it basically is.the only confirmed cut is a nanosecond of the intro sequence and if you install the unoffical patch "plus" the restoration stuff you dont have to "worry" about that either.pro +great writing. (story and dialogue)interesting characters.decent facial animations.classless system.great atmosphere. (with some ♥♥♥♥ your pants moments.)highly non linear.lots of replayability. decent hacking mechanic and a cool computer interface where you actually have to type.lots of weapons, magic. stats and talents. (you can make people go insane or puke blood and stuff goood times)different vampire clans that are really different! people will react to you differently. greatly.cool soundtrack and enviromental sounds.voice acting is really good when its good.community patches and mods.gory fun.lovecraftian reverences..twistscon -dated graphics.will be buggy without patches.can be frustrating due to its sometimes harsh difficulty.you can potentially screw up your character build.voice acting is not so good sometimes. (unless its great)overall a great game. just dont expect a first person shooter. it isnt one. its more like the fallout or deus ex games in that respect.i say buy the game and spread the word about how awesome it is.lets hope troika or some developers of it make a comeback.and uh.... "dont open it".

												This game is so good that you even forget that this is an old game (with its related limitations). It perfectly represents the punk gothic scenario designed for the Storyteller’s RPG, putting all the environmental, climate, and situations exactly as it should be in such world - a must for those who used to play the RPG. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 7
												i played this game before it was on steam. beat it once and did several playthroughs that i didnt finish. (or did i ?)so nevermind my 5.3 hours on record.this rpg is very similiar to the deus ex games. a lot of your time will be spend in open "hub"? areas where there is a lot to explore and find.a lot of places you didnt expect to be there and some disturbing secrets.combat wise you can shoot, sneak, bash and use bloodmagic and the like. all is mostly stat based.there are no levels in the game you just get exp that you can spend on anything you like whenever you like. (except for some clan exclusive abilities)this game is highly NONlinear. there are not only multiple endings but branching storylines and various ways to complete a quest.want to talk your way through the entire game? well you can. but make sure your vampire clan isnt nosferatu or you will be so hideously deformed that most people will run away from you and call the cops. sometimes you might convince someone you had a horrible accident but you should really stick to the shadows and mostly the sewers where you feed on rats.want to be part of the insane malkavian clan so you cant speak one coherent sentence and creep everybody out and convince human beings that they are in fact turtles? you can too but prepare for things to unfold very differently. or do you want to be part of the snobbish ruler clan where the lower classes will treat you with disdain or a pretty boy (or gal) who charmes and seduces his way through the game (to the disdain of certain nosferatus).you can choose to hack computers and talk and find clues to complete quest. or bully, brawl and shoot your way through the questlines. you can be compassionate, insane or cruel all these things shape the story you will experience. not only can you decide the way you approach the game mechanically but you also have a say in how the story unfolds. for better or worse.there is a lot of atmosphere and humour to the game so there are definitely light hearted moments. but for the most part its all about lowlife, decadence, depravity, perversion and supernatural and sometimes even lovecraftian horror.bloodlines is using the source engine (the half life 2 one). im not sure but i think it came out before half life 2 and it certainly shows. but the facial animations in the dialouge are on point. ranging from bored teenage store clerk, doped up pawn shop owner or insane cultist. oh and the mutliple choice dialogue is decently expansive. with great writing.troika went broke while completing the game so it was released in a very buggy state. nonetheless this game was (and still is) considered by many rpg fans as one of the best. i concur. if you like deus ex or just rpgs in general you will find a lot to like. its quite unique and unmatched in many ways. certainly the best vampire game on the market.even 13 years (wow really? time flies!) after release the community is still active in modding and patching the game. you should definitely (yes there is no argument to be had) get the latest unofficial community patch by wesp (i think) from patchesscrolls. the last one is from a few days ago. shows you the dedication of certain fans. a lot of bugfixes and an optional plus patch that restores content cut from the game due to development limitations and such.the voice acting ranges from superp and excellent to "sufficient". but the enviromental sounds are quite fitting and the soundtrack gives you a great neonoir (thats a thing right?) feeling.theres a lot more to mention and im sure other steam reviews will help you out or some big game reviewers go into more detail. all in all its a fantastic game and there is no reason not to try it.(btw if you live in germany dont be put off by the "low violence" disclaimer)this "low violence" version used to be sold as the german uncut version in stores and it basically is.the only confirmed cut is a nanosecond of the intro sequence and if you install the unoffical patch "plus" the restoration stuff you dont have to "worry" about that either.pro +great writing. (story and dialogue)interesting characters.decent facial animations.classless system.great atmosphere. (with some ♥♥♥♥ your pants moments.)highly non linear.lots of replayability. decent hacking mechanic and a cool computer interface where you actually have to type.lots of weapons, magic. stats and talents. (you can make people go insane or puke blood and stuff goood times)different vampire clans that are really different! people will react to you differently. greatly.cool soundtrack and enviromental sounds.voice acting is really good when its good.community patches and mods.gory fun.lovecraftian reverences..twistscon -dated graphics.will be buggy without patches.can be frustrating due to its sometimes harsh difficulty.you can potentially screw up your character build.voice acting is not so good sometimes. (unless its great)overall a great game. just dont expect a first person shooter. it isnt one. its more like the fallout or deus ex games in that respect.i say buy the game and spread the word about how awesome it is.lets hope troika or some developers of it make a comeback.and uh.... "dont open it".

content:
er 28, 2015
												NOTE: It says I have zero game hours because I used the unofficial patch and it didn't record my Steam hours. Just know that I played this game ALOT.This is my second favorite role-playing game of all time! And it's still extremely close to my first favorite, Mass Effect 2. The voice acting is really, really good. You get a pen and paper-like character customizer where you get to pick your gender, and vampire clan along with a backstory about before you became a vampire. The intro is really interesting and builds the world very well. You really do feel like a vampire that's hiding their true identity in Los Angeles. Each quest is interesting, and are all worth playing. Instead of an open world, you get four hub cities Santa Monica, Hollywood, Downtown, and Chinatown. Depending on your gender, clan, and certain skills, you can select alot of interesting dialogue options, and unlock more too! The lore is very interesting, and I recommend studying it on the White Wolf Wiki if you're gonna buy this game. This game also has great characters who are all very detailed in the world. In fact, my favorite gaming character of all time came from this game, Therese Voerman. If you look past the dated graphics, even some bugs with the unofficial patch still installed, and look at all the great things this game has to offer like detailed role-playing, interesting characters, a well set up world, rich lore, and great quests, you can easily have alot of fun with this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2013
												Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines is a rare gem. It takes the basic gameplay of the intelligent shooters of old and mixes it with a heavy does of RPG mechanics and open ended storytelling.Bloodlines start you off in a very classic vampire way, you find yourself in a seedy motel room being hot and heavy with someone of the opposite sex when all of the sudden they bite you. Before you get a chance to get your bearings some goons storm the place and take you and your new lover away to a court where your lover is executed for making a new vampire without permission but you are uncharacteristically spared. You are then set loose on the streets where a friendly old geezer explains what it means to be a vampire and after a quick tutorial introducing you the various concepts of the game you are free to explore the city.Bloodlines is a first person shooter in it's most basic form although many of the weapons and abilities are melee in nature. It takes a great deal of inspiration from Deus Ex and System Shock by creating a myriad of different ways to go about each area. Lots of vents and back alleys, locks to pick and people to persuade. There is always another way to go about things depending on your skills and inclination. The RPG system is fairly straight forward, you get skill points as you level up which can then be put into a myriad of different skills and abilities including some special vampire magic that tends to be specific to the vampire clan you select during character creation.The vampire clans are on the big highlights of the game with the most notable mentions being Nosferatu who are hideous and unable to pass for a human unlike the other clans and the the Malkavians who are, quite literally, completely and utterly insane. Both of these change the way you play and experience the game significantly and in particular the Malkavian guarantees you will need a second playthrough.The main storyline isn't anything tremendously exciting however the smaller side-quests and the world itself is exceptionally well written and acted and you will feel heavily immersed throughout the game.Source is the engine upon which this is all created which makes for a decent looking game even though it was released a good while after Half-Life 2 due to licensing issues which unfortunately also had the side-effect of absolutely killing the sales of this game and also Troika, the developers.When originally released Bloodlines was extremely bug ridden despite the delay in release and it was nearly unplayable at that point, now however most of the bugs have been patched out and for those few things left unfinished there is a very high quality fan made patch that I recommend everyone gets before playing the game.All in all Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines is one of the best games of the modern era and one of the few modern games that manages to pull off a first person view without losing sight of what the game is trying to accomplish. You could classify it as an action RPG or as a first person shooter with some RPG elements but either way, it's a great game.

content:
4, 2014
												Rating: 8.5/10What is it? First Person RPG in a vampire setting. The Good:+ Character creation is excellent. You start off by choosing your vampire clan. Each clan has its own set of abilities. Two clans in particular really change the game up: The Malkavians and the nosferatu really play differently from the other clans offering some nice replay value.+ Lots of stats to further build your character. Play as a melee, stealth, guns, hacking etc.  Build a character that fits your play style+ The plot and characters are interesting, they really flesh out the story and dialogue. + Great main and side missions+ Multiple ways of completing your missions depending on your character build. Go in guns blazing, or sneak in through the back, etc. + A lengthy game that never feels boring or drawn out simply because the developers did a good job of keeping things interesting all the way through. The Bad:- Technical and texture glitches. The game was officially patched however there were still plenty of bugs left over. You must play with some of the unofficial patches. I was playing with a widescreen mod which may have contributed to all the texture anomalies. -The combat feels less polished then the rest of the game. Melee combat goes into third person view which could be off putting to some. Using guns can be very frustrating and probably won't be worth it until you invest some heavy experience points into the firearm skill. Guns probably won't be effective until half way through the game. - Some really annoying parts of the game.  Luckily it was far and few between to really hurt the overall experience.ConclusionA great game, and if you love RPG's this is a great game that you can't go wrong with. Possibly one of the best vampire games out there.

content:
y 20, 2015
												It should be noted straight away that this game cannot be run on modern operating systems without unofficial patches. For those who don't want to take the time to figure out how to do this, you'll probably want to avoid purchasing this game.That said, if you're comfortable with spending a few minutes finding and installing the unofficial patches, you might find this game interesting. You should probably wait for a deep-cut sale though; $20 for a 10 year old game that barely made it out of production is a little silly.The good:- Excellent writing (easily the best aspect of the game)- Compelling storyline- Interesting lore and characters- Voice acting is very well done- Play as one of seven vampire clans with differing abilities- Allows for several different play styles- Explore side quests in a non-linear fashion- Multiple endingsThe bad:- Combat feels very clumsy. The defensive stance in melee combat is essentially worthless. It is difficult to maneuver and avoid being hit by enemy attacks.- The game favors melee combat until much later in the game where guns are very powerful. However, since this is an RPG, the player must level up their skills one way or the other. Certain boss encounters are very difficult for players who choose a melee play style.- There are stats that are basically worthless to invest in, such as haggling. Lockpicking and hacking can be useful for those in a hurry, but are in most cases not needed since keys and password notes can be found nearby. Other stats such as those used to influence others in dialogue are useful early on in the game, but aren't used at all later on.- It is not possible to remain in first-person view at all times. The game forces you into the third-person view when engaging in melee combat. Ranged combat functions like a first person shooter.- The player can make many different choices, but there are no diverging story paths. All choices the player makes eventually lead to the same outcome.- The graphics aren't terrible, but look quite dated.- At times there are graphical glitches or weird physics.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												I'm not normally a fan of Vampire games, but I picked up this one upon recommendation by a friend, and holy cow is it good! Important points include:1) There are violent encounters you can turn into diplomatic ones, if you're very diplomatic.2) There are stealth encounters you can turn into shoot 'em up encounters, if you're inclined.3) The game is reasonably faithful to the tabletop, but makes some pretty clear changes to make it a good video game.4) There's a mission where you're supposed to get rid of a ghost. It just might be the scariest mission in the whole game, and you don't fight a single monster or enemy the whole time.5) If you play the game as a Malkavian, your flaw is that you're crazy. So they changed all the dialogue options to reflect this, voiced over responses to your crazy talk, and made a few other changes to make it really work.6) This is the first time since high school that I felt like I really wanted to play a vampire tabletop game.NOTE: The unofficial patch (now in version 9.0) is basically required to play this game on a modern computer. You can get it here: http://www.patches-scrolls.com/vampire_bloodlines.php

												I actually really enjoyed and still enjoy this game. True, everything about this game is dated, the graphics though good then seem poor now and the interactions between you and in game NPCS range from linear to non-existent. That being said, I love this game, it is dark, gritty, and really gives you that predatory sense you would expect from being on top of the food chain. The dialogue that you do experience between your character and other characters never feels forced and is almost always engaging. Additionally I want to say,  being Malkavian is so entertaining that even though the general story does not change regardless of what clan you pick, it feels like a completely different experience.  This game gives out multiple endings, with interesting plot twists and a whole ranges of level concepts ranging from frightening to pure combat. My only real complaint about this game are in the in game cut scenes, I don't know exactly what it is, but the models at times look so hunched over and walk like they have too poop sometimes that I get actively annoyed. All that being said, definitely worth exploring the world of darkness if you got the time.

content:
22, 2013
												One of the greatest FPSRPG games of all time, thwarted by it's own ambitious design, a publisher that refused to allocate funds to finish and polish the game, and valve cockblocking the release until half life 2 was out (which of course stole all the limelight and caused the game to sell poorly)It has since developed a cult following, and numerous unnofficial patches and gameplay updates.It really succeeds in making you feel like an undead badass and in portraying a world that thrives at 3am, features memorable locations like a gothic nightclub, a hollywood porno store and of course a haunted house (and theatre, and cemetary, and derelict hospital, and rundown apartment building, and fish market.... basically there's a lot of hauntings)Features some terrific writing, dialogue and humour. It also has a great levelling system where allocated skills and abilities actually affect the gameplay in a big way.Gamebreaking bugs and glitches can usually be overcome with the unnofficial patches, and are highly recommended.

23, 2014
												Bloodlines is a flawed gem of a game, it had a troubled as hell development and it really shows. The game is a buggy mess, but thankfully fans have patched out a lot of the bugs so make sure to get the Wesp fan patch before you play. To sum it up Bloodlines has some of the best atmosphere, writing, and actual roleplaying in an RPG and it still really holds up to this day. There's multiple solutions through missions and each vampire clan have their own unique skills to solve them, i.e. Nosferatu can turn themselves invisible, Tremere have powerful blood magic, and Malkavians can drive people insane. Sadly, the game falls apart in the end with some horrid forced combat sections (So make sure you have a good combat build going, though just cheating through it is totally fine) but it ultimately is a game worth playing because there are still way too few RPGs that are like it.

content:
22, 2015
												Well, where to start with this game. It is easy to be swallowed in to the game by it's rich storyline and a fantasticly written dialogue - but it's not just that. I felt immersed in this game that was able to describe and not only give me an idea of - but also allow me to feel like I was suddenly pulled into a vampire society. Which, judging by the popularity of the vampire genre in video gaming, seems to be something that many games involving vampires have great difficulty with. I look forward to the future and hope that the vampire genre can be inspired by this game.I'll list the pros and cons of this briefly, from my experience. Pros:~ Deep and non-linear storyline.~ At the start, you can choose your stats or 'roll' them randomly (let the game decide!), and have a choice of clans with their own personality, background, advantages and disadvantages.~ Creative and well written dialogue, of which can change depending on chosen clan.~ Voice acting that fits well with the characters and enriches their personalities.~ Many hours of play filled with many missions and many choices for you to make.~ Experience various entertaining kinds of insanity.Cons:~ There are bugs. The patch does help with this and is easy to find with a web search. However, it does not eliminate them completely, and this is also to be expected when playing an old game. Personally I wasn't bothered by them, as I was too busy enjoying the storyline.~ Combat is funky. This links with the bugs, but don't get me wrong - there are tough fights.~ Graphics can be improved with the patch I believe, but are still old. It's not disasterous or unplayable however, by any means - on the contrary, very good for an old game in my opinion.~ For some people this will be a con. SAVE OFTEN. Your experience of the game will differ in places depending on the choices you make, and you may want to go back to have a different experience later. And then of course, there's always the possibility of getting shredded up and dying.

content:
2014
												This is a great game! If you can get it to work. That's right. Before buying VTMB, you should know what you're getting yourself into. The game was never finished; it was released as an imcomplete, buggy, broken product - and that's what it still is, even today. Teams of modders have been working on it to either fix as many bugs as they could or even to rebalance and redesign it and to install one of the unofficial patches is, after installing the game to your hard drive, the very first thing you should do; but even so, be prepared for a world of bugs, crashes, google searches, .exe replacing, .cfg tweaking and so on.Let me tell you about my experience with this game. I bought it. Then, I installed Tessara's gold patch which, supposedly (and I have no reason to think otherwise) does an amazing job at fixing all the imaginable problems this game was released with. Then I had to find a way to make the screen resolution acceptable (not 1024*768, this isn't 1999 anymore). Then I was on the street and I noticed a loss of framerate, so I tweaked the .cfg file to deactivate meteo effects. After a couple hours I reached a beach and the game started crashing, forcing my computer into sleep mode. I couldn't get past that beach. Later on I found that the sea's texture was making my comps go bananas so I went for more .cfg tweaking. Then I played a couple more hours and the AI, suddenly, disabled itself - meaning, NPCs froze in place, making the game completely unplayable. Then, as I was looking for a solution, my comps started crashing again.That was it. I decided to wait a year or two for the (unbelievably dedicated) teams of modders who were working at fixing this game, and uninstalled Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.Now don't get me wrong - some people (with Tessara's help in any case) are able to play VTMB just fine. I was able to play for like 5 hours and it was great - dark, immersive, great attention to detail, thrilling game system, great infiltration sequences... It feels like Deus Ex all over again. It feels like a pen & paper experience where I'm alone with the game master. It feels great.But it's ♥♥♥♥ing unstable. It's broken. Anyone considering purchasing this game should know that there's a risk that it won't work at all, that you'll spend as much time fixing it as playing it. Buying this game is a gamble - you're risking your money here.But, again, when it works, whoa, guys - what a ride!

content:
ry 23
												This is by the far the best single vampire game in existence.There have been countless vampire games through the years.  Some focus on the monster, some focus on the romance,  Most you don't particularly have to think about all the consequences of becoming one.  This game will immerse you in a seductive and dangerous world of vampirism the likes of which has not been replicated to this degree in a game.  And when I say you, I mean you.  It is a deeply personal affair in which you can take a personal journey or a journey of any character you wish, with whatever depth you wish.Do you want to be the outcasts of society?  Do you want to be the Hollywood monster that people avert their gaze from?  Do you want to be the Anne Rice version of a vampire?  Smart, seductive, ruthless.  Do you want to be utterly insane?  So many ways to make yourself your own, so many ways to interact with the myriad of story lines in the dark, urban nightlife of Cali.The music is also phenomenal.  Utterly fantastic.  The soundtrack feels dark and gritty while you're wandering the streets, diving in sewers and popping in night clubs seducing and making your way.Modding is REQUIRED.  I say again, R E Q U I R E D.  Don't think about playing this without extensive research on the must have mods.  The story of this title is infamous, go read if you want to know why it requires so much rework and how passionate this community around it is.  I did the unofficial patch and a few graphic overall mods myself, your mileage may vary.Writing this review makes me want to install it again and play...If you have any interest of vampires whatsoever, pick it up!

												This game, moreso than any others I've played, embodies the word "classic". Though buggy and unpolished in its original state of release, the unofficial patch allows this title to reach its full potential: an experience that completely draws you into its gloomy, thoroughly immersive settings, with characters so vibrant as to make you almost think - and certainly wish - that you were carrying on conversations with the most intriguing individuals you could ever imagine. The class customization and dialogue options allow you to feel like you're shaping your own destiny, and progression is steady and fairly well paced, so that by the end, you feel like you're ready to step into whatever epic showdown awaits. With atmospheric music, witty personalities, unique game mechanics, and absolutely top-notch voice-acting, this is a  vampire adventure you'd be sorry you missed out on.

content:
ry 28
												As a huge fan of the VTM tabletop game, I'll admit, I was skeptical when I first bought this.  Sometimes adapting one media into another (be it book to movie, game to movie or, in this case, one type of game to another), it either loses something or gains WAY too much to be enjoyable to longtime fans of whatever the previous media was.  So, yeah, I had my doubts -- but let me tell you, they were entirely unfounded.  This has become one of my favorite (if not absolute favorite) RPGs of all time.  Not only does it stay true to the source, which was a big selling point for me, but it is so incredibly easy to become immersed in the world you're presented.  The atmosphere is wonderful, especially for an older game when creating those elements is a bit more limited than it is now; maybe it's just me, but while wandering around Santa Monica, L.A., and the rest, I definitely do get that feeling of 'city by night'.  Lots of memorable NPCs scattered about, and the combat system is..fair, I think.  A little wonky here and there, but for the most part, it's pretty smooth.  That your decisions/dialogue affect some aspects of gameplay is always a neat element, too,  and as an added bonus:  no sparkly, wussy vampires.  That goes along with 'staying true to the source', yes, but for anyone who can't help but roll their eyes upon seeing 'vampire', it's worth calling attention to this.Really, I can only find two major downfalls for this game:  first and foremost would be the graphics.  While again, it is a beautiful game, especially for its age, it certainly could benefit from some better visuals, especially where player characters and NPCs are concerned.  This isn't super important to me or anything, as it doesn't take...well, anything, away from the game, but it is worth mentioning.  Second would be the fact that there is no fast travel while in a zone.  It DOES help with immersion, I'll admit, and it's not like the zones are HUGE, by any means, but sometimes it does seem tedious to have to run from point A to point B.All in all, thought, this game is absolutely fantastic.  It's hardly perfect, but for anyone who enjoys RPGs, I cannot possibly recommend this one enough.  This is just one of those games where, every time someone mentions it, someone else will just HAVE to reinstall it.  It's just THAT good.

content:
4
Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines is filled with a dark, seedy, gory and erotic atmosphere that makes the gameplay all the more intense. VTMB is a story-rich, choice-driven experience where your thought process, your beliefs, your moral compass and the way you interpret situations directly affect both gameplay and story. VTMB awards the player with malleable main quests, a variety of secondary quests and comprehensive characters with unique motives and ideologies. Explore inner cities, mansions, beach houses, sewers, underground cities, asylums, haunted hotels and more. VTMB allows the player to explore complex moral and existential questions through the eyes of bloodsucking monsters. Contemplate on the meaning of politics, sex, death and life while simultaneously coming to terms with your own monstrosity.You chose to play one out of seven vampire clans, each with their own bloodline weaknesses and strengths. Once you choose your preferred gender and clan, you preliminary fill your skills and abilities sheet.  The choices are endless and incredibly flexible – you can be a femme fatale with a weaponized sexuality, a passionate brawler who persuades people with intimidation and fist-fights, a stealthy shadow dweller that hacks and lock picks their way through each level or a malformed nosferatu who is forced to travel through the sewers and dark alleys lest he risks breaking the Masquerade. The choices continue, and you can mix and match as you please.The main plot of the game is that you were a mortal who has been recently turned into a vampire, a process known as the embrace. The Camarilla, or the ruling class of vampires in Los Angeles, executes your sire for not following the proper siring protocols and for breaking the Masquerade. The Masquerade is an organized campaign enforced by the Camarilla to convince people that vampires do not exist.The Masquerade is the cornerstone survival strategy for Kindred, without it, the humans would rise up and exterminate all the undead. From there on, you learn your ways as a new vampire under the rule of the Camarilla. However, VTMB is a heavy choice-based game with a story-rich plot that allows your character to make decisions that fundamentally change, derail, progress or otherwise conflict with the overall narrative of the game. For instance, there are different political factions, such as the Anarchs you can join that have their own stories, quests and motivations. Doing so will unlock new endings and will allow you to rebel against the standard narrative of the game which is doing the Camarilla’s main quests. This choice mechanic is prevalent in absolutely every aspect of the game. For instance, the one of the first quests you have to do is meet Mercurio, a Camarilla agent you have been tasked with helping. Once you meet him, he will tell you he was robbed. He will tell you that he was supposed to meet with a local gang at their Beach House and purchase their explosives. Unfortunately for him, he went alone, got beat up and failed to trade for the explosives. A dying, bloody Mercurio then asks you to retrieve that the explosives for him and avenge him. Now, upon receiving this quest you can:Fight your way through the Beach House with clan disciplines and/or good ‘ol fist fights and retrieve the explosives.Sneak your way through by lurking in the shadows, avoiding bodyguards, performing stealth kills, killing the lights and retrieving the explosives.Seduce your way through each bodyguard up to the seller. Then, using masterful subterfuge get the gang boss alone by creating the illusion that you are going to exchange sex for goods, kill him by sucking his blood dry and then simply walk out. Or rob the place and then make a run for it – or kill them anyways. Intimidate them through dialogue and maybe fist-fight one to prove your worth. Persuade them through dialogue to set you up an opportunity to trade with their boss and then properly haggle with them (through dialogue) to get a cheaper price and/or potentially for free in exchange for other goods and/or favors. Use certain clan disciplines to control the mortal fools and make them kill each other, then retrieve the explosives. Use certain clan disciplines to speedily break into the window where thee explosives are located, steal them back and run. Or, my personal favorite in the second run-through of the game. Kill Mercurio for being a demanding ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and a screw-up. Get the explosives however you desire and carry on with your quests.VTMB also offers an interesting approach to combat as well – slash your enemies with katanas, sledgehammers, bare fists and more. Use specific clan disciplines to sneak through your enemies, dismember them or enslave them. The game is incredibly well-written, with unique dialogue options allowed and displayed depending on the clan you choose. All in all – buy this game, you will be replaying it over and over again, finding new details, new quests, new dialogue options and new approaches to gameplay.If you enjoy the way I review games, join and follow my curator group! It comes with a fun discord channel for horror fans to chill and game. Malkavian Madness

												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, is a near perfect gaming experience despite coming across hundreds of flaws in most every aspect of the game, from the visuals, audio, optimization, rushed mechanics, poor save files, and so forth... Bloodlines suffers from a plagued development, and is far from finished, but comes across as a product both greatly entertaining and lengthy in gameplay. Utilizing the HL2 Source engine, Bloodlines is easily modifiable, and as such many fan made community patches are in circulation around the internet. I highly recommend downloading these patches for a more refined and polished gaming experience (although it is optional as the game is still playable all the way through without said patches). Bloodlines delivers exceptional voice acting, a grim and atmospheric setting, a fantastically agreeable soundtrack, a fair amount of character customization, and at times, a fair amount of role-playing choices, all for a low sum of 20 bucks, and believe me folks - with said amount of issues, it's still very much worth it.

												This has been my favorite game since it released in '04. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes the supernatural (vampires, werewolves, ghosts, etc.), dark humor, and an RPG more akin to Deus Ex than Oblivion. For additional enjoyment, get the Unofficial Patch, which you can easily find via Google. It is still being updated from time to time by a talented devotee who goes by Wesp5. The patch features a basic version that fixes any bugs that have been brought to light and can be corrected, as well as a plus version which includes actual content that was in the game but had not been implemented at the time of release; even pre-recorded dialog and weaponry. I've beaten the game somewhere between 20 and 30 times, you can play as 7 different types of vampire, each of which you can upgrade differently with experience points, which are gained via completing quests rather than grinding kills.How did I forget to mention the characters in my original review? Almost every character in this game is memorable, with many interesting and likable characters: Nines Rodriguez, Velvet Velour, Jeanette Voerman, Therese Voerman, Knox, Gary Golden, Damsel, Romero, Mercurio, Sebastian LaCroix, Chunk, and many, maaany more. I've probably logged at least one-thousand hours on this game on the disc version before it ever came to Steam. I love this game and wish there had been more games from the developer in this universe, but at least I'll always have Bloodlines. <3

Well that is exactly what this game is like and it has a very complex structure of Vampire that I've frankly, never seen before where there are many different races of Vampire each with their own distinct look, personality traits, and strengths/weaknesses, for example, the Malkavians are absoultely insane and have different personalities talking in their head and see telephone lines swaying constantly in the air and people will be a little off-put by you (if you choose to be this class...this is exactly what you'll see and hear as well along with crazy dialogue options)The gameplay is more or less exactly like Deus Ex with more modern day weaponry and the fact that in order to use your special ablities you need blood which you can either drink a blood pack or find a victim and follow them into a back alley and have a buffet delight.The story is also very intriguing and is inline with the lore from the tabletop games where its essentially about this ancient vampire coming back to life and eating Vampires and causing the end of the world.I'd recommend this game to anybody really and especially those who are a fan of Deus Ex, Vampires, or fans of RPG/Action games. This is another really underrated game that definitely should get more sequels (comeon Activision, I know you have it in your black heart somewhere!) If you see it during a sale for about $10, which is rare, think about picking it up because you shouldn't be disappointed.
