er 12, 2015
												This game is amazing.  I actually stood around a radio in this game just to listen to each radio program loop in each game chapter because it was so damn entertaining.  This game is loaded with so much awesome stuff, and the humor in it is great.  It's a shame these guys when out of business, they had the potential to make games as good as anything Bethesda has put out.   A note about all the people complaining about this game needing a patch to run: Of course it does, morons, stop your whining.  This game was made to run on an operating system that's been obsolete for over a decade (and people could argue that Windows ME/2000/XP/etc were garbage when they came out), and the company that made the game was crushed and is long gone, of course you will need to DL a patch to run it.  The good news is that these patches also fix bugs that were originally issues in the game.  So look up and follow the easy to install patches, it's totally worth it (and they are free, so ... yeah).    This game is also worth multiple play-throughs, which can be hard to find with linear story/plot games.  As each clan (and gender) has some different perks, playing through more than once can be rewarding.  And if you haven't played as a Malkavian (the crazy ones), that is always good for a last play-through for the whole game.   Great for any fan of Vampire the Masquerade, great for any vampire genre fan, great for any FP/RPG game lover.  I played this a LONG time ago, and playing again now is just as fun, and it is still an impressive game.  I highly recommend this game.

content:

												“Remember, wherever we go, it is the blood of Caine which makes our fate.”Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines is a great role-playing game with an immersive dark atmosphere, authentic characters and a solid storyline, that does the game justice. The bloodline (clan) you choose will affect your relationship with other characters, the available quests and the choices presented to you throughout the game, offering plenty of variation and replayability. While the A.I. is simple and pretty straight forward, the game often gives you several ways to solve a situation, including combat, stealth and rhetorical possibilities. The unbalanced combat mechanics are the weakest link of the game, which can create partially frustrating combat situations. The official support for this game was stopped in 2005, leaving it behind with numerous bugs. The fan community has released an unofficial patch, which addresses most of the issues and can be found on the link below (thanks to Voxel).http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647To fix the runtime error, try the following link (thanks to Zzero).http://steamcommunity.com/app/2400/discussions/3/846959521009517711/Fun Fact: The several different vampire clans and their various strengths and weaknesses are based on the tabletop role-playing franchise Vampire: The Masquerade. --My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Characters-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Story-	Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(Ah, your’re gonna love this! Alright, check it out. Blood: It’s your new rack o’lamb, your new champagne – blood’s your new ♥♥♥♥in’ heroin, kid.)Characters: S-Rank (I am the proprietor and salesman of the month several years in a row; the ladies call me “Oh, god!”, but you can call me Fat Larry with F-A-T, ‘cause I know I got a weight problem and I just don’t give a ♥♥♥♥.)Details: S-Rank (Man, we got everything you’ll ever need. Softcore, hardcore, gay, straight, farm or furry. We got shockers, shiverers, self-lubricators and strap-ons. Chains, crops and canes are in the back next to the triple-ripple. Like I said, we got it all.)Tactical gameplay: A-Rank Story: B-Rank Combat & Controls: C-Rank --There are no achievements to conquer.Achievement difficulty: none--Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (PC) – First-person role-playing game(Dark Fantasy) – 2004-Vampire: The Masquerade – Redemption (PC) – Action role-playing game Dark Fantasy) – 2000

7, 2014
												Know that if you get this game, there is a decent chance that it will need some tweaking to even run.  The instructions to do this can be found here.http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=229Talking to people, I cannot pinpoint the reason that some new computers will run it without the fix and some will not.This game is old and the people that made it are out of business.  Steam has posted it up here basically "As-Is", without warning us.  While I have the assurance of many Steam users that this game is excellent, I have yet to play it as I haven't felt like jumping through the hoops.Granted that patching or modding older games to work has been a staple of PC gaming for years, shouldn't we be past that in the age of digital distribution? I am appealing to Steam here, you are the future(some would argue the present) of PC gaming distribution, putting a game for sale that has issues with so many modern computers is step backwards.This is the edited version of the review based on input from other users.(you can find my original dissapointment filled review below)----This game crashes as soon as you run it.  If you want, you can follow guides like some kind of treasure map to get it to run but that kind of misses the point of steam.Knowing the bad press that would come from this, Steam requires a 5 minute play-time minimum before posting a review, so I ran the game and let it crash over and over until i got to 5 minutes.  Hopefully I can reach a few people to spread the message that, instead of buying a fun vampire game, you are being the target of an insidious cash grab.Shame on the game's makers for it not being fixed and shame on Steam for selling it.----

content:
ry 12
												I first bought this game in 2005 (back when CD-Roms were still a thing), and have been playing this game on and off ever since. I could talk about the bugs (there are plenty), the glitches (try beating the game without I patch, I dare you) or anything like that, but honestly, it is not relevant at all when it comes to this game, not in 2017 at least. This old, little game that many have never even had the pleasure to hear about, is still supported by a loyal community that have made this game something very special. They adopted a game that was left in a very unfinished state and not only fixed what was broken, but recovered and completed unfinished and unused portions of the game as well as add new content to create a one-of-a-kind game that anyone who loves RPGs, Vampires, Role-playing or just a good game in general will enjoy. The game itself, even before it was patched, is unique and charming. You play as a vampire in a gritty, dark version of Los Angeles. You are given nearly complete freedom as to how you want to play. You can talk your way out any situation, use violence to get the job done, or sneak around and avoid dealing with people altogether. There's 7 "clans" to play as, and each one offers a unique experience which is better suited for one style of gameplay or the other (good luck charming your way through the game as a Nosferatu). The characters you meet are memorable, and your dialogue choices really have an impact on how they interact with you. In some cases their lives may even depend on your choices. You'll find yourself hating, liking or at the very least caring about some of these characters, and will remember them long after you beat the game. The locations are likewise interesting, memorable and unique. From the dangerous streets of Downtown L.A. to dark Griffith Park and from the sewers under Hollywood to a haunted mansion in Santa Monica, you will not be bored with your surroundings (even if the graphics are dated). I could go on and on, but you should really see for yourself. Make sure you patch the game, and then immerse yourself in a World of Darkness. You will not be dissappointed and be drawn to this game time and time again.

content:
y 5
												There isn't much I can say about this game that hasn't already been said, but since this has become one of my top five favorite games of all time, I have to leave a review.There are very few RPGs that have this level of depth. Fantastic atmosphere with fleshed out NPCs. Excellent writing is complimented by voice acting. The clan you choose and the choices you make have a direct effect on how the world responds to you and on how the story unfolds, which has become increasingly rare in modern games. Your choices have consequences that open and close doors. There's a lot of replay value just in exploring the "what ifs". That being said, it is an unfinished game, and the gameplay leaves something to be desired. You /have/ to install a fanmade patch in order to be able to even complete the game, which is why I have so few hours logged since I forgot to have it launch via Steam. Even with it intalled there are some bugs that I needed to fix with the console. Combat is clunky and the unavoidable camera change in melee is annoying. Some skills become very unviable in late game. However, I do like the perk system and how there is a real feel of progression. Obviously the graphics are going to be dated since it's a thirteen year old game, but I think they hold up pretty well and it's not a deal breaker for me, especially since I don't own a powerful gaming PC.Overall, Bloodline's succesions highly outweight its shortcomings. If Troika hadn't been rushed and had time to fully develop and complete this game, I have no doubt it would be considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time.

												Rating: 8/10 (With Unofficial Patch, NOT RECOMMENDED if otherwise)Great RPG that will totally suck you in (Pun unintended) and get you interested in vampire lore. 												This game is an amazing adventure through the old World of Darkness, suitable for anyone regardless of experience with the tabletop roleplaying game. For those interested in that, I'd like to note the world in which this game takes place has been rebooted in a new game, and the current analogue to Vampire: The Masquerade is called Vampire: The Requiem. Some terms and ideas still exist, but the very feel of the world and the themes of the game are wholly different. They've switched from the advertised "gothic-punk" atmosphere (a term the company itself uses to describe the old setting) to a more supernatural mystery/thriller feel. Even if you don't intend to play the tabletop game, this is still one of my favorite RPGs, period. Just make sure you go out and download the unofficial patch collection from a mod website. It's still buggy as hell.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Everytime you mention Bloodlines, someone installs it, or so it's said.Anyway, onto the review!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines has a ridiculous title but that's alright. It's based off a tabletop RPG called Vampire: The Masquerade by White Wolf Publishing.It's set in Los Angeles by night where the player controls their own vampire. There are seven clans to choose from and each has their own "thing". There's a clan which focuses on art, one that speaks in riddles, one that lurks in the shadows etc (Also adds replayability!). The PC is sadly not customisable, but it's possible to play as female or male. Gender doesn't have a very big impact on the game, but it affects NPC interaction a couple of times.There's also some crazy ♥♥♥♥ going down in game. I won't be going into too much details but it can be kinda scary sometimes. Also there will be gore, sex and even a snuff movie. And maybe about two jump scares.BUT WAIT. Luckily there's a console in case you really don't want to/can't do something. Hooray!There's no such game as levels in the game. Like a real RPG, there's a character sheet and you can upgrade your abilities by spending experience, which you get from completing quests.Questing is fairly fun in this game. There's no such thing as mindless farming! The first challenge is getting the quest, through picking the right dialogue. In some cases, if you pick the wrong dialogue you're missing out on quests and thus, experience.Quests can be completed in different manners. You can either kill everything, stealth and in some cases just with dialogue, which is nice for the lazy people among us. Sometimes it affects the experience gain though. (For example, getting 3 XP instead of 2 if you aren't seen).Combat is decent-ish, but at least you can switch between first- and third-person perspective.The game isn't sandbox, but there are a few hubs you can go to as you progress through the game. You can travel as much as you want, as you have your personal vampire cabdriver! Awesome!NPCs are all voiced and depending on the clan, even the whispers in your PCs head too! Isn't that fun, you'll never be lonely again! Anyway, it kinda adds to the already dark atmosphere of the game.And unlike a lot of games, choices DO matter, throughout the whole game. If you aren't nice to someone, you might miss out on a quest/experience/ending.The downside is that combat becomes more important as you get closer to the ending. This is probably because the developers were in a rush to finish the game. The vanilla game has some game-breaking bugs even, but if you use a patch by Wesp the game is definitely play-able.There are also a lot of loading screens. Fortunately, loading times aren't long.True, it's not a game for everyone. But what game is? BUT. IN THIS GAME...You'll meet fellow vampires, werewolves, ghosts, zombies and humans!You can be nice, sarcastic, or really mean!Your vampire can dance just as good as you can!Also you can make people explode so their blood is everywhere. Did I mention that? 'Cause that's cool you know.For a rushed game from 2004, it has a lot of mods and some even revamp whole game mechanics. So I guess it's kinda hard to get bored of it.Ten years and going strong!

												Bloodlines was damned to be a "flawed gem" straight out of the box. Despite a loyal, yet small fanbase creating unnoficial patches to fix the bugs found in the game, it still has a lot to be fixed. The game works on the early Source engine, so it uses to base code for Half Life 2, but the development cycle took different paths from the very beggining. The most notable feature of this RPG in particular is the fact that Experience isn't gained for kiling enemies, but for completing quests or finding alternate or special routes to them. That makes it a lot more that a run & gun game. This is - a true Role Playing Game.Even though this game came out in 2001 it i still by far my favorite RPG and no matter how many times I play it I always want to go back for more. I definitely reccomend this game.

First - The game is not playable without unofficial patches so you really should download one to be able to even complete the game. Though the game boasts a varied play style (Each vampire clan plays differently), the gameplay is not that enjoyable. Combat is clunky and the shooting mechanics are abysmal. But decent graphics (For its time) and a great soundtrack does make up for a lot of these flaws. So overall, expect a memorable, yet perfectly flawed (And I mean that in a good way) experience that you shouldn't pass on!

content:
y 5
												There isn't much I can say about this game that hasn't already been said, but since this has become one of my top five favorite games of all time, I have to leave a review.There are very few RPGs that have this level of depth. Fantastic atmosphere with fleshed out NPCs. Excellent writing is complimented by voice acting. The clan you choose and the choices you make have a direct effect on how the world responds to you and on how the story unfolds, which has become increasingly rare in modern games. Your choices have consequences that open and close doors. There's a lot of replay value just in exploring the "what ifs". That being said, it is an unfinished game, and the gameplay leaves something to be desired. You /have/ to install a fanmade patch in order to be able to even complete the game, which is why I have so few hours logged since I forgot to have it launch via Steam. Even with it intalled there are some bugs that I needed to fix with the console. Combat is clunky and the unavoidable camera change in melee is annoying. Some skills become very unviable in late game. However, I do like the perk system and how there is a real feel of progression. Obviously the graphics are going to be dated since it's a thirteen year old game, but I think they hold up pretty well and it's not a deal breaker for me, especially since I don't own a powerful gaming PC.Overall, Bloodline's succesions highly outweight its shortcomings. If Troika hadn't been rushed and had time to fully develop and complete this game, I have no doubt it would be considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time.

content:
er 17, 2014
												I would like to note that before anyone buys this, it will NOT RUN on modern machines unless you install fanmade patches. ( http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035 ) In this day and age vampires are often a mockery in pop culture, thanks in large part to sensations like Twilight. But let me tell you, this game has no glittering pretty boys. It's a true painting of what the modern vampire should be- they walk among us in society because they look like us, often using their intelligence and sex appeal to feed and maintain their powers. The game largely focuses on the politics within vampire society known as The Masquerade- it's this web of politics that sends you off on several quests where, depending on how you've chosen to level your character and converse in dialogue with NPCs can play out very differently. The side quests are also very compelling. And I'm usually incredibly disinterested in these- the lore and the characters are all just so well written it made me want to explore the game more.If you're looking for an obscure gem, excellent writing, unique atmosphere, or just tired of seeing Vampires suck ♥♥♥ like they have been in recent years this game is up your alley.

content:
9, 2015
												It was a bit tough to get this game started because I didn't have at least 15mb of RAM, but after installing the unofficial 9.2 patch, the game ran like a charm. I think during the entire play through I had less than half a dozen crashes. I found this to be pretty impressive considering I couldn't even launch the game after installation.Ok, so if you've bought the game and installed the 9.2 patch, the next step is to mod your female character to look like Jeanette or Velvet Velour ;)On to the game!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines sounds like a sequel and there was a game before it, but it starts fresh and doesn't seem to carry any baggage from the previous game. You play with roleplaying-style skill points which increase as you buy into the higher levels. Your skills range from melee, to stealth, to guns, to computer hacking, and everything in between!When creating your character you choose between male and female, and then one of many different families. These families give you your vampire powers, like terrifying presence, or moving in super speed.Your job as a newly converted vampire is to do the will of your Prince and leader. During your missions you'll meet so many creative and unique characters. The world you're put into is just so unique and enjoyable from everything else out there right now, it's really hard to describe how this game's story was.Bottom Line: Get this game. If you like great stories and/or role-playing games, then this is a gem I had missed for years and I wouldn't want any of you to miss it any longer.

												First of all, look at my total hours of playing this game...I know its zero(now probably just a few hours)...thats because I got the game back in 2004 when it came out and now with the steam platform I just had to get it here. With that said, let me tell you, I installed this game in 2004 and still have it installed today in 2014, I have well over 500 hours on this game and I will now proceed to try and give it another 500 hours on steam and heres why!This is my favourite game, I fell in love with it the second I played it.Its a very dark game that shows you the real world behind our lives and the sugar cotted world where we live in.You will see that this World of Darkness thats all around us Humans, is a brutal world where sex, violence and murder along with a lot more sins are casual things on a normal night in the vampire society.The gameplay is pretty much summed up as a quest based RPG, you have your main quest line but if you wish and start peeking around you will find plenty of side quests and each of them has tremendous depth and unique stories (sometimes sad or gruesome) of their own.You play the game the way you want to play! If presented with an obstacle you can most certantly find diferent ways of passing it and reach your goal, be it guns blazing, charming your way through, beating everyone up, sneak in without murdering anyway, its your choice, you play the way you want to play!This is an immersive game, with a dark atmosphere, filled with mysteries regarding both the main and side quest line and the lore itself of the world of Vampire The Masquerade!From the dark clouds in the nights sky to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s waiting in a alley to the beautiful soundtrack, this game acomplishes in setting the right ambience, dark, violent and seductive!I cannot express how much I love this game and how much I think you all should play it!Its a dark, moody game where you are now the social, brutal and sexual beast behind the veil of the world thats hidden from human sights!

content:
16, 2016
												As true a diamond in the rough as any game you can find here. Well, well worth the time of anyone who's interested in RPGs, arcane / urban / supernatural horror atmosphere, good writing in games or good plotting in gaming. If this is on sale you're cheating yourself if you don't give it a go.The premise in a nutshell: Your character goes on a bender and ends up dead, then undead. Saved from certain (final) death, you end up an investigator / fixer for a secret shadow society of urbane monsters, chasing down all sorts of weird happenings in and around nighttime Los Angeles. Talk, fight, and use your monstrous powers to manipulate or destroy hapless mortals and other, less redeemable things.Let's start with the good: The plotting, writing, atmosphere are all simply amazing. From the marketing materials and screenshots you might assume the game is grim and gritty and oh-so-goth, but the game is, for the most part, incredibly funny. Think Deadpool or Garth Ennis' comics - there's a lot of black humor. Most everybody is dead and loving it. And it's not possible to say enough about how incredible the voice talent cast is, with a small handful of exceptions. Yes, that's Bender showing you the vampiric ropes in the tutorial. If the premise seems ridiculous at first, the game will sell  you on it. The central mystery is really good and the sense of dread builds perfectly.The atmosphere of the game is great - much like Deus Ex, it makes the most of being set entirely at night. There is a definite sense of traversing the city of angels' seedy underbelly - while the rest of the world's sleeping, all the weirdos and club kids and dirty cops and streetwalkers come out to play. If you look hard enough you'll find not just other vampires but stranger, more sinister, and inexplicable things preying on humans. the original soundtrack is very good and mostly trip-hop influencedm and the licensed soundtrack (mostly playing in clubs) is, well... It's subpar goth metal, for the most part, but all the files are in .mp3 format so you can switch them out for whatever you want.*The narrative is composed of several story strands and subplots but is structured in "hubs and spokes" - think Hell's Kitchen in Deus Ex or Omega Station in Mass Effect 2. Each city center (there are four) is a large street-level area, thick with opportunities to take on new quests, pick fights, steal money or blood.As with any classic RPG, you have stats, skills and powers that you level up (note that experience is given on quest completion, not upon killing ♥♥♥♥ - it's just as viable, and probably more fun, to play a stealthy character). There are no classes but you do choose a "clan", sort of a vampiric race. One thing you'll constantly hear people rave about with this game is how different the game can get based on this choice - most are interchangeable (save for the powers given clans are allowed) but the Malkavians are marked by insanity, and so every single line of dialogue you can give in the game is rewritten as a bizarre riddle (it's fun to talk to NPCs as they try to make sense of you). Nosferatu, on the other hand, are clearly monstrous, and so most every human you interact with will freak out, if they assume you're not a burn victim or wearing a costume.Fighting gameplay is fairly good, though hardly exceptional. This came out before the advent of cover-based shooting so it may take some getting used to. Guns kind of suck unless you really know what you're doing. Melee can be fun but can also drag. Using your powers is always fun, you just have to watch your blood level (basically mana) - invest in the "brawling skill" so that you drain enemy blood in the middle of combat. Sneaking is pretty satisfying and intuitive. The visuals are pretty fugly, and the animations in gameplay are bit janky, with the very notable exception of the dialogue animations - Troika took full advantage of the rigging potential of the then-young Source Engine (V:tmB rather infamously released on the same day as Half-Life 2, to its detriment) and as a result the conversations hold up to this day- it's crazy to go from this to, say, Mass Effect and marvel how much more expressive NPCs are here.Bloodlines has its warts - Chinatown is full of caricatures, the lack of polish over the whole product is stupendously evident and a community patch is more or less essential to play the game to its fullest - but believe me when I tell you that there is no other game like this. When it gets its hooks in you, you'll play it to the end, and when it's over you'll wish you could spend more time exploring its strange, sinister world.* If you're going to do this, wipe all the ID2 tags from the file through Windows or Audacity before you insert them in, otherwise the game will freak out and crash.

												This game is such a delight to anyone a fan of horror and vampires, the attention to detail of gameplay and storyline for a game of the day and age for once it came out is of a unique high quality.The ability to turn from first person shooter to 3rd person at a moments notice for play style makes it versatile and keeps it fresh, full spoken dialog from characters in the world and questlines, the ability to choose and customize yourself/character from a variety of talents to apply to the game to finish objectives, play styles have a wide variety (be a sneaky lockpicking/hacker, a monster of a vampire with a brutish thirsts for blood and chaos, or a socialite with a sharp tongue for manipulation etc etc!). This aspect makes this game very re-playable, if one would like to explore all aspects that the game can offer.The character creation also gives you a variety of vampire clans to choose from, each with their own personal look and place within the world; special attacks and specializations are given for each clan presented depending on which one you choose from, some clans provide abilities that will help cater to the play style that you would wish to use.The beauty of this game is that they're more than one solution to finish a job and it purely depends on how you want to play the game and how you spread out your talent system. I don't want to give too much away but I highly recommend this game! I also recommend that before you play the game that you download the unofficial patch for the game as it removes some of the ingame bugs. http://www.moddb.com/mods/vtmb-unofficial-patchThe link also has a few cool mods to add onto the game like the Final Nights mod that changes the selection of clans in the character creation menu with all new special abilities and all that good stuff (do this after you play the origianls clans/clan if you are looking for more fun!)It's probably a very short review compared to the grand scale of this game has to offer but I hope I helped someone in convincing them to play this great game :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Everytime you mention Bloodlines, someone installs it, or so it's said.Anyway, onto the review!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines has a ridiculous title but that's alright. It's based off a tabletop RPG called Vampire: The Masquerade by White Wolf Publishing.It's set in Los Angeles by night where the player controls their own vampire. There are seven clans to choose from and each has their own "thing". There's a clan which focuses on art, one that speaks in riddles, one that lurks in the shadows etc (Also adds replayability!). The PC is sadly not customisable, but it's possible to play as female or male. Gender doesn't have a very big impact on the game, but it affects NPC interaction a couple of times.There's also some crazy ♥♥♥♥ going down in game. I won't be going into too much details but it can be kinda scary sometimes. Also there will be gore, sex and even a snuff movie. And maybe about two jump scares.BUT WAIT. Luckily there's a console in case you really don't want to/can't do something. Hooray!There's no such game as levels in the game. Like a real RPG, there's a character sheet and you can upgrade your abilities by spending experience, which you get from completing quests.Questing is fairly fun in this game. There's no such thing as mindless farming! The first challenge is getting the quest, through picking the right dialogue. In some cases, if you pick the wrong dialogue you're missing out on quests and thus, experience.Quests can be completed in different manners. You can either kill everything, stealth and in some cases just with dialogue, which is nice for the lazy people among us. Sometimes it affects the experience gain though. (For example, getting 3 XP instead of 2 if you aren't seen).Combat is decent-ish, but at least you can switch between first- and third-person perspective.The game isn't sandbox, but there are a few hubs you can go to as you progress through the game. You can travel as much as you want, as you have your personal vampire cabdriver! Awesome!NPCs are all voiced and depending on the clan, even the whispers in your PCs head too! Isn't that fun, you'll never be lonely again! Anyway, it kinda adds to the already dark atmosphere of the game.And unlike a lot of games, choices DO matter, throughout the whole game. If you aren't nice to someone, you might miss out on a quest/experience/ending.The downside is that combat becomes more important as you get closer to the ending. This is probably because the developers were in a rush to finish the game. The vanilla game has some game-breaking bugs even, but if you use a patch by Wesp the game is definitely play-able.There are also a lot of loading screens. Fortunately, loading times aren't long.True, it's not a game for everyone. But what game is? BUT. IN THIS GAME...You'll meet fellow vampires, werewolves, ghosts, zombies and humans!You can be nice, sarcastic, or really mean!Your vampire can dance just as good as you can!Also you can make people explode so their blood is everywhere. Did I mention that? 'Cause that's cool you know.For a rushed game from 2004, it has a lot of mods and some even revamp whole game mechanics. So I guess it's kinda hard to get bored of it.Ten years and going strong!

content:

												This game is an amazing adventure through the old World of Darkness, suitable for anyone regardless of experience with the tabletop roleplaying game. For those interested in that, I'd like to note the world in which this game takes place has been rebooted in a new game, and the current analogue to Vampire: The Masquerade is called Vampire: The Requiem. Some terms and ideas still exist, but the very feel of the world and the themes of the game are wholly different. They've switched from the advertised "gothic-punk" atmosphere (a term the company itself uses to describe the old setting) to a more supernatural mystery/thriller feel. Even if you don't intend to play the tabletop game, this is still one of my favorite RPGs, period. Just make sure you go out and download the unofficial patch collection from a mod website. It's still buggy as hell.

content:
ry 2, 2015
												A game every RPG fan should play.It takes place in LA, putting you in the shoes – or heels – of a freshly made vampire. They have a secret society and live among us with a certain set of rules to maintain order and ensure that their existence won't become widespread knowledge. This is the Masquerade. You become the new pawn for the local leader in his political wars. Not all is well in vampire community, and some factions are eager to change things.It's a comfortable entry – just as you're in the dark, so is your character, letting the two of you learn together who's who and what's what in vampire life. It's a pretty crazy one, too. Violence and sex are plentiful and the game doesn't shy from either. You'll find it hard, and not too rewarding, to play your regular Good Hero sort. It's also a very humorous game with plenty of moments that made me chuckle. The voice acting is terrific and there are many great characters. I found myself often just standing still and listening to the in-game news report on the TV, or the late-night radio show for the laughs. The story develops in unexpected ways and the ending managed to surprise me. Maybe I haven't found them out yet, but I didn't feel as if my choices bore significant consequences. It didn't really bother me, though, because the ride was a good one. The game is divided into city hubs that open one at a time after plot checkpoints, and you can jump from one to the other freely once they're available. You won't find the trademark "collect 10 donkey tails" side-quests that pollute fantasy RPGs, but instead many fun investigative missions outside the main plot. Backtracking can be annoying, though.While the story isn't too divergent, the gameplay is. It shares similarities with Deus Ex – many missions (though not all) don't offer just one way to the solution. Usually you can take a stealthy approach as well as the loud and bloody one. If your hacking skill is low, often your lockpicking will let you do the job instead – or vice versa. And while, like many other RPGs, it has its skills which aren't as useful as the others, I was happy to find out that many non-combat ones are still well utilized in the game. I won't write down a guide to power-building, though. One, because you can easily google it. Two, because it's hard to suck at the game.You can focus either on guns or melee. I did one playthrough of each, and while I felt that later on my gun-focused character was stronger, the melee was more satisfying, despite how simple it was. I really liked playing an immortal psychopath who charges into a room while people shoot at her and she just jumps around slashing everything. However, just like the graphics, keep in mind the year of the game and don't expect anything advanced in terms of combat mechanics.The game also has serious replay value. I'm already during my 3rd playthrough, and I'm not crossing out the possibility of a 4th sometime in the future. It's not due to different choices, because – as I said – they're not too significant here. It's partly due to reviewing the story with the insight of the twist at the end and partly due to different approach in mechanics – like many RPGs. You don't choose a specific class, but instead a clan. They're set apart by their own few unique abilities (some even have different dialogue options, which is pretty amazing if you ask me), while the bulk of the simple ones are shared between them all. Before you start, two things. First, the game is buggy as hell and you shouldn't play it without the unofficial patch. Google it, it'll come up. Second, don't play the Malkavian clan in your first run – they're lunatics who hear voices, and their dialogue is completely overhauled and special, partly due to their weird insights into matters. So without understanding the plot after a complete playthrough, and knowing what happens in each interaction, playing a Malkavian can be really confusing. But after your first playthrough? Highly recommended. They're very entertaining.

												Do not betray the Masquerade, Kindred, for the penalties of alerting humanity to our presence is dire indeed. Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines is an RPG powerhouse. In this game, you are embraced by a vampire clan of your choice and go through late night Los Angeles preying on humans and exploring the grim city that vampires call their home. The story is to die for, the mechanics are phenomenal and the world is incredibly immersive. It's pretty much a perfect 10/10 with memorable characters, distinctive settings and replay value as each clan of vampire plays differently from the others. Two minor things put this game back: The combat system is similar to that of Borderlands and that enough should tell you that it isn't the best way of doing things (it still executes this system better than Borderlands) and in order to even run the game, you must find the latest version of the Unofficial Patch and install it. Other than that, get this game. You'll be wishing you were a Child of Caine in no time.

content:
, 2014
												I really wanted this game back when it came out. Since I was on an extended gaming break at the time and had an old computer I missed out on it. But it always lurked in the back of my mind. Now I finally have and can emphatically state that the decades wait was worth it... With one caveat.First of all, you must get the unofficial patch, which is easily found and installed. Once that is in place you can start enjoying this absolute gem of a game.It's not the best at any one gameplay element. Melee combat is a bit clunky, ranged combat somewhat underpowered. Stealth is too easy and infiltration a bit simple. But that's exactly the thing - the sheer amount of choice and ways to achieve goals is incredible and puts many far more advanced games to shame. There is very rarely just one way to reach a destination but many. The choice of which clan you belong to (equivalent to choosing a race in standard rpgs) truly matters and makes the game have lasting value. On a new game you can either choose your clan or answer a series of questions to determine the clan. If you decide to buy this game I highly recommend that you answer the questions on your first playthrough.Add to this that the story is pretty good, the plot and progression of the story is great, every choice matters and there are tons of sidequests and you've got a real winner. Highly recommended.

content:
14
												For those of you who ascribe to the "TL;DR" method of reviews, here's basically what you need to know: the storytelling is fantastic, the characters are interesting, the voice-acting is awesome, and while the graphics are a bit dated the game still looks pretty good. It doesn't have the greatest controls, particularly in the area of combat, but it's far from unplayable. 9/10, would highly recommend. It's pure, unadulterated fun.Now, for a more detailed review.This is the greatest game I have ever played. No, I mean no exaggaration, this is not a joke. This is the best game I've ever had the honor to play.Your story is that you're a newly developed vampire whose sire (creator) is executed right at the beginning, leaving you to fend for yourself as you struggle to survive and prove your worth to the head vampire with only your own wits and the help of a few compassionate souls.The characters in particular stand out sharp in this game. They don't feel as if they only spring into existance when you need them there, or like they'll stop moving and living the minute you leave their occupied area. They feel real enough that you can believe they'll keep doing their own thing even after you're gone. They're all interesting and well-developed, with many of them having their own backstories, and some even having arcs throughout the game.The amount of content in this game is ridiculous. It has seven clans to choose from, which makes for a lot of replayability since character interactions, and even certain missions, will vary based on what clan you are. There's tons of sidequests and little things you can do. There's five endings to discover for yourself. Thanks to a vast character sheet, as well as distinct dialogue options, it's easy to slip into whatever kind of character you want to be: a seductive beauty, a cold-hearted killer, a bloodthirsty maniac-- the possibilities are many. This game is good at making you feel like a powerful monster of the night, surrounded by weak, human prey.And all of that is just with the basic patch. If, like me, you choose to go with the Scrolls patch, (I can't recommend it enough) then there's also the option to set it to Plus, which unlocks even more content. I would suggest beginning with the basic for your first playthrough, and then changing it to plus for another playthrough later on. That way you can get a close feel for how the vanilla game works versus how it works when modded slightly.I would also advise that you leave one particular clan, Malkavian, for last. Malkavians are, by far, the most fun clan to play; however, because they are future-seers they will frequently spoil upcoming events in the game, so definitely save them for your final run.Overall, I can't praise this game highly enough, nor recommend it enough. It's well worth full price.

content:
er 28, 2014
												Pros: Fantastic Storytelling, perhaps the game's strongest element. Plenty of options for characters: Strong, Charismatic, Deadly; however you'd like to play, there's a way to do it. A plethora of memorable characters, backed with Excellent voice acting. An engaging plot, with plenty of sidequests: At least 30 hours of content. Unique character development that adheres to White Wolf's game system. Cons: Combat is sketchy. Those looking for a beat-em-up or a FPS will be dissapointed.  The endgame involves a lot of combat, and may be dissapointing for relatively pacifist players. Also, see above. The out of box product is rather buggy, and even the official patched and plus patched versions can have memory leak issues. Save early, and save often.If you get this game (and you should, believe me) Be sure to install either the unofficial patch, which fixes a lot of inherent issues with the game, or the plus patch, which restores deleted content and improves existing content for smoother gameplay. As is, the game includes the 1.2 official patch Patch 9.2 [forums.planetvampire.com]Being one of the finest RPGs out there in the sense that it adheres to Role-Playing,  Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines  Is a must for anyone who considers themselves a fan of RPGs. It has its flaws, yes, but it's a shining example of what interactive roleplaying can and should look like. TL;DR I give it 9/10. Install the unofficial patch.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2013
												This game is a buried gem. Activision, as per their hitleristic standards, rushed this game into release about halfway through the development. The result is somewhat painful as far as bugs and glitches go. For me, the game wouldn't even start on its own, and when I initially tried to play it, I uninstalled and felt regret for buying it on my boyfriend's recommendation.A few months afterwards, I installed it again while I had a craving for RPGs. Here's the single key to enjoying this game: go and download the unofficial patch, and make sure to select the patch plus during the installation process. A large amount of the game's content is in unactivated code. The patch is regularly updated - the most recent update was this year, last I checked - which fixes all of the game breaking bugs and readds content that wasn't quite finished or activated.The game? Great. The lore is excellent, which most of anyone who has experience with the Old World of Darkness universe would know. Even if you're not, the game is a great introduction. I wasn't a huge expert before I started playing, but a few hours in, I pulled up the wiki and simply started reading. The writing is quality. The characters are memorable, and it's hard not to feel about them; usually, if they're not Beckett or Jack, that feeling is indescribable loathing. The quests are so interesting, you feel a need to go out and find all of the ones avaliable. The environment offers many areas to explore and makes you want to explore them.The only two things I would say aren't perfect about the game are the graphics and the combat. The graphics, naturally, are as dated as the game, and they haven't aged well. I honestly enjoy them because sometimes they're literally laughable. The combat is charmingly schizophrenic, in that you're never quite sure what you're doing, nor what you should be doing, but gosh dang if the results aren't fun. The combat difficulty jerks up and down with little in game conceivable reason, and initially I was confused, but then I realized that the difficulty wasn't based on game mechanics. It's based on lore. If the game makes you fight vampire hunters, no matter at what point you're at in the game, the fight's going to be very hard because vampire hunters in the Old World of Darkness are damned near impossible to kill. It's a great game, and I think that if lore, missions, writing, and plots are your thing, you should play it. However, don't buy it. Pirate it. A larger company - I think it was Bioware - bought the company that made it and fired everyone who worked on it. Your money would be spent paying the people who ruined the chance of a second game.

												This game is amazing... buggy as hell, but amazing nonethelessa fine example of FPS and RPG mixture done right in a non-Borderlands way (I do love Borderlands, by the way)the story develops really well, as it should in an RPG, and it gives you a play-style totally unique to your senses, You like to play sneaky and talk your way through things? Good, have funYou like bashing skulls and punching down your way through the game? Good as well, have funYou are just a madman wanting to shout a little nonsense into a nonsensical world? You will need to find the patch.Moving to the more detailed review...The intial attempts you may make to load the game could end in heartbreak, as the game possesses a bug which prevents you, or at least prevented me, from playing the game without downloading a key patch. You also have the option to set everything yourself, if the guided version did not set things to your pleasure.And then you get to the story, and that... Well, it's hardly my place to spoil it, especially with it's numbers of little twists and hidden reprocussions.You should play it if you really want to find out.

content:
y 24, 2016
												This game sat in my wishlist for a long time before I decided to play it.  My main concern was that I couldn't be impartial.  I love the World of Darkness games, and was seriously worried that despite the many recommendations this game has recieved, I couldn't help but be disappointed.I was not disappointed.Truely, I felt as if I were in the World of Darkness.  The game is a little crowded with WoD lore, but it was fun to see a little bit of everything from hunters to hengeyokai.  The leveling system is almost straight out of the WoD role playing system, which made it easy for me to know what was going on right away.The game's controls never got in the way of gameplay, but sometimes the camera would get a bit confused when crawling through sewage tunnels.  It was all worth it though.  The first time I let loose with Celerity 5 in a room full of ninjas, all was forgiven.I've seen a lot of mention of issues getting the game to run well on Windows 7, but I had no real trouble.  I did get the "not enough RAM" error, but going in and changing the compatibility to XPsp2 fixed that right away.All in all, this is a fun action RPG.  While some of the programming shows it's age, the gameplay has aged very well.  I feel that most people will find this game enjoyable, but if you are a World of Darkness RPG series fan, then Bloodlines is absolutely not to be missed.

content:
er 4, 2013
												This game is a buried gem. Activision, as per their hitleristic standards, rushed this game into release about halfway through the development. The result is somewhat painful as far as bugs and glitches go. For me, the game wouldn't even start on its own, and when I initially tried to play it, I uninstalled and felt regret for buying it on my boyfriend's recommendation.A few months afterwards, I installed it again while I had a craving for RPGs. Here's the single key to enjoying this game: go and download the unofficial patch, and make sure to select the patch plus during the installation process. A large amount of the game's content is in unactivated code. The patch is regularly updated - the most recent update was this year, last I checked - which fixes all of the game breaking bugs and readds content that wasn't quite finished or activated.The game? Great. The lore is excellent, which most of anyone who has experience with the Old World of Darkness universe would know. Even if you're not, the game is a great introduction. I wasn't a huge expert before I started playing, but a few hours in, I pulled up the wiki and simply started reading. The writing is quality. The characters are memorable, and it's hard not to feel about them; usually, if they're not Beckett or Jack, that feeling is indescribable loathing. The quests are so interesting, you feel a need to go out and find all of the ones avaliable. The environment offers many areas to explore and makes you want to explore them.The only two things I would say aren't perfect about the game are the graphics and the combat. The graphics, naturally, are as dated as the game, and they haven't aged well. I honestly enjoy them because sometimes they're literally laughable. The combat is charmingly schizophrenic, in that you're never quite sure what you're doing, nor what you should be doing, but gosh dang if the results aren't fun. The combat difficulty jerks up and down with little in game conceivable reason, and initially I was confused, but then I realized that the difficulty wasn't based on game mechanics. It's based on lore. If the game makes you fight vampire hunters, no matter at what point you're at in the game, the fight's going to be very hard because vampire hunters in the Old World of Darkness are damned near impossible to kill. It's a great game, and I think that if lore, missions, writing, and plots are your thing, you should play it. However, don't buy it. Pirate it. A larger company - I think it was Bioware - bought the company that made it and fired everyone who worked on it. Your money would be spent paying the people who ruined the chance of a second game.

content:
ber 24, 2014
												Pros:-one of the few fully fledged RPGs to feature vampires (and I'm not even a vampire fan)-interesting twist on the vampires - 7 playable clans, each with their own strengths and weaknesses-nonlinear gameplay - sneak around without being seen or slaughter everyone with a gun-diverse 'disciplines' (basically supernatural powers) - invisibility, charm, induce insanity and more-decent dialogue system-good plot with ingenious quests-strong cast of characters-can be witty at times, playing with stereotypes and such-length - it probably took me around 30+ hours to finish, including most of the subquests (don't mind the hours on record, I often play in offline mode)Cons:-the graphics (that is to be expected from a game released in 2004) - clipping issues are unfortunately quite common-difficulty spikes - very easy at first, can be frustrating at the end depending on what weapons you're using-lackluster and unbalanced combat system - upgrading your melee comabt skills will only increase the damage you deal, the movesets and attack speed remain the same (or improve just slightly); there is also no good reason to choose unarmed combat over melee weapons-hubs offer relatively little to do once the sidequests are finished (justified in that you only ever walk the streets at night)-buggy (be sure to install unoffical patches)-the inventory can be messy-price - about 20 bucks for a ten-year-old game that isn't even a cult classic (albeit, for what it is - a very decent RPG, perhaps it should be)My rating: 7.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2016
												Alright, for real though, this is a game that has aged very well. It was a golden RPG for 2004, and today is still Golden. With Troika dead, and before Paradox bought out the rights to White Wolf and WOD, CCP didn't do crap with this series including updates, letting other people remaster it, etc. Luckily this game still has a somewhat active, but small, community, and came out with amazing patches even after a decade of death and silence. There was a project to remake/remaster the game called Project Vaulderie, but unfortunately it got shut down by CCP even though CCP had been doing nothing besides working on Eve Online. The best:-The music is A1. Introduced me to some good gothic metal bands, and the soundtracks for a lot of the hubs are very pleasing. -The dialogue is hilarious most of the time, and it changes depending on what clan you are. -While there was some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting, there was also a lot of good voice acting from well known voice actors.-Clans: There are several you get to choose from, each one has its own special abilities, appearance, and ways you run through the game. -There is no leveling up, you gain experience points and then assign those earned experience points to certain skills you want to increase, which is a simple and nice. -Kind of has it's own karma system to put it basically, you kill innocents, you lose humanity, you lose all your humanity, you go into a frenzy which isn't always the prettiest. So most of the time you have to be conscious of your actions.-The atmosphere was greatly crafted; to be a dark gothic setting. Everything is eerie, not especially scary, but eerie and dark really no matter where you are. -You get to dance like a maniac.-You get paid good for a lot of quests.-A ♥♥♥♥♥ON of lore.The Bad: A lot of this can be excused because of the time it was released, but still mentioning,-The map is absolutely tiny. There are only 4 hubs you can go to, which all are pretty damn small and will take you like 10 minutes to run through all the buildings. -The bugs. Of course, this has to do with the state it was released in, problems with the devs and Valve, etc. But if you don't install the patch that was wonderfully made by fans, then you're going to have a hard time playing because this game is bug heaven.-A lot of the NPCs are the same, there's probably like 5-7 differen't types of NPCS in one city, with 3-4 repeats. -The AI is awful. You can have a decent sneak level and be crouching in front of a group of cops that are on a hunt for you and they wouldn't see you. -The game is fairly short. I think the first time I played this I completed the main and side quests within at least 14 hours. -You don't really get a choice in who you side with. Throughout the game, you are working for LaCroix no matter if you don't like him, but at the end you do indeed get a decision. -You can't really replay this game much differently than a last playthrough mainly because in terms of storyline, there isn't too much you can choose differently, besides minor decisions.-It really doesn't show too much or hint at the enormous amount of lore the WOD and VtM series has. The first time I played this I had no idea that there was a crap ton of books belonging to this series. But luckily, once I found out, I bought all of them. -Because the environment is small and all the work went into the quests, you really can't do much in terms of just exploring. There's not much to interact with. -LOOT. There is rarely any loot throughout the entire game. Which any loot you find is sold for dirt cheap and you get barely any $$$. Overall, a lot of the flaws of this game I can look past because of the age. Lets all hope Paradox does a good job dealing with this series, because it can either go absolutely horribly or incredibly wonderful. And lets hope they don't make a MMO.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2014
Greater than the sum of its parts; an understatement.On the hunt for another game that plays like Deus Ex (open world, many ways to complete tasks, stealth is almost always an option, etc.),  I fell onto this game.  And I'm both happy and sad about it.  HappyThis game is fun, engrossing, interesting and at times a little creepy.  The setting, SoCal, becomes as much a character as any of the off the wall kindred or kine you meet.  To me, I can't get enough open world games set in present day cities, and this has to be one of the more quirky and shady settings that I've played in recent years. The gameplay isn't as polished as a game like Deus Ex, but not many games are.  If you get past the dated graphics / character design and the not-so-great combat mechanics, you'll be able to enjoy a big world that has a lot to offer, filled with funny and odd characters throughout.It's one of those games that after you beat it, you look forward to the next play through a year down the road.  There are a handful of different clans to play as (which can really change the way you play), but as most people suggest, save the Malkavian clan for your 2nd play through for when you already understand the story.SadAfter you get into the game, learning the basics of the Lore that VtmB has developed over the years, you're bound to want more.  And I want so much more.  This game couldn't be big enough.  I want more chapters, more missions, more locations to explore.  More dangerous encounters.  Hell, take this engine to New York or Chicago or London.  Tell more stories using the already rich World of Darkness universe.The huge problem with all this is that there hasn't been another video game in the Vampire: The Masquerade (or even World of Darkness) universe since this game; 2004.  With so much dense material to create a story with, it's surprising that it hasn't happened.  I'm not sure I would've been interested in the MMO that got canceled earlier this year, but it would've been better than nothing.TL;DR - If you want a game that you can take your time exploring, a game that gives you the freedom to go about completing parts of the story the way you want, and don't mind Vampires as a means of telling a story, then please, get this game.Warning:  Patch this game with the unoffical patch.  It may be a annoying, but it's necessary.

content:
r 27, 2013
												One of the most immersive and unique RPGs you will ever find. Imagine if you take the action, skills, moral choises and decisions from games like Deus Ex and Fallout 3, and combine that aspect with a modern world secret vampire society set in the midst of Hollywood - Los Angeles. Then you have the recipe that is Vamire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.As a newly turned vampire you are off to a rocky start. You begin to unravel ancient mysteries and conspiracies within the society itself. Many clans are at war with eachother, and it's up to you to decide which sides to take. You can either try to resolve things through diplomatic efforts to stay in touch with your human side as much as possible, or go the more animalistic way of violence and murder. But beware, everything you do may have serious consequences!

												Ok yeah so the game is old. And it shows. And it's pretty janky and buggy and needs a bit of patching to run smoothly (crash to desktop on boot, anyone?) It's pretty authentic to the hard-copy pen and paper (and LARP) RPG system which it is based on, so if you're a fan of the tabletop/larp, you should get a kick out of this!It's a little treasure of a game, beloved by its fans, and honestly if you can look past the dated appearance (I personally find it rather charming) and deal with the occasional bugs (seriously, PLEASE check the forums for this game if you pick it up and download the unofficial patch) you should have a pretty good time.Also vampires. :)

Details are in the review.(spoken in a dark macho manly voice)"The time is 12:30am or something, i dunno i can't read the time, everyone is trying to mind their own buisness and telling me to ♥♥♥♥ off because i keep getting way too close to them. I'm given another bazillionth task to retrieve some ♥♥♥♥ that will 'definetly' not backfire by some girl i obviously can tell that has dual personalities, but for some strange fate i'm the only one that notices but can't say so because the writers, uhhh i mean God thought i have a perception of a seven year old and gave me a speech impared stroke." "I'm still not able to date that girl at the bar without being shuned so hard that i slam through a brick wall, why must i be given the curse of being able to defend myself against an entire army of thugs, and generally being badass at everything else, EXCEPT TALKIING LIKE A NORMAL PERSON TO A GIRL! Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ dating women who think socially awkward men are 'cute', this is how i became a vampire in the first place."This is a generalization on my thoughts in "Vampire: the masquerade-Bloodlines". I played through the game as a  combat hardened vampire with the dating capability of a five year old, and ended the game as a combat hardened Vampire with the dating capability of an eight year old. So thats 1,000 bodies piled up in one night, and 0 women shaged blood sucked through what was supposed to be shagging in a lifetime. But  everything else was A ok, the story was fantastic, the characters were likeable, and the combat was riged but interesting enough to be worthy of a Bethesda RPG. But beating a dead horse five or eight times is not enough, noooo you want to eviserate it and smear the entestines all over yourself. You deffinetly don't want to be affiliated with something like that, so im gona help you look like you do by framing you and calling the cops on you. For now why don't you read the rest of this review while i make sure that your into snuff films.gameplayIf your eyes were too lazy to read the description of the game, you play as a vampire in the modern world. But the game dosn't want to be that kind of game, like the recent fallout game, it want's to be unique and engaging like a hetrosexual. You have your penalties, your overbearing number of skills to track, your journal, blood because your a vampire obviously and your soon to be overburdened inventory. if thats hard to keep track of, pray to God that the police won't arrest you, if not continue reading.Then we got the combat, what about it, like a bethesda RPG, clunky, unpolished but original enough to keep you interested. wacking people sends them flying and slaming against a wall if there is one, and shooting people is as interesting as the new call of duty, the same as every call of duty game. Then theres your supernatural skills, because vampire, and that the affect is what race of vampire you are, like a hetrosexual. Theres a dozen different races, but on my first run i played as a carniverous hippy with Bob Marly enthusiast hair.But where it really shines like a flash bang going off in your eyes is the dialouge. Almost everyone in the game has profesional voice acting (except for the same looking security guards) and have facial animations of melted chocolate being forcefully poured down your throat. The protagonist (yourself dumbass) even has great dialouge that made me actually feel about the scenarios the game passes to me on a silver platter, which looks to me was  suppost to be a golden platter.atmosphereThe world is dark, scary and sleazy like Detroit, probably is inspired by real world Detroit. The game almost looks believable enough to be a real city with bumbs walking around in the dozens and the looks of what was suppost to be a city with imbition is strife with poverty. Hope and kindness is a rare comodity, and even if its not impossible to be nice, conflicting consequences force youto chose between human, or monster. Even the game has a moral meter but instead of getting to look bad, the more evil you are the likelier you are to have no control over you character while they go on a rampage, im serious.But underneath that exterior lies a society of, you already know what it is. The world of the dead always changes the tone of being in a normal place, to being in somewhere where you are powerless. you'll be one minute fighting thugs in the dozens while some will try to flee in terror, then you'll be in a haunted mansion or a house of a crazed vampire, making you sick and spooked at the same time, it actually works very well.Everything from lighting to texture work makes this a believable place, almost at the same levels as 'Deus ex'.negativesBUGS, bugs everyhere even if you start it throws at you a '15 gb of space required' prompt that throws you out like a bouncer at a strip club. Fortunatly i have a solution here[www.patches-scrolls.com]. even if you get that to work your still going to run into problems, like asanine enemy locations and game braking bugs. a noticable one is the CARGO SHIP LEVEL. I see cops everywhere, i sneak past them to investigate something, i try to escape but i don't know how to without killing the guards blocking my escape route and i can't kill anyone. You know what the solution was,  NO CLIP. I had to use it to pass through that level because i tried every solution to get out without getting spotted by the 'highly trained officers' who shoot on site, because making advance ai is hard.conclusionThis game has fantasticly told story with slightly dogy but engaging combat with loads of bugs, but you know what it is. An unfinished masterpeace because the developers were on a tight schedual and tried to cram everything in a reasonably long game. It works for the most part and optimization is great, its a shame that it has so many bugs that would scare alot of players away. I recommend this if you like decent RPG's and don't mind cheating a little.The police are probably there already and your thinking of ways to kill me, well i get alot of death threats so im a popular guy .Ill be in hiding while you plan your escape route, even though i am most likely to get assasinated by the many secret agencies and lives of people worthy enough for a protagonist of a John Woo film.

content:
y 25
												Vampire the Masquerade, though an old game, is a pretty good game for its time. The story is gripping and exciting, causing me to have some sleeplees nights trying to complete the many missions in the game. It also involves a world filled with werewolves, humans and demons living together in adelicate balance of survival and peace.The story goes like this. When you were bitten by a vampire. you became one. A clan leader took you under his arm and ordered you to perform many missions. Without giving away too much of the story, you will eventually come across three main factions, each with its own ideals and belief. Your decisions in the game will eventually lead to an outcome favourable to one of the faction.The controls are average. The first 10 hours was great. However, at the later stages, the game becomes repetitive as you travel to and fro from your apartment just because of the 'emails'. You will also encounter some bugs but these can be solved by reloading the game. The graphics are really dated but viewable.Game satisfaction is 76%.

ry 21, 2014
												LOVE this game.It look old and it's a bit janky (particularly combat using firearms, melee is must more rewarding) but the world is amazingly well constructed and highly immersive.This is a world you can get lost in with multiple play style options and great ways to have a completely different experience. If you've already played through and want something different picking a different clan can give open up options and pathways that you previously couldn't have found. Great examples of this are the Nosfertu which prevent you from being seen by human without incurring penalty making you spend the game learning the under paths of the hub areas and the Malkvians who, being insane, replace all of your dialogue options with entertaining non-sequiturs and giving different dialogue from NPC (usually remarking that you're insane).Just make sure you get the unofficial patch which fixes a range of issues and greatly improves the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 12
												Really, I don't see the need even to review: the game speaks for itself even all these years later. As I write this VTMB is 13 years old and yet it has stood the test of time as being one of the greatest games ever, the sort of a game whose mere mention on a forum can convince *someone* to reinstall it. It's a damn shame Troika went under, CCP cancelled the MMO, and that it was overshadowed by HL2 as they both used the same engine and wanted Half Life out earlier (frankly idgaf about GabeN releasing HL3 or not but if only a new World of Darkness game...) But, then again, Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could just be fated to be one of those games where no studio is ever going to own up to the original. To me, it is like the StarCraft of modern RPGs, where no matter how hard they try all the new material would just be crappy DLCs and an underwhelming experience lacking the true love that went into the first.The good:Painstakingly recreated the original gothic-punk noir atmosphere with the right balance of humor and in-jokes (much akin to the original Fallout games and why Fallout 3 is ridiculed by old fans) and perfect atmosphere. For anyone who's ever been a fan of what White Wolf made with PnP and their novels/source materials, this is great, and serves as an excellent primer and introduction for those that haven't. The soundtrack is awesome. Also very well done for helping set the tone of the whole game.Mood in general is very grimdark in the tragic sense--you get less the feel of "whoa superpowers" and more the grinding tragedy where existentialism may well be the less angsty and horrid option than the ancient being(s) being very plausibly real, with you as ultimately a set piece no matter how bad you think you are (often literally).The storytelling and character interactions. Just superb writing.Replayability: almost every single person to play this game has gone through at least twice, three times being the average. The replay value is possibly the best I've ever seen for a game that actually follows a semi-linear story. Different clans, dialogue options, and playstyles, with the option of multiple endings means you're likely to only see at most 2/3 of the game on your first play through no matter what you do--and that's just the storyline(s). In terms of disciplines (abilities and spells) and various playstyles, one playthrough is probably 1/4 the content. Make sure Malkavians are one of your runs.The Bad:Certain stats are all but useless and things don't translate as well from the PnP. Most common example is loss of humanity, which doesn't affect a whole lot in the game and is fairly easy to replenish which is not like the original content at all. Still, what is lost in translation is probably unnoticeable to anyone not familiar with the setting. The only noticeable parts are things like Seduction which is an almost entirely useless stat.The combat system. It's not actually as horrible as I thought at first especially compared to KoTOR, but it's still pretty bad, although use of firearms is decent enough and for its time isn't really that bad. Besides, if you're looking for a hack and slash this game isn't for you. The main reason is due toBugs. The game wasn't polished at release so needs a patch. My very first run through had a Kuei Jin stuck in mid air as I slashed him helplessly. Most bugs have been fixed otherwise.Lastly it has had a fairly dedicated community including people from the actual project still working on it after release just out of dedication and love for the game, which in its own right should tell you something.10/10 will probably play again after 3 solid runs

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 6, 2016
												The world Troika built is fantastic, and absolutely oozing with the kind of atmosphere you want in a Vampire RPG. At one point in the game, you'll appear in a room in Santa Monica. I personally sat there for like an hour just listening to the news on the tv, and then listening to Deb of Night on the radio. it's the kind of thing that really brings the game to life. I tuned in every so often to check if there were any new stories. There's also a lot of really memorable characters in Vampire: The Masquerade. All of whom are wonderful to meet, good, evil, or in between. I really liked the setting as well, the game world you get to explore has a really interesting aesthetic that channels gothic horror. From Santa Monica to Chinatown, all the locations have a wonderful look to them. Some with a run-down 80s aesthetic to them that reminds me of The Terminator (1984) and Escape From New York. The asian locations feel like something out of a John Woo movie. They're all great. A lot of the businesses and buildings have really interesting or funny names too, that I just love. The OST is mainly different genres of rock, and is pretty cool, I definetly enjoyed it as well. That's not to say that it is without problems though. While the characters are all mostly well written, and well voiced, a lot of the voices seem to suffer from some audio issues, like some characters randomly talking way too quietly, or sometimes seeming to be talking into a tin can. The character progression isn't stellar either. You only gain experience from completing quests and objectives, and instead of levels, you directly use experience to purchase points in various skills and abilities. Which doesn't sound all that bad, but you don't get to use a skill point that often, and most the changes are negligible. Another thing annoyed me was doors. Walking through doors is a pain. You have to wait for the door to open completely, and it opens very slowly. If you try to go through while it's opening, you'll get stuck in the door way. The combat in this game is action based, and isn't that good either. In fact you'll probably try to avoid it in your playthrough using stealth and the social mechanics. This game is very bittersweet, on one hand the setting is really amazing, and the characters and places in this game are lovely. On the other, Troika being forced to publish the game before it was finished makes it suffer from bugs that make it unplayable (Unless you have Wesp5's Unofficial Patch), and lack of content. It seems like the city zones could have potentially been bigger and better, if Troika had enough time. As they are, they're still great, but in the back of your mind you won't be able to help thinking what could have been, with more npcs wandering about, more places to visit, and more to do. Do I recommend this game? Yes. Even with all its problems, I'd still say that it is an absolute classic and there isn't really another game like it.

content:
, 2014
												This game cannot be compared to other games of the same ilk, and it truly saddens me that the company that made it went under, This game brings you on a story following a young man or woman forced to turn into a vampire and his/her following adventure. Now I don't wish to spoil too much of them game but I will say it lets you choose between seven different playble clans each with their own inherent powers and personalities and even more clans that you see in the world. The mthical creatures in this game aren't cookie cutter definitons and each has its own uniqueness that adds character to the game. The game plays a mixture of rpg elements, such as getting points to add to skills of your choice, getting and saving humanity so that you don't turn more beast than man, and following the masquerade, a set of rules to follow so you dont bring unwanted attention to the vampires. The game also employs first and third person aspects; in first person you get to control the gunplay and you will be spending most of your time looking this way, but in third person you can control your melee aspects which are done extraordinarily well. As in most rpg games you have an inventory in which to keep you weapons, cash, artifacts and other miscellaneous objects in,To say this game is good is an understatement and I still beat myself up for not playing it sooner, and the game only gets better with mods. I am giving this game 9.5/10. Play this game asap.
