content:
3, 2014
												One of the best game i have ever played. Bloodlines features every night creature we know and love into one good RPG. Story is really cool and makes you want to move forward. You were bitten and turned, now you discover the underground world of vampires and need to learn how to be one of them. The game have a lot of interesting NPCs and characters for you to interact or feed if you so wish. Has a compelling vampire lore built that does not sound stupid or untrue. Combat is real time but based on stats (weapon damage + your skills). You have some vampire powers also to use. Boss fights can be a drag, but are not really that bad. You also have a lot of choices and paths to take. You can almost always choose to go peacefull, stealth or all out warfare (depends on skills). Some missions are scary (especially the mansion one, you will know what i am talking about after you played it) and can range from the basic deliver this in there to complex and engaging storylines.From the start you can choose your race and some features. Add some points in skills you desire. You will also visit different cities and locations.Warning: The game have a memory problem, meaning if you have more then 2gb memory ram, you will need to download the unofficial patch, which fixes the problem and many others, so i would recommend it even if you can run it vanilla.The game is fun and fresh, i would recommend it for anyone that likes RPGs and long conversations and choices ala Mass Effect.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2011
												Seriously a gaming milestone, one of the best games I have ever played. Well made and full of character and intrigue it also features the most frightening sequence I have ever experienced in movie or game format to a point where many people opt to skip the section via the console due to its nature (one could argue if you have played through it once you find it more annoying than scary). It has a lot of great writing and acting in it and the downsides to the game are that it was released before Half-Life 2 and as such valve didn't let them use the fully optimized version of the source engine which led to a lot of bugs. Bloodlines was hurried near the end of production as Troika was going out of business and the combat slog toward the end of the game reflects that. Several people continued to work on the game without pay just to get it as finished as it could be. A fan patch might be necessary for you to fully enjoy this free of some odd bugs but you do yourself a disservice missing out.

content:
3, 2014
												I only briefly played the tabletop RPG of White Wolf's V:TM, and never really got into vampire stuff in general. This game, in particular, is outstanding on its own merits. The side quests, characters, open world - all of it is superb. I know that the development got cut short, so the game that got released initially was buggy and incomplete. I can't imagine what this game could have been, but it has been patched by the community as well as the developer itself before they went out of business, but this game is incredible. Easily one of the best, most realized game worlds I've ever played in.

content:
0, 2011
												This game pretty much makes up for every one of its shortcomings, and there are plenty, through pure style. There are some fantastic fan mods that even out the rough edges, but even unmodded this is one of the most immersive games out there, one that throws you into its world and lets you explore its darkest reaches. Rather than excessive exposition, it lets you discover the ins and outs of the underground vampire society yourself, much as an outsider like the player character would have to do. It has a fantastic amount of player choice, and a genuinely good storyline to follow, however you choose to play. Many of the core mechanics are pretty sloppy, and the various skills are terribly balanced. Not to mention an excess of bugs can impede your progress. But if you can ignore, or mod out these issues, you'll find it's the perfect vampire game. Just as the Arkham games make you feel like you really are Batman, this makes you really feel like a vampire. And makes vampires cool again in the process.(As usual, ignore my low recorded playtime, as I've already played my non-steam version multiple times.)

												The atmosphere in this game is unmatched. I have vivid memories of walking around in-game Los Angeles, taking in the night-time view and looking up at the sky for longer than I care to admit. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
												One of the hardest parts of writing any good review comes from writing the review itself. Every person has their own appeal, games they like and dislike, and reasons for those likes and dislikes. Not every game a reviewer will play will conform to those likes or dislikes, and a review must still compose himself and present a fair and balanced review in spite of his personal thoughts. I bring this up because it is very difficult to talk about Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (hereafter referred to simply as ‘Vampire') without delving into the subjective elements it presents without sucking all the emotion and personality from the review and transforming it into a technical overview of the game itself. As such, I have divided this game up into two sections, an objective and a subjective one. But first an overview of the game itself;In Vampire you play as a young person living in L.A. who has recently been transformed into one of the undead. Upon your indoctrination you quickly come to discover that the vampire society needs to be very secretive about how they act so as to keep the public unaware of their actions. Before long, though a sarcophagus which may or may not house the remains of a very ancient and very powerful vampire is uncovered and the various vampire clans in the city all begin a secret war of cloak and dagger tactics, each trying to recover the sarcophagus and its contents or deny them to others for themselves, all while trying to keep their very existence secretive from humans.Firstly, for the objective. The game is VERY well designed and it shows in its game mechanics. Serving as a action RPG with elements of The Elder Scrolls (except less open, confining the player to four primary districts that are fairly small and multiple dungeons) it is solid right from the get-go. From the beginning you are forced to select one of a series of vampire clans, each offering its own unique set of bonuses, abilities, and disadvantages that will end up shaping how you play. I, personally, ended up going with Clan Ventrue which focuses a lot on persuasion, but can't feed off of animals and can only feed reliably on upper-class humans. Someone else may end up with Nosferatu which can't raise their appearance at all and has to avoid being seen at all by humans for example.The gameplay itself is fairly solid with most of the controls being very tight and having almost no real problems beyond a few glitches (which I will cover later) which I can't blame on the controls. One of the interesting things is that, instead of leveling up stats like strength and such, the player instead levels up various skills and abilities which, in turn, affect stats. This can cause for some very interesting outcomes where a character may choose to level up a skill they don't intend to use at all to bolster another skill which they do, in fact, use and results both in a large amount of flexibility and interesting builds as well as a drive to experiment around and see what else can be done.Another interesting thing is that players do not gain experience from killing enemies in the slightest, but rather from quest completion. This puts an added drive to complete even simple sidequests as the added experience is the only way to make your character stronger.Lastly, there are two special meters that will need proper attention. The Humanity meter and the Masquerade meter. A large focus of the game is the focus on struggling against the vampire urges and keeping ones self ‘human' despite needing to drink human blood in order to survive. Certain actions can cause players to lose some of their humanity and, as the gauge lowers to 0, it can result in them becoming utterly feral. Meanwhile, keeping the humanity high can result in a weaker vampire who struggles with their new nature. Additionally, keeping ones actions as a vampire secretive is very key and, every time a player is caught being a vampire in public, it costs them on the Masquerade meter. They start with a set amount of chances and, if those chances ever all disappear, game over (going feral wastes a chance). This puts an added focus on keeping ones nature as a vampire truly secret and staying human as going feral at the wrong time on a player who didn't try to keep hidden can cause an outright loss.Visually the game is fairly solid as well. While, sadly, you won't be able to delve too deep into the many complexities of polygon count, it very successfully manages to convey the feeling of the World of Darkness (the world as a vampire sees it). Vampire does its best to drive this home too, but manages to back it up with some solid displays. While they may look a bit dated today, there is a HUGE difference between ‘dated' and ‘bad' and this is most certainly not the latter.There are some problems with the game though. First off it seems to revel in giving vague directions and not giving you anything resembling a quest-marker. While this wouldn't normally be too bad of a thing it is very easy to end up lost and unsure of where to go or who to talk too, especially if you stop playing the game for a week or more and don't remember the location of an important NPC with the lack of a map (aside from some bus-stop signs) driving the annoyance home. But, more overbearingly, is the glitches. There are a LOT in this game, and they are NOT of the minor kind. These are the kind that can destroy a game and leave it unplayable. Hunting down a patch and/or activating the command console may very well be a requirement for this game.And now for the subjective. This is a dark game. A VERY dark game to say the least. The game makes sure to reinforce this with such locations like abandoned hospitals, scummy apartment buildings, sleazy motels, brothels and night clubs galore, and death around every corner. The streets are almost never clean and are littered with trash, bums and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s seem to be the most common ‘professions', and so forth. People looking for a game about sparkling vampires, or even just ‘normal' vampires may find themselves off-put easily. This is a very dark and pessimistic game, and it ended up causing me to rethink about how to score this.To say that this is a bad game simply because it's world is so scummy and grim is shortselling what the game does right. In any other setting where you can count the number of people who are ‘good' on more than one hand this probably would have been an amazing title. However, this game does not hide for even a moment that this is a grim and depressing world. People not looking for this sort of thing specifically can very easily end up becoming disguised and/or offended by it. Even the ending of the game seems to love rubbing in just how dark this world is.As a result, I feel it is VERY important to look into the game before buying it and deciding if you wish to play a game like this. While it can be enthralling for people who revel in its darkness, for those people looking for even the tiniest ray of light and hope, they would be better off searching elsewhere.In summery: while a solid game that is mired by some technical problems, its subjective aspects and story may simply be so off-putting to a player who does not enjoy its dark and grim world as to not make this game recommendable on a whim. If you buy this game, you should know what you're getting into, because this game is in no way shy about tossing you into the shadows.My pricing: For someone looking for a dark game: 15-20 bucks. It's very solid, if a bit dated and dealing with bugs.For someone not: Avoid at all costs. Remember, this is a game where it is possible to lose because you couldn't pretend to be a human being instead of a blood-sucking monster well enough.

content:
ber 20, 2014
												While I've not played any game taking place within the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, I was pleasantly surprised by the attention to detail this game in particular had. It was a unique experience, giving me a more contemporary feel of vampires in modern settings, even ones as ugly as the Nosferatu. Hell, even  finding vampires of Asian descent  was an interesting thing to find out. Not to mention how long the game is and how extensive some maps could be, Bloodlines proved to be an adventure worth finishing. That being said, there were some parts of the game that just felt either...off or just broken. While it didn't detract from the overall experience, they were buggersome to have to deal with. Let's break this down into two lists: Pros and cons.Pros:Intriguing story. The ability to mold your path by the choices you make and the factions you choose to aid make the game replayable quite a few times. Multiple paths. As stated above, you can go a completely different route the next time you play just to see how things would've ended.Playstyles. While some types excel in some fields, you're completely capable of being any build you desire, which is a nice bonus to have when figuring out what you wish to be good at. Unfortunately some builds just don't work as the game progresses, which I'll cover below.Theme and enviroments. The world is pretty well done. I didn't expect source to be capable of this kind of detail, major props to the devs. When you walk into the different maps, the different atmosphere feels refreshing too.Characters. I was impressed by the characters and the people voicing them. They were really aggressive and sold their roles enough to make me wish they had more to say. Honestly, I feel this is the biggest selling point of this game.Cons:Combat. Gotta say, the combat in this did not age well. It just didn't feel very engaging to shoot jerkfaces from a distance, nor was it fun to engage in melee combat against things that could very well kill you. The weapons were fun, sure, but it felt somewhat boring.Builds. You can pidgeon-hole yourself if you do not build your character correctly. If you go mostly charisma, you will melt later on. Buffs don't seem to make much of a difference if you don't focus your points into boosting them, which can either interfere and flatout make your build a mess. Imagine having to fisticuff a boss but doing almost no damage. Argh.Story and ending. While interesting, the story felt like it tossed elements at you without really explaining much. Like  the werewolf attack . And while multiple endings exists, only one is worth bothering for, and even that can strain the nerves.Bugs. There are some game-busting bugs that were never fixed in the official release and either need a third-party tool to fix or flatout cheat to get past some triggers that just do not function anymore, which was a big detractor for me.That said, the game is pretty solid and still fun to play, even today. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking to play a game involving vampires and guns.

content:
ry 5, 2014
												OK, first off, you will most likely need a patch just to run this game. Unfortunately when this game was originally released it was full of bugs & I guess Steam doesn't provide any fixes but don't worry there is a solution. Go to the forum or the website patches-scrolls and install Wesp5's patch version 8.9. This person has done amazing work to not only get this game running but provided many fixes for any in-game bugs. And it's worth the extra bit of time it takes but first off the bad stuff. The first thing you will notice are the outdated graphics but they really are not that bad and you get used to it pretty quick. The worst thing is combat. It's a bit clunky.....actually, it just plain sucks but not so bad that it's unplayable. The thing is VTMB is billed as an RPG & it not only delivers but it may be the best game ever in this aspect if you like getting immersed in an excellent story. There are rules you have to (un)live by & consequences if you don't. Decisions you make early on reflect what happens later. Basically, in a nutshell, it's an RPG that truly allows you to roleplay who you create & that's what makes this game shine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2015
												Despite its quirks (graphical hiccups, repeated NPCs, wonky combat) and the absolute NEED to mod V:tM-B in order to run it on modern systems, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is, hands-down, one of the best RPGs - and possibly the best vampire game - ever made. Simply put, LA does not give two hoots about you, and events are only driven forward when you begin to interfere. Nevermind that vampires have generally fallen out of favor amongst gamers - this is one that should be played through at least once. Lust, hunger, betrayal, and hard decisions - its all here.Expect to die at least a couple of times; the game doesn't pull its punches, and will backhand anyone thinking they're running on rails. The game's world may seem small, but given that the game is over 10 years old now it has quite a bit of space to roam. Maybe not Witcher levels of freedom, but very few of the game's quests are (or really feel like) fetch quests. The things you do change how the game plays, and each Family has their own oddities to them - both good and bad.If there ever was a game that needed a graphical (and gameplay) overhaul, though, it would be this one. The visuals, while striking, are severly dated, and you'll see the same bums/hookers/random people begin to repeat over and over after a while (although it does give the feeling that the city is beginning to mess with your head). As well, the combat system feels severely tacked-on, and while functional, it is almost ALWAYS preferable to go in with a gun rather than a bat or blade, as melee combat suffers the worst. While it only becomes troublesome in a few areas, those can be the places that make one throw the keyboard in disgust. Finally, as mentioned, the game will NOT run unpatched, so picking up an unofficial patch is necessary to run it on a system with a Windows 7 or newer OS (not sure about Vista; it might work, but it definitely doesn't on W7). Attempting to run the game unpatched causes many issues, so don't even think about it.Overall, though, it is worth picking up (especially when it goes on-sale), as it was Troika's last game before they went bankrupt, and while buggy their games have managed to pick up cult classic status over the years. Beyond that, its a damn good convoluted tale featuring the children of the night, and certainly deserves praise for making the player FEEL like they're a bloodsucking monster.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
												What can i say about this game...Imperfect beauty.Even with all the glitches, bugs, and any other annoyence within the game, it is one of the best RPGs i have ever had the pleasure to play. This game straight up toppled Fallout from my list of RPGs i love, and took the spot of number 1.The game itself is low detail, with many bugs (at one point random furniture spawned throughtout certain areas, and if i looked into the sky i would see what looked like the shadows of furniture and people in the sky xD) but the bugs would rarely effect gameplay and since the game saves after ohmost every time you leave a Building you can take a few steps back, if you ever come across a bad bug that really stops you in your tracks. I only ever had one bug that was like this but i didnt even need to load to a previous point cause it was done for me when i was killed by a couch xD(invisible wall kinda deal).Now if you have been reading up on this game you know that it was never really polished off cause of the developers departure from gaming, luckily a rouge developer by the name of wesp5 took it upon himself to create an unofficial patch that rounds off quite a bit and adds in a few things previously unavailable. Now a lot of people can play the game without the patch but i see no reason not to get it since it adds more to the game(just a little bit). Some people are afraid of going outside of steam to fix their games but its not that hard to find a reputable site. I got my patch from http://patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647 and remember to download 9.0 and install it into steam (itll try to install it into a file that dosent exist i.e if you actually had this game on a CD)

It lacks a proper character creation tool for customizing facial details and hairstyles and what not, but that isn't really an issue as most of the pre made characters are mostly spot on. A must buy, especially if it's on sale.

												A great game.  I had never heard of this game until I saw it on sale during Halloween, and then watched a video where Total Biscuit called it one of, if not the best RPG games ever made.  It really is fun.  Choose what bloodline of vampire you are, which gives you some special abilities.  Probably the most fun are the Malkavians, who talk in a very strange way.  It definitely makes for interesting dialogue.  An interesting story, cool combat.  You are a vampire, living in the modern world, in a big city. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 3, 2011
												Troika may not have the best track-record for putting out the most stable games, but they certainly have a handle on excellent writing and storytelling. The unofficial patch takes care of nearly all the bugs and restores additional content that was left out of the retail release. RPG elements are implemented a bit differently than most RPGs, in that xp is only awarded for completing quests, so there's no grinding involved, or even leveling (as xp is used to increase stats). The variety of vampire 'clans' that can be played provide a high replay value, as the dialogue options and events vary depending on which you choose. If you enjoy the subject matter, this is definitely a recommended purchase.

												I mostly love this game for the world created for it, and the stories contained within that world. Besides that, it's got memorable characters, a good soundtrack and can be funny at times, both on purpose and accidentally (keep in mind this was released in '04). Combat gets repetitive pretty quickly, so I suggest trying to kill enemies without being detected to make things a bit more intense. I also suggest to not bother with guns and stick to melee (always collect any dropped weapons though, so you can sell them later). Plenty of sidequests to keep the main narrative from getting boring, great character sheet. I recommend the hell out of this game.

You can play it many different ways unlike some RPG's, you can choose what kind of character you play both roleplay and combat wise. It was a little buggy when it first came out but with the official patch AND the unofficial community patch (which is essential imo) it works like a charm. It's very much a mature RPG that isn't all about elves and dwarves so it's a great change of pace from other games in the genre. Very much recommend if you like RPG's and you can handle a mature game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												If you play RPGs not only for incredible loot and skill tree leveling, but also for the sake of role-playing a character and taking in the atmosphere, this is the game for you. While you do gain experience, and unlock new abilities, the skill tree will be unfamiliar to those not already versed in White Wolf's pen and paper games. Also, there is very little gear, whether dropped or bought and it almost feels scripted. You get to a new place, and get a new weapon or armor, at the same time on every character you make. The only other bad point i'll touch on is the combat system. While it's fun hacking away in melee, and the vampire powers you get to back your fighting skills are top-notch visually and mechanically, if you specialize in guns, expect to have a REALLY hard time until about halfway through the game, even if your ranged skill is high. On top of that, even when your wielding a trusty baseball bat knocking some punk to the floor, you literally have to wait for them to get up to strike again as the hit-boxes don't register when they are prone. But those a few minor annoyances, and really aren't the spirit of the game. You can get through many missions without physical confrontation if you are socially inclined, or can make people magically go insane. The characters you meet all have a story and each one's personality might clash with another or even yourself. It's a great opportunity to really role-play a vampire and a must have for anyone looking for more than a run-through guns blazing type of game.

content:
10, 2012
												Can't beleive I haven't rated this game yet . It's one of my all time favorites.  It has vampire's, it's an RPG ,based off a pnp game, it's got action, guns and swords. What's not to love?  I'd give it a solid 96% rating.  now the bad The graphics while being competitive for today's games (it used source engine)  is looking dated also having switched to a wide screen monitor reccently I noted it has no wide screen resolution support. A bit disapointing considering many games  even older ones from 2002-3 had wide screen support. The game was released in 2004 about 4 months before half life 2 was even out, making it the first comercial game using valve's source engine (though they licensed the engine so this game was not developed by valve) This game is really worth a go for vampire and rpg fans alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2011
												Fair warning: this game is incredibly buggy and you will need to install unofficial patches to get it running stably under Windows 7.The piece of advice I see given to new players most often is that you should not play as a Nosferatu or Malkavian during your first playthrough. In the former's case, you are not allowed to be seen by (let alone interact with) human NPCs, turning the game into one of stealth, and in the latter's case, you are literally insane. There is literally an entire game's worth of dialog written exclusively for Malkavian players.This speaks volumes about the game, I feel. The game can play COMPLETELY different depending on your character and the style of play you choose. Because exp is awarded for completing missions, so it doesn't matter whether you progress through persuasion, stealth, or bashing someone's head in. Nobody plays this game just once.tl;dr it's deus ex with vampires

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2011
												Are the graphics on this dated? Yes. Is it bug-ridden? Sure. It's also one of the most interesting and engaging Action-RPGs written, full stop. The action bits are a bit (ok, very) railsy, but the writing is top notch, helped by solid voice acting, and the story is well paced, with plenty of room for player choice. In fact, people talk about "mortality system" and whatever, but honestly Bloodlines does moral choices better than all the games that attempt it today, and all without a crammed on sidegame.

content:
er 4, 2014
												steam says its too long so i cut the boring part, here comes pt 2...Oh God, what am I doing? All the above is the most dull, uninteresting cr@p You ever read. I want to sell this game to You and not in a Wall Street meeting room way, that would not work. So, change of pace OK? Let's see what is sooo coool about VtMB:1. graphics (partly): did You think a decade ago how well the faces and facial expressions of Alyx or Breen were made? Wait for ol' pirate Jack (he is in the tutorial so You do not have to wait much) and You'll change Your tune.2. music, atmospheric sounds and voice acting: they are superb. I only read about the World of Darkness, but they represent well how I just imagined it.3. writing: those Troika guys really know how to sketch up a completely believable character - with only a few lines of dialogue. The story is also great, the quests varied, entertaining and inspired.4. RPG elements: it seems that the developers tried to contain as much as possible of WoD in one game, 7 playable clans is very much respectable, adds immense replay value and a great number of combinations to achieve Your goals. Character development is seemingly simple but understanding it a bit more deeply may lead to some head scratching. Meaning it is good 8).5. quite a selection of vampiric capabilites which complement Your melée wapons or guns. lots of guns.6. nice selection of occult items which enhace Your capabilities.7. Have you ever wanted to......feed on innocents and baddies alike?...steal others' lifeforce from afar?...have a pretty pet ghoul to feel Yourself the center of the universe?...sell a bubblegum and some blood to an idiot who thinks these will help with his vampirism?...lure girls into a dark alley to... to... suck on their neck?...boil Your enemies blood so they explode?...steal drugs from a hospital for the junkie owner of the local pawnshop?...bring peace to a ghost who haunts an old, abandoned and spooky hotel?...damage invaluable paintings?...get a suitcase from under the nose of not one but two gangs for the local arms dealer?...assassinate a russian mob boss boondock saints style?...send a swarm of insects or bats to destroy Your enemies?...lure an annoying tv personality to the hands of a cannibalistic vamp?...do favors for the boss of the most monstrous vamp clan - for posters with some female in-game characters scantily dressed?...destroy a snotty restaurant's reputation?...move faster than Neo?...get love letters from a centuries old vamp 'exotic' dancer?...kill a score of zombies?...use a bush hook to kill the baddies (and goodies)?...destroy the reputation of a celebrity and drive her into suicide?...help out a plaid skirt japanese schoolgirl with destroying a fish smelling demon?...get a pair of human eyes for an evil little old man?...play a character whose talk even You barely understand? (Play Malkavian! 8)...collect the blood of Your victims into a perversed half-alive creation for later use?...have 5+1 different endings?...then this game might be just for YOU!(How was the sales pitch?)Partly due to its troubled history however the game has its problems. The bugs were well wiped out thanks to community effort but still has minor annoyances. Nothing game breaking but like e. g. when You face a boss, there is some talking and after that You have to reselect Your weapon. Things like that, nothing major.Steam has the latest official version, some of the major bugs were addressed in that but You would probably do Yourself a favor installing one of the community patches:True Patch Gold aims to totally conserve the original gameplay while addressing the bugs.Unofficial Patch has two flavors, the basic patch more or less does the same, though some minor changes were made to the original to make some things more logical. In the expanded 'plus' version (it is one download You decide which to use while installing) however the creators tried to restore and even recreate much content cut from the final game, including places, weapons, abilities, weapons, dialogues, quests etc.If You are a purist and want to experience the original game, True Patch Gold is for You.If You do not mind a few changes but want the original experience, UP basic might be the way to go.If You want to see the game as what it could have become if not for its troubled history, choose UP plus.And please, please do not ask in forums which to choose, the above should be enough information. There is a years long flame war involving the patches, their creators and their supporters. Don't spill oil onto the flame. It is a shame, both are great, took up a lot of time and work, both deserve respect. As a closing, a few notes, hints, advices:- save often. Really. There is a quicksave function, You can have a few, it is nat too hard to press F5 (or whatever).- spend some time studying the character sheet and understand how feats work, what adds to them etc. Don't throw around Your points, there won't be that many.- understand how skill books work so You can get the most of them.- specialize. It might be hard, You'll need some unarmed to feed, also there is a quest which is very hard without celerity discipline or ranged - on the other hand the game seems to push You toward melée.- have spare XP points unspent as many as You can. The amount in later game may go up to 50-60. You never know when You'll need to spend a lot to buy in to a skill that You need to complete a quest to Your satisfaction. You WILL need for example high computers and lockpickig, if You spend all Your hard earned XP on fighting/social skill You will be in trouble with side quests, maybe even main ones. Btw, You might think that the game will throw a lot of XP at You later in the game, it won't. Conserve.- if You are completionist, and Your ego can stand it use a walkthrough, otherwise there will be a lot of saving/loading and running around. You don't know beforehand which solution to a quest will yield the best reward. Dialogues are also unfriendly: if You choose the wrong line You might never get to the option that gives the best option. Also NPCs are rarely very clear concerning their wishes. If they hint that it would be appreciated if You did X quest without bloodshed that means that You SHOULD do it that way for the best reward. They are often not even this clear.- if You want to have all endings as an option in the endgame You have to forget about roleplaying and go for shameless bootlicking and say to all major players what they want to hear, all the time.This is it. Well, not much of a review, but at least it is long 8).PS: If You liked Bloodlines You might also want to try Redemption. Even older and uglier and starts a bit slow, quite different from VtMB but has its good points, a very enjoyable experience. VtMB is available on Steam, VtMR on GOG.com.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												Currently the main game I am playing at the moment. Personally, I am fascinated by vampire lore in general and Troika Game's adaptation of the pen-&-paper-role-playing-game, Vampire: The Masquerade has so far been really entertaining. I have heard that there are unofficial patches and mods for this game that have been developed by fans since unfortunately Troika Games is defunct (The same folks behind the first Fallout game), but I intend to not use any patches for my first play-through, I might in the future however. Some people would turn away from this game because there are some bugs in this game such as uncooperative doors and quest logs that don't always update. To my understanding this game was a bit rushed and was pushed to be released the very same day as Half Life 2 being the first 3rd party developer to use the source engine. So while you play this game just keep in mind, this is a game from 2004 (10 years ago). I am currently playing a Nosferatuean Vampire whose core mechanic is using stealth (google Nosferatu vampire and you will see why), you can choose quite a few different vampires however, such as Ventrue, a high class vampire who uses charm and persuasion which gives you a more diplomatic sense of playing, or a Malkavian vampire who is bat♥♥♥♥ crazy with hilarious dialogue.This is a good game, but don’t get this game for 20$. You can afford to wait, this game frequently is 75% off on steam sales. It will probably be on sale this Winter Steam Sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 3, 2014
												This game has its flaws, mostly technical flaws. In order to make this game function on most computers, you must install a patcher to make the game actually run on your machine. If you make a quick google search, you'll most definitely find the installer. However, underneath all the technical problems, this game is an absolutely great, mostly because of the RPG elements implemented within the game. You start the game by either answering a few questions that affect your character's stats, or you can spec your character yourself. The atmosphere of VTM:B is fantastic. I find the word "immersive" pretty tacky, but that's exactly what the atmosphere feels like. Once you've invested a couple of hours in this game, it'll almost feel like you're in this dark and eerie version of modern day Los Angeles. The quests in this game come in a great variety. And sometimes, you might not be able to access these said quests due to your choices! In this game, your choices have an actual affect on what goes on around you. The game also offers a great deal of replayability. The combat isn't that great, in fact, it's a bit broken to be honest, but if you're a fan of role playing games, you should definitely give this game a try.

Even older and uglier and starts a bit slow, quite different from VtMB but has its good points, a very enjoyable experience. VtMB is available on Steam, VtMR on GOG.com.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 3, 2014
												This game has its flaws, mostly technical flaws. In order to make this game function on most computers, you must install a patcher to make the game actually run on your machine. If you make a quick google search, you'll most definitely find the installer. However, underneath all the technical problems, this game is an absolutely great, mostly because of the RPG elements implemented within the game. You start the game by either answering a few questions that affect your character's stats, or you can spec your character yourself. The atmosphere of VTM:B is fantastic. I find the word "immersive" pretty tacky, but that's exactly what the atmosphere feels like. Once you've invested a couple of hours in this game, it'll almost feel like you're in this dark and eerie version of modern day Los Angeles. The quests in this game come in a great variety. And sometimes, you might not be able to access these said quests due to your choices! In this game, your choices have an actual affect on what goes on around you. The game also offers a great deal of replayability. The combat isn't that great, in fact, it's a bit broken to be honest, but if you're a fan of role playing games, you should definitely give this game a try.

content:
er 5, 2014
												Currently the main game I am playing at the moment. Personally, I am fascinated by vampire lore in general and Troika Game's adaptation of the pen-&-paper-role-playing-game, Vampire: The Masquerade has so far been really entertaining. I have heard that there are unofficial patches and mods for this game that have been developed by fans since unfortunately Troika Games is defunct (The same folks behind the first Fallout game), but I intend to not use any patches for my first play-through, I might in the future however. Some people would turn away from this game because there are some bugs in this game such as uncooperative doors and quest logs that don't always update. To my understanding this game was a bit rushed and was pushed to be released the very same day as Half Life 2 being the first 3rd party developer to use the source engine. So while you play this game just keep in mind, this is a game from 2004 (10 years ago). I am currently playing a Nosferatuean Vampire whose core mechanic is using stealth (google Nosferatu vampire and you will see why), you can choose quite a few different vampires however, such as Ventrue, a high class vampire who uses charm and persuasion which gives you a more diplomatic sense of playing, or a Malkavian vampire who is bat♥♥♥♥ crazy with hilarious dialogue.This is a good game, but don’t get this game for 20$. You can afford to wait, this game frequently is 75% off on steam sales. It will probably be on sale this Winter Steam Sale.

												One of the best games ever made.Good/neutral/evil, stealth, magic ("disiplines"), guns, melee, hand to hand, exploration, different endings and lots and lots of multiple choice, very well-voiced conversations (Fallout 4's female PC for example) make this a true gem of a shooter RPG.The game still holds up today easily. Choose FPS or third, or alternate instantly as you like. XP are not given for kills, but for resolving situations (killing everything that moves is one way of resolving pretty much any situation though, but frequently not the only way). Get it! y 13, 2016
												     To call this game a favorite of mine would be no understatement. While, sure - there are areas that it's lacking (both because of it's original release date AND due to it's rushed completion before release) but such things are easily overlooked when it comes to the genuine, lovable storyline, side quests, and characters. This game is witty and just all around really enjoyable, though maybe not for everyone. It's got a humor similar to what you might find in one of the Saints Row games, but I somehow favor this game over the afformentioned. Storylines a bit more involved, too. Though - be warned. After pouring hours upon hours into the patched version of this game, the ending did feel a little bit rushed, but as to be expected with a game that narrowly made it's deadline.     Overall - I consider this a personal classic, and would recommend it to anyone looking for a nice dark, witty RPG to fill their time. Didn't regret playing.

Unfortunately when this game was originally released it was full of bugs & I guess Steam doesn't provide any fixes but don't worry there is a solution. Basically, in a nutshell, it's an RPG that truly allows you to roleplay who you create & that's what makes this game shine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2014
												While I've not played any game taking place within the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, I was pleasantly surprised by the attention to detail this game in particular had. It was a unique experience, giving me a more contemporary feel of vampires in modern settings, even ones as ugly as the Nosferatu. Hell, even  finding vampires of Asian descent  was an interesting thing to find out. Not to mention how long the game is and how extensive some maps could be, Bloodlines proved to be an adventure worth finishing. That being said, there were some parts of the game that just felt either...off or just broken. While it didn't detract from the overall experience, they were buggersome to have to deal with. Let's break this down into two lists: Pros and cons.Pros:Intriguing story. The ability to mold your path by the choices you make and the factions you choose to aid make the game replayable quite a few times. Multiple paths. As stated above, you can go a completely different route the next time you play just to see how things would've ended.Playstyles. While some types excel in some fields, you're completely capable of being any build you desire, which is a nice bonus to have when figuring out what you wish to be good at. Unfortunately some builds just don't work as the game progresses, which I'll cover below.Theme and enviroments. The world is pretty well done. I didn't expect source to be capable of this kind of detail, major props to the devs. When you walk into the different maps, the different atmosphere feels refreshing too.Characters. I was impressed by the characters and the people voicing them. They were really aggressive and sold their roles enough to make me wish they had more to say. Honestly, I feel this is the biggest selling point of this game.Cons:Combat. Gotta say, the combat in this did not age well. It just didn't feel very engaging to shoot jerkfaces from a distance, nor was it fun to engage in melee combat against things that could very well kill you. The weapons were fun, sure, but it felt somewhat boring.Builds. You can pidgeon-hole yourself if you do not build your character correctly. If you go mostly charisma, you will melt later on. Buffs don't seem to make much of a difference if you don't focus your points into boosting them, which can either interfere and flatout make your build a mess. Imagine having to fisticuff a boss but doing almost no damage. Argh.Story and ending. While interesting, the story felt like it tossed elements at you without really explaining much. Like  the werewolf attack . And while multiple endings exists, only one is worth bothering for, and even that can strain the nerves.Bugs. There are some game-busting bugs that were never fixed in the official release and either need a third-party tool to fix or flatout cheat to get past some triggers that just do not function anymore, which was a big detractor for me.That said, the game is pretty solid and still fun to play, even today. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone looking to play a game involving vampires and guns.

content:
er 23, 2014
												This game is far from perfect, but it is also fantastic. For an old broken game that should NOT have aged well, it has somehow managed to do quite the opposite and be a refreshing and immersive RPG experience. There is a surprising amount of depth and a wide range of options for how to build your character, allowing for new and interesting experiences even through multiple playthoughs. You will meet a variety of characters, most of which are very memorable and leave a lasting impression (even if that impression is that you want to drain them dry on the spot...I'm looking at you, Patty). You will not be impressed by the fighting mechanics, it is janky at best and flatout broken at worst, but you also won't care. The setting, the soundtrack, the NPCs, the simple joy of feeding from unsuspecting humans...it all adds up to something special and fun that you won't regret giving a shot, so just do yourself a favor and buy the hell out of this game.

												This game pretty much makes up for every one of its shortcomings, and there are plenty, through pure style. There are some fantastic fan mods that even out the rough edges, but even unmodded this is one of the most immersive games out there, one that throws you into its world and lets you explore its darkest reaches. Rather than excessive exposition, it lets you discover the ins and outs of the underground vampire society yourself, much as an outsider like the player character would have to do. It has a fantastic amount of player choice, and a genuinely good storyline to follow, however you choose to play. Many of the core mechanics are pretty sloppy, and the various skills are terribly balanced. Not to mention an excess of bugs can impede your progress. But if you can ignore, or mod out these issues, you'll find it's the perfect vampire game. Just as the Arkham games make you feel like you really are Batman, this makes you really feel like a vampire. And makes vampires cool again in the process.(As usual, ignore my low recorded playtime, as I've already played my non-steam version multiple times.)

r 30, 2013
												Hands down the BEST ROLE playing game made to date (2013). And it was made in 2004. Also the best RPG mechanic I've ever played. Makes the systems used in various MMO's and other rpg seem massively inferior and sometimes pitiful. Highlights are: Every character (except yours) is voice acted, and done by professionals. Your dialogue choices are numerous and varied, and based off how you increase your social skills. Every character is really interesting, and all side quests are excellent. All dialogue is very well written.The main story is really good. And the choice of endings is more "branched" then even current rivals, although thats not saying much (Except for Witcher II which holds the crown for choices that  change the entire game and political landscape, and truly stands out in the RPG marketplace). There is plenty of music made by professionals. There are details like news reports and radio shows that progress as you progress thru the game and make mention of things you do. An if you play Malkav you are in for a bonus surprise with regard to that. The whole atmosphere is so darn immersive and well constructed.Multiple clans to play, so the game has at least a couple of repeat play thru's. By my count, minimum of three, since the Nosferatu (stealthy) are quite different, and certainly the Malkavs (totally crazy), and then there is everyone else (they follow more conventional social interaction).Make sure you check out/read up on the community mods for the latest patch (Activision does not bother to fix their own property), and also resolution fixes.

content:
r 20, 2015
												Resurrected as a vampire after your death, you are recruited to assist in an ongoing war of attrition between several vampire clans who vie for control of Los Angeles. Using a combination of stealth, cunning and brute force, only you can ultimately shape the result of the conflict.Famously released in an unfinished state (though several patches and mods have been released that largely fix this), Bloodlines is a flawed yet absolutely captivating gem of a game that takes the stealth-action RPG hybrid gameplay of series such as Deus Ex and Thief, drapes it in a veneer of equal parts Anne Rice sensual horror and goth club sleaze, and ties it all together with an excellent script dripping with lore, mystery, sexuality, and violence. There's plenty of replay value to be had as well thanks to the diverse array of vampire clans one can play as; from the seductive Toreador or traditionalist Ventrue, to the monstrous Nosferatu or gibbering and insane Malkavian. Just be ready to do some patching after you've installed the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												This game is something that is very unfortunate. It has a seriously interesting world, that will imerse you regardless of whether you're a fan of gothic culture or not. It spins a vampire tale that is both interesting and enjoyable at the same time. The plot remains solid and tense up until the 75% mark and then it feels unfortunatly rushed. I ended this story, feeling satisified of the journey but the overal end just left me feeling like alot of choices I made didn't matter. This is of course, due to the game developer being rushed to finish the game on time and highlights of game gems such as this one, are unfortunatly not given the extra attention they deserved.Gameplay is very similar to that of games like Deus Ex. You are allowed to tackle objectives in any way you wish, in fact the game presents you with a series of classes which almost define your playstyle from then on. And this isn't just a minor state boost ethier. Playing as a particular class for example, renders you unable to travel on the streets due to your inability to blend in. The consequence of this is that you spend most of the game in sewers eating rats, but have a massive advantage when it comes to any stealth encounter. This is one of the fantastic game design choices the games makes! Certain vampire classes have advanatges in certain areas. Some are good at meddling with humans, others are better at combat and violence. One class is considered insane, and has an entire dialouge choice to back it up in conversations. Combat can be a little worse for ware, but it isn't unplayable. The broken AI, doesn't tend to put up much of a fight - especially in stealth sections. When you pick your class, you will find it difficult to progress down any other path. Stealth classes, tend to be killed quite easily if you try full frontal combat. Stealth isn't just a one off thing ethier, it is supported by stealth kills, shadow blending etc. Overall, when you play this game - it is very difficult not to appreciate it, for what it could be and for what it is. I find it difficult to discredit the game up to the 75% mark. After that, things are obviously rushed, everything becomes more combat focused and you will find yourself struggling if you didn't pick a combat class. Before that though, is a game that definatly rewards player choice in both story and gameplay. It provide an interesting, immersive gothic world that will delight both those who enjoy vampire culture and those who don't, alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2015
												Despite its quirks (graphical hiccups, repeated NPCs, wonky combat) and the absolute NEED to mod V:tM-B in order to run it on modern systems, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is, hands-down, one of the best RPGs - and possibly the best vampire game - ever made. Simply put, LA does not give two hoots about you, and events are only driven forward when you begin to interfere. Nevermind that vampires have generally fallen out of favor amongst gamers - this is one that should be played through at least once. Lust, hunger, betrayal, and hard decisions - its all here.Expect to die at least a couple of times; the game doesn't pull its punches, and will backhand anyone thinking they're running on rails. The game's world may seem small, but given that the game is over 10 years old now it has quite a bit of space to roam. Maybe not Witcher levels of freedom, but very few of the game's quests are (or really feel like) fetch quests. The things you do change how the game plays, and each Family has their own oddities to them - both good and bad.If there ever was a game that needed a graphical (and gameplay) overhaul, though, it would be this one. The visuals, while striking, are severly dated, and you'll see the same bums/hookers/random people begin to repeat over and over after a while (although it does give the feeling that the city is beginning to mess with your head). As well, the combat system feels severely tacked-on, and while functional, it is almost ALWAYS preferable to go in with a gun rather than a bat or blade, as melee combat suffers the worst. While it only becomes troublesome in a few areas, those can be the places that make one throw the keyboard in disgust. Finally, as mentioned, the game will NOT run unpatched, so picking up an unofficial patch is necessary to run it on a system with a Windows 7 or newer OS (not sure about Vista; it might work, but it definitely doesn't on W7). Attempting to run the game unpatched causes many issues, so don't even think about it.Overall, though, it is worth picking up (especially when it goes on-sale), as it was Troika's last game before they went bankrupt, and while buggy their games have managed to pick up cult classic status over the years. Beyond that, its a damn good convoluted tale featuring the children of the night, and certainly deserves praise for making the player FEEL like they're a bloodsucking monster.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2015
												Every time someone mentions it, someone will reinstall it.This is one of the most enjoyable games you'll ever play. Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines is first person and third person action RPG based of the pen and paper RPG of the same title(Vampire the Masquerade). You play as a fledgling vampire who was spared after your sire was executed, now you have to fight the beast inside you by keeping your humanity and obey the laws of the masquerade.Story 10/10This game has amazing writing. From the get go you got yourself into some vampire politics and have a whole new world around you that you have to discover. There's not only kine and kindred (humans and human like vampires) there are also things like the sabbat, werewolves, vampire hunters, etc. The main vampire government are the Camarilla, but their are also vampire rebels known as the Anarchs. As the story progresses you'll have to pick a side. Beyond the main story there are countless side missions that often have mini stories or side stories to them.Gameplay 9/10It's got a lot of buggy issues to the game but there are several 'unofficial' patches to the game that can help. I can't compare the vanilla game with the patched version because I installed the patch before playing it. But mainly there are various mechanics to the game, from simple combat like shooting and melee attacks, disciplines which are basically spells, you have a blood bar you regenerate from drinking blood, you have a humanity bar you need to keep balanced, and finally the masquerade bar. Knowing the names of the mechanics is one thing, figuring and mastering them is another.The game is very immersive, depending on what clan you are and what you do and say to people effects how you are treated by various characters throughout the game. The game allows you to have your own play style, from sneaking around vents to going guns a blazing, and seducing or threatening people you talk to to get information. There are also the little things that make this game so amusing as well, for example I mercilessly murdered a fat guy at a diner and I heard the sounds of sirens and the police were waiting outside, I also broke into an art gallery and a mission later watched a news reporter talk about that very thing. Great stuff!Music 10/10The music is top notch! Composed by Rik Schaffer & various others, the game has many tracks to fit the mood. From ambient tracks for the streets of LA and haunted hotels to Club tracks by actual bands and slow tracks to strip clubs. I absolutely love it!Over all: 9/10VtMB is an amazing game to have. I personally found it hard to stop playing, and within two and a half days already had 25 hours of play time. Even though I make this sound like a masterpiece it does have it's negatives like the need for a patch to properly work, it gets a bit hard/confusing at times to find stuff or complete objectives, or the fact there's not enough Jeanette(play the game and you'll know what I mean ;P)! ::I almost forgot to mention this game has lots of sexual content, it almost surprised me. So if you're not into that kind of thing or just don't like it in general I would highly consider that a factor before thinking about buying this game::  But this is still something to have, especially if you're into vampires or just Action RPG's in general. So I urge you to check it out!

												This game is in my top 5 list of all time. I would even give this one the 1st spot. It doesn't matter what kind of genre you're into; if you want to get totaly immersed by a game then get this. The atmosphere in this one is unmatched in my opinion. Seriously,in the gaming world there are games and there are experiences. This one belongs to the latter category no doubt about it.

content:
26, 2014
												The atmosphere in this game is unmatched. I have vivid memories of walking around in-game Los Angeles, taking in the night-time view and looking up at the sky for longer than I care to admit. Numerous other locations are also worthy of praise, with the Ocean House Hotel deserving special mention for being one of the scariest experiences I've ever had in a video game.The different vampire clans you can play as provide plenty of replayability, and I've played through this game more times than I can count. In particular, Malkavians and Nosferatu make for the most unique experience.The base game is a bit buggy, so track down the latest version of the unofficial patch before you get started. With this installed I haven't had any issues to speak of.Although the graphics are a bit dated now, this game is the most underrated RPG I've ever played. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPGs, vampires, or simply a good story.

content:
4, 2012
												A staggeringly brilliant game. The story is the darkest and most sophisticated you'll come across in a game, the dialogue is the best I've ever come across in a game, and the Role-Playing elements are brilliantly strong, the amount of options open to you is matched only by Deus Ex. You can clearly see the influence Deus had on Vamp's development, with every mission having several possible methods of completion. While this game is buggy, the fans are still making patches since Trokia sadly went bankrupt after completing this game. You will still experience bugs, and that is the only bad thing about this game, but if you can get past this (and you should) you will find, in my opinion one of the best games ever made. It has a dark sense of humour, and a sophisticated world. Play this game if it's the last thing you do

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
												One of the hardest parts of writing any good review comes from writing the review itself. Every person has their own appeal, games they like and dislike, and reasons for those likes and dislikes. Not every game a reviewer will play will conform to those likes or dislikes, and a review must still compose himself and present a fair and balanced review in spite of his personal thoughts. I bring this up because it is very difficult to talk about Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (hereafter referred to simply as ‘Vampire') without delving into the subjective elements it presents without sucking all the emotion and personality from the review and transforming it into a technical overview of the game itself. As such, I have divided this game up into two sections, an objective and a subjective one. But first an overview of the game itself;In Vampire you play as a young person living in L.A. who has recently been transformed into one of the undead. Upon your indoctrination you quickly come to discover that the vampire society needs to be very secretive about how they act so as to keep the public unaware of their actions. Before long, though a sarcophagus which may or may not house the remains of a very ancient and very powerful vampire is uncovered and the various vampire clans in the city all begin a secret war of cloak and dagger tactics, each trying to recover the sarcophagus and its contents or deny them to others for themselves, all while trying to keep their very existence secretive from humans.Firstly, for the objective. The game is VERY well designed and it shows in its game mechanics. Serving as a action RPG with elements of The Elder Scrolls (except less open, confining the player to four primary districts that are fairly small and multiple dungeons) it is solid right from the get-go. From the beginning you are forced to select one of a series of vampire clans, each offering its own unique set of bonuses, abilities, and disadvantages that will end up shaping how you play. I, personally, ended up going with Clan Ventrue which focuses a lot on persuasion, but can't feed off of animals and can only feed reliably on upper-class humans. Someone else may end up with Nosferatu which can't raise their appearance at all and has to avoid being seen at all by humans for example.The gameplay itself is fairly solid with most of the controls being very tight and having almost no real problems beyond a few glitches (which I will cover later) which I can't blame on the controls. One of the interesting things is that, instead of leveling up stats like strength and such, the player instead levels up various skills and abilities which, in turn, affect stats. This can cause for some very interesting outcomes where a character may choose to level up a skill they don't intend to use at all to bolster another skill which they do, in fact, use and results both in a large amount of flexibility and interesting builds as well as a drive to experiment around and see what else can be done.Another interesting thing is that players do not gain experience from killing enemies in the slightest, but rather from quest completion. This puts an added drive to complete even simple sidequests as the added experience is the only way to make your character stronger.Lastly, there are two special meters that will need proper attention. The Humanity meter and the Masquerade meter. A large focus of the game is the focus on struggling against the vampire urges and keeping ones self ‘human' despite needing to drink human blood in order to survive. Certain actions can cause players to lose some of their humanity and, as the gauge lowers to 0, it can result in them becoming utterly feral. Meanwhile, keeping the humanity high can result in a weaker vampire who struggles with their new nature. Additionally, keeping ones actions as a vampire secretive is very key and, every time a player is caught being a vampire in public, it costs them on the Masquerade meter. They start with a set amount of chances and, if those chances ever all disappear, game over (going feral wastes a chance). This puts an added focus on keeping ones nature as a vampire truly secret and staying human as going feral at the wrong time on a player who didn't try to keep hidden can cause an outright loss.Visually the game is fairly solid as well. While, sadly, you won't be able to delve too deep into the many complexities of polygon count, it very successfully manages to convey the feeling of the World of Darkness (the world as a vampire sees it). Vampire does its best to drive this home too, but manages to back it up with some solid displays. While they may look a bit dated today, there is a HUGE difference between ‘dated' and ‘bad' and this is most certainly not the latter.There are some problems with the game though. First off it seems to revel in giving vague directions and not giving you anything resembling a quest-marker. While this wouldn't normally be too bad of a thing it is very easy to end up lost and unsure of where to go or who to talk too, especially if you stop playing the game for a week or more and don't remember the location of an important NPC with the lack of a map (aside from some bus-stop signs) driving the annoyance home. But, more overbearingly, is the glitches. There are a LOT in this game, and they are NOT of the minor kind. These are the kind that can destroy a game and leave it unplayable. Hunting down a patch and/or activating the command console may very well be a requirement for this game.And now for the subjective. This is a dark game. A VERY dark game to say the least. The game makes sure to reinforce this with such locations like abandoned hospitals, scummy apartment buildings, sleazy motels, brothels and night clubs galore, and death around every corner. The streets are almost never clean and are littered with trash, bums and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s seem to be the most common ‘professions', and so forth. People looking for a game about sparkling vampires, or even just ‘normal' vampires may find themselves off-put easily. This is a very dark and pessimistic game, and it ended up causing me to rethink about how to score this.To say that this is a bad game simply because it's world is so scummy and grim is shortselling what the game does right. In any other setting where you can count the number of people who are ‘good' on more than one hand this probably would have been an amazing title. However, this game does not hide for even a moment that this is a grim and depressing world. People not looking for this sort of thing specifically can very easily end up becoming disguised and/or offended by it. Even the ending of the game seems to love rubbing in just how dark this world is.As a result, I feel it is VERY important to look into the game before buying it and deciding if you wish to play a game like this. While it can be enthralling for people who revel in its darkness, for those people looking for even the tiniest ray of light and hope, they would be better off searching elsewhere.In summery: while a solid game that is mired by some technical problems, its subjective aspects and story may simply be so off-putting to a player who does not enjoy its dark and grim world as to not make this game recommendable on a whim. If you buy this game, you should know what you're getting into, because this game is in no way shy about tossing you into the shadows.My pricing: For someone looking for a dark game: 15-20 bucks. It's very solid, if a bit dated and dealing with bugs.For someone not: Avoid at all costs. Remember, this is a game where it is possible to lose because you couldn't pretend to be a human being instead of a blood-sucking monster well enough.

												One of the funnest games in my library. There's loads of options to choose from, featuring rebels and insane prophets to play as. content:
8, 2011
												Seriously a gaming milestone, one of the best games I have ever played. Well made and full of character and intrigue it also features the most frightening sequence I have ever experienced in movie or game format to a point where many people opt to skip the section via the console due to its nature (one could argue if you have played through it once you find it more annoying than scary). It has a lot of great writing and acting in it and the downsides to the game are that it was released before Half-Life 2 and as such valve didn't let them use the fully optimized version of the source engine which led to a lot of bugs. Bloodlines was hurried near the end of production as Troika was going out of business and the combat slog toward the end of the game reflects that. Several people continued to work on the game without pay just to get it as finished as it could be. A fan patch might be necessary for you to fully enjoy this free of some odd bugs but you do yourself a disservice missing out.

3, 2014
												One of the best game i have ever played. Bloodlines features every night creature we know and love into one good RPG. Story is really cool and makes you want to move forward. You were bitten and turned, now you discover the underground world of vampires and need to learn how to be one of them. The game have a lot of interesting NPCs and characters for you to interact or feed if you so wish. Has a compelling vampire lore built that does not sound stupid or untrue. Combat is real time but based on stats (weapon damage + your skills). You have some vampire powers also to use. Boss fights can be a drag, but are not really that bad. You also have a lot of choices and paths to take. You can almost always choose to go peacefull, stealth or all out warfare (depends on skills). Some missions are scary (especially the mansion one, you will know what i am talking about after you played it) and can range from the basic deliver this in there to complex and engaging storylines.From the start you can choose your race and some features. Add some points in skills you desire. You will also visit different cities and locations.Warning: The game have a memory problem, meaning if you have more then 2gb memory ram, you will need to download the unofficial patch, which fixes the problem and many others, so i would recommend it even if you can run it vanilla.The game is fun and fresh, i would recommend it for anyone that likes RPGs and long conversations and choices ala Mass Effect.

content:
y 8, 2013
												I once read a comment that said "Whenever someone mentions Vampire Bloodlines you just know that someone, somewhere, is installing it again.", and I must agree wholeheartedly. I read that a few years ago, mind you, and I have since found other RPGs to add to my "best RPGs of all time" list. But Bloodlines, despite its age, its sort of mediocre gameplay that can confuse you for being based on a set of rules that are not always apparent, despite its dated visual and lack of character customization... Despite all that, the world, characters and tone still keep me coming back. Pretty much every quest is interesting, the dialogs are well writen, the urban fantasy setting is something I wish I could see more often in gaming (especially in RPGs) and it has what simply must be my favourite haunted house level in gaming. Ever.So yes, after almost ten years I still recommend Vampire, if nothing else because it will show you a world like which you won't find in any other videogame.Man, now I feel like starting another playthrough.

content:
er 28, 2011
												Vampire: The Masquerade is a decently well-known role-playing system that I was not familiar with before playing Bloodlines. However, for a new player like myself to jump in without any prior context, Bloodlines does a great job of establishing the fiction of the world of Vampire. What is most impressive is the game's way of forcing a "vampire mentality" on you. The Masquerade is a system requiring vampires to keep their existence secret from humanity, and this sometimes means having to kill innocents in unfortunate circumstances. By not doing so, you risk the lives and foundation of all vampire society. Bloodlines is an open-world modern RPG/adventure, allowing you to take quests while following a main story narrative. For a game released in 2004, the graphics aren't half-bad, and the character expressions/facial animations are actually rather impressive. Be aware that some odd unofficial patching needs to be done to make this game work on modern systems.4 out of 5 foxes.

content:
r 15, 2015
												Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is a heavily story driven Action-RPG where there's several town hubs with whacky characters who want YOU to do their bidding. Everyone has their own ulterior motive and the deep lore that goes into the "World of Darkness" that this game is based on just enhances the feel and depth of this story.The combat mechanics are pretty simple, there's 2 types of weapons, melee and ranged. If you want to be a crazy monster vampire who uses his fists to beat people into dust.. You can do that. If you want to use ranged weapons by running around and shooting people up.. You can do that.  If you want to go around with a katana and slash people up.. You can do that as well. The skill and "clan" system helps you build your character the way you want to. There's many different clans, all of them have different skill sets, pros and cons - There's the nosferatu that need to go through sewers because of their hideous deformed bodies would alert humans of the supernatural. There's the Malkavian who keeps on hearing different voices in their heads (Although most of it seems gibberish, a lot of it is actually true and the voice can also tell you the future or hidden intends behind the people.), malkavians have completely different dialogue options and their lines can also be seen as insane and convoluted with hidden intents. The lore is just so deep in this that you can't help but get invested.This games second strong point is choice. You will have different choices on how to complete your quests, you will have choices on what you would like to do with the item, would you be OK with giving the item to the person who wants it, or can you find a third party who will offer more for it? Do you care for your own humanity and help people out just to keep your connection to the mortal life that you had. Or will you only look out for yourself, discarding the other peoples needs just to further your own agenda. There are multiple choices for everything you do, but what's great is that there's choices that aren't apparent and if you manage to find them they will usually pay off sweetly. This is a masterpiece in gamedesign. You WILL find interesting quests and items if you look around enough and you are not rewarded for going around and killing everything, but are rather ENCOURAGED to do things the way you want to.Even though this game was released in an extremely buggy state because the game developer didn't have enough money to keep working on this. The game has been fixed with several patches (Some of the game devs worked for free after getting laid off, just to fix this. Goes to show how much they actually loved this game.).. Now thanks to the huge community there's several mods, unofficial expansions, etc that completely change up this game.Before buying this game on steam I had already spent more then 100 hours in this, so I've played this for around 200 hours or so..

content:
r 20, 2015
												Resurrected as a vampire after your death, you are recruited to assist in an ongoing war of attrition between several vampire clans who vie for control of Los Angeles. Using a combination of stealth, cunning and brute force, only you can ultimately shape the result of the conflict.Famously released in an unfinished state (though several patches and mods have been released that largely fix this), Bloodlines is a flawed yet absolutely captivating gem of a game that takes the stealth-action RPG hybrid gameplay of series such as Deus Ex and Thief, drapes it in a veneer of equal parts Anne Rice sensual horror and goth club sleaze, and ties it all together with an excellent script dripping with lore, mystery, sexuality, and violence. There's plenty of replay value to be had as well thanks to the diverse array of vampire clans one can play as; from the seductive Toreador or traditionalist Ventrue, to the monstrous Nosferatu or gibbering and insane Malkavian. Just be ready to do some patching after you've installed the game.
